first, let me express my love for this game. The b00bies, the artstyle, the catgirls, the ears, the maid outfits are all masterfully made by Nekoworks, and I'm surprised they haven't recieved trillions in funding yet. There were times were i was suicidal and depressed, standing at the edge of my building when a hand reached out to me. That hand was of Vanilla, the best catgirl in the series. Her fluffy white ears and tail was what stopped me from commitng suicide. This series has brought so much joy and spark to my life i cannot describe. The moment i saw the franchise on steam for sale for 70% off, i cried tears of joy. When my eyes met with the beautiful "400 hkd" price tag, i nearly creamed my panties. There were literal times where i had a blade to my wrist, when the familliar sound "nyaa~" brought me back to my senses. The comprehensive storytelling and love between the catgirls and MC is simply amazing. If there was a way to reset my memories, I would have done so a million times.         next, lets focus less on my personal issues and talk more about the game itself. Nekopara is a series of adult visual novels developed by Neko Works and published by Sekai Project. The first game in the series, Nekopara Vol. 1, was released on December 30, 2014. The series is set in a world where humans live alongside catgirls, known as "Nekos" It is a mastepiece. Catgirls, also known as Nekos (ネコ, cat in Japanese), are an intelligent species of cat-human hybrids that live alongside humans in the Nekopara universe. Catgirls physically resemble humans with feline ears the same color as their hair , slitted pupils, a tail, and a cat-like mouth. Catgirls were once left homeless and living in the streets, but now they are domesticated by humans and aren't allowed to go anywhere by themselves without their masters unless they have a bell. All main catgirls are here as follows.      Chocola - The youngest (together with Vanilla) of the nekos and is Vanilla's biological twin. She has developed a close attachment to Kashou and couldn't bear to be separated from him. Her cat breed is unknown.      Vanilla - Chocola's biological twin and has a very close relationship with her. Vanilla rarely expresses her true emotions and has a kūdere-type and stoic personality. Her cat breed is unknown.      Azuki - Eldest and shortest of the Minazuki's nekos. She has a mischievous and energetic personality and oftenly picks fights with the others. She is a Munchkin Cat.      Maple - The second eldest of the nekos. She is well-informed about technology and enjoys visiting various shops and restaurants to try different foods and drinks. She is an American Curl.      Cinnamon - The third youngest of the nekos. She often interprets and expresses everything in a sexual manner, resulting her to be aroused. She has a very perverted personality. She is a Scottish Fold.      Coconut - The second youngest of the nekos. She possesses a very womanly body though she isn't confident about this and instead, yearns to be called cute. She has a cool personality according to the others. She also appears to have very low self-esteem, and tends to think about things such as suicide when she fails to do something or doesn't meet the standards of others. She is a Maine Coon.      Milk (also known as Food Stand Cat) - A catgirl who manages a takoyaki food stand situated in the park where Kashou, Chocola and Vanilla often visit at during their break hours. She has a similar personality with Chocola, being cheerful and friendly even to new acquaintances. Her cat breed is unknown.   The game series are here as follows: (for fans of the franchise)  Nekopara vol. 0  Nekopara vol. 1  Nekopara vol. 2  Nekopalive (VR supported)  Nekopara vol. 3  Nekopara OVA  Nekopara OVA extra  Nekopara EXTRA  Nekoworks is able to create a coheasive and heartwarming plot and storyline to warm our hearts with these adorable catgirls. Every single thing they do in this game gives me a warm, fuzzy feeling. Everything in this game is perfect, from the catgirls going in heat to the bath scene is all beautifully coreagraphed, with love from Nekoworks. Recently the anime has been released (its nekopara Vol.1) and is a braeutiful, heartwarming callback to my original playthrough of this game. When i finished playing, the only thing that was left was a mixture of my tears and semen. I originally got this game to enjoy myself, stroke the pencil, let the one eyed snake loose, jacking off, masturbating, fapping, bash the bishop, beat it, choke the chicken, punish percy, polish the family jewels, slap the salami, wank it, wax the carrot, wax the dolphin, punch the clown, self abuse, cook up a batch, crack one off, frig, pet (one's) kitty, play with (ones self), drop the kids off at the pool, beat the meat, yank it, fuck your hand or pudwhack. However, halfway through the playthough with my hand on my p3nis, i started crying. The story was simply so moving and emotional that i had to wipe both my tears and ejaculate at the same time. The only issue i had with this game was no traps.  In conclusion; get the game if you want an amazing storyline and beautiful visuals. Or if you want to masturbate. Just get it. good
What can I say but wow. There is a small story as to why this game ended up on my account. You see, I would tend to help friends in various games to help them level, earn rewards, etc. They naturally asked if I wanted any compensation for my efforts. And I would always jokingly respond that the best form of payment is in Nekopara. This “joke” turned into what is now my complete devotion to the characters, world and 18+ patch when one of my friends actually went ahead and got one of the games for me. Now it is easy to explain why I love this series, and yes, a Lenny face is very fitting. This Visual Novel, which make no mistake, is all it is. Puts you in the shoes of a pastry, sweet and cake maker, etc. Who has recently moved out of home to set up a café business. However, upon unpacking his possession finds that two of the boxes contain two of his cat girls, who managed to stow themselves away so they could stay with him. What follows is a cute story of him coming to terms with them wanting to stick with him and the cat girls development as employees of the business…… and other “developments” if you catch my drift. Yes, these cats are not left untouched for very long, and it very quickly sheds it’s somewhat innocent image in exchange for what is the purest, sweetest vanilla fun times that you could ask to come across. Sure, the story has zero interaction, sure the animations aren’t crazy, sure some scenes stagnate when you are reading miles of text. But it just doesn’t matter. Because this is Nekopara. This is the epitome of cat girls. I will come back for the story once and for the real “plot” a hundred times more. I wear my Nekopara badges, wallpapers and achievements with pride. This review will forever be left here, as a sign of pride. Godspeed Neko Works, Godspeed. 10/10

It's a story about a little sister that loves you romantically, but since you're unwilling to engage in a relationship that taboo, she sends two of her catgirls to be your girlfriends instead (which is apparently just the right level of taboo for your character). It's super weird, but if you don't take it too seriously it's actually a fun little visual novel.   Pros: -Great Art -Adorable characters. Yes, I have a weakness for anime catgirls.   -It sticks to the genre without being overly long. This technically isn't a game, but it's also not trying to be. It's a short visual novel without any extra expectations or baggage.  -Pretty much anime crack (or catnip, if you prefer)  Cons: -The story is nonsense. As mentioned above, it's anime crack. If you're looking for something deeper, this ain't it. At least the game knows what it is though. I hate visual novels and anime that act like they're so deep and meaningful but are just bloated, edgy teen fodder *coughattackontitancoughcodegeasscough*.  -Music is just OK, and gets repetitive fast.   Neutral: -There is 18+ DLC for anyone into that. Whether that's a pro or con is up to you.

no
Well...here it is...my review of NEKOPARA Vol. 1. Honestly I don't where to start this game and franchise has become the most addictive thing imaginable to me. However, I'll try to get through this anyway so here goes.  NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a visual novel game with the option of purchasable 18+ content, soundtracks, an artbook and the NEKOPARA OVA Set. The game is set in Japan in a fantasy world where creatures called "catgirls" exist. Catgirls are the combination of a human female and a feline, specifically their body is that of a human with the only exception being that they have cat ears, tails and their ears/tails are the same colour as their hair/fur. The main "protagonist" is a young guy called Kashou Minaduki. He has a younger sister named Shigure and they both own six catgirls. Those catgirls from eldest to youngest go: Azuki, Maple, Cinnamon and Coconut with the youngest of the catgirls being a pair of twin sisters named Chocola and Vanilla and during the time this game is set they are 9 months old in human years. The story in this volume starts off with Kashou moving from the Minaduki household to his own bakery to start his own business "La Soleil" as a patisserie. Chocola and Vanilla hear about the news and set out to get their master to let them stay with him. I won't spoil the rest of the game otherwise some people will complain and I don't want to ruin it for anyone who is thinking of buying it.   Now that the story has been dealt with, what do I think of the game? Well, if you couldn't already tell from my steam profile and steam inventory, I LOVE IT! The characters are animated using a software called E-mote, an advanced software that allows NEKOWORKs to animate the character's bodies. The story is wonderful and was good enough to make me buy volumes 2 and 3 to see the rest of the story and even buy NEKOPARA Extra and volume 0 to see the events before volume 1. If you're here for the 18+ content, you won't be disappointed I would say it's definitely worth it's price and I thoroughly enjoyed the game. The soundtracks to NEKOPARA Vol. 1 are incredible but to be honest the soundtracks are incredible throughout the NEKOPARA franchise. The Vol. 1 artbook is nice and comes in a PDF format in the game's files in the Steam directory. The NEKOPARA OVA Set, in my opinion, is worth the money as it provides you with the 210 page NEKOPARA Chronicles artbook (definitely worth the money just on it's own) and the soundtracks of the NEKOPARA OVA which are as stated earlier incredible (although I prefer the in-game music more than the OVA music I cannot complain).  Do you want catgirls? Do you want a good, gripping story that spans across five games (with Vol. 4 in production and Vol. 5 planned that would make it 7 games)? Do you want 18+ content that you can watch again if you want to at anytime? Do you want some nice theme songs and music to listen to? If you want all of these NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is worth it for you. Before you pay for the full game I recommend downloading the demo and playing that as it goes through the game to the intro video and stops there. Obviously it's up to you if you'd like to purchase specific DLC and leave out others but I'd definitely recommend all the DLC and especially that if you get the game, you get the 18+ content for it too.  If you would've told me one year ago I'd be not only playing this franchise but addicted to it to the point of purchasing figurines, snapback caps, soundtracks, artbooks, all the games, the OVA and OVA Extra, and a huge collection of steam items including the badges, the foil and non-foil trading cards, the backgrounds and the emoticons, then I'd say you're delusional. That was one year ago, here I am now making this review and not regretting getting into this franchise as much as I've done. It's brought so much happiness to me and I've even talked about it with my parents and they have accepted the fact that I play it even with 18+ content. If you want further information on the franchise it won't be difficult to find. This game will always be remembered as the start of an addiction that I love and I'm happy I started.  NEKOPARA isn't for everyone but I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who is interested in buying it. If you're not too rushed about purchasing it then I'd wait till a Steam Sale and purchase it then, you won't be disappointed.  Thanks NEKOWORKs, Sayori, Sekai Project and anyone who has worked on the NEKOPARA franchise as a whole, I look forward to the Nekoparaiten mobile game, the rest of the TV anime series and NEKOPARA Vol. 4 and Vol. 5.  That's it for this review, sorry for making it so long but I kind of had to. It's the one thing that has made me happier ever since.

Truly a very immersive narrative horror game that my foreskin crawl.
[b]Vanilla[/b] is a clever and quiet catgirl who loves Chocola. She is Chocola’s twin sister and the youngest among the Minaduki catgirls. [b]Vanilla[/b] is prone to be misunderstood because she rarely expresses her emotions. In fact, she is quite smart and often makes some remarkable insights. Her sharp wit and I’ll-do-things-my-way attitude make her Chocola’s complete opposite. However, she remains both kind-hearted and, well, catlike.  In contrast to her twin Chocola, [b]Vanilla[/b]'s ears, tail and hair are primarily white with a subtle pink undertone. She has blue eyes which are often slightly squinted, and her hair is tied up and styled as twin tails supported by a blue ribbon strand.  Her usual attire consists of a light blue and navy blue lolita-style dress with white shin-length socks with garter trims and blue Mary Jane shoes. She wears two large blue ribbons; one on the top of her head and one on her collar. Her left hand is lightly wrapped around with a blue string and she wears a small garter near the tip of her tail.  [b]Vanilla[/b] is quiet, calm and very stoic. She rarely expresses her emotions, making her a somewhat of a kūdere character, as opposed to her sister's energetic, playful personality. She loves her twin sister Chocola and will accompany her always due to her sis-con-like relationship towards her.  [b]Race:[/b] Catgirl [b]Breed:[/b] Mixed Breed [b]Gender:[/b] Female [b]Age:[/b] 9 months old [i](11 years old in human age)[/i]

heh
Who would have thought that the weirdest thing in a game about catgirls is actually your little sister, who is 100% human? Me neither, but it happened.  In all fairness, the dialogue was at times truly hilarious - I found myself laughing at my pc a couple of times whereas this game is clearly not (primarily) meant for that, but it really got me at times with Vanilla's witty remarks. There's also quite a bit of cheesy talk near the end which I was a bit less of a fan of, but nothing that really broke the experience for me.   Truth be told, I did look up the uncensor patch, but it would seem that it did not work after I installed it - I actually feel like that was not such a bad thing in the end. Most of the experience for me now was just a light-hearted, genuinly funny visual novel with clear attention to detail, from their facial expressions (which only very rarely ventured into the uncanny valley) to their motions (yes, there is a 'chest bounciness' slider in the menu which I kept at about half, which seemed fine), to the voice acting, which was pretty well done in my opinion (despite every other sentence ending with a meow, but you get desensitised pretty quickly).   Now, to address the elephant in the room, is it worth the full price? I would have to say 'no' unfortunately, for the gameplay is literally non-existent to the point that if you would check 'auto' and leave, your computer would play the whole game for you to the end in about 6 hours. I got it in a -50% sale and I think that then it is about worth it, if you can appreciate these kind of things, that is.  Long story short, I would actually recommend to 'play' this game exactly how it is on steam, for it offers a nice feel-good story with cute characters that makes you forget about the world around you, but just not enough to prevent you from looking over you shoulder periodically, because... you know, just in case. Even though it is all pretty harmless in the end. If you are looking for a very deep story, this is not the place to look, but you already knew that from the start. If you are looking for something very erotic, I would just recommend opening an incognito tab in google and go have fun that way. If you just want to enjoy a couple of relaxing evenings, consider giving it a go. Who knows, maybe you'll like it.  One concluding remark: I don't think playing this game or any related stuff is something to be ashamed of. You were probably expecting me to say something like 'this game was gifted to me ;_;' or 'I was forced to play this lol', but you know what? I bought this game for myself because it seemed fun. There. I said it. And in the end, it was indeed fun, I laughed and the girls were cute - I have no regrets. No regrets at all.  So, that was all I had to say, sitting behind my pc at 3 AM (yes, I know I'm not living up to my statements in previous paragraph, but at least I didn't set my status to offline, which I know you will). And after all this only one question remains: why did I go through the effort of seriously reviewing this game in the first place? Perhaps some questions are better left unanswered.

Personal Rating \\ 10/10   This game is a masterfully crafted first-person shooter with the charm of Titanfall 2 and the fast-paced, shoot to kill feel of Call of Duty. I couldn't recommend this game more to my friends. I've spent dozens of hours playing this game and its many, many modes.  Search and Destroy has to be my favorite, especially since the characters, such as Coconut and Vanilla, don't impact gameplay as much as they do in the TDM mode. Each character has their quirks and bugs but in all honesty, none of them are gamebreaking. I do believe however that the developers made a good decision in allowing a photography mode into the singleplayer campaign.  On the note of campaign. Every second of it is an artistic masterpiece and the player is (or should be) always engaged in the character design and how the characters constantly stay interesting throughout the complete story. The plot never feels too confusing or stereotypical. Controls are extremely fluid and have a massive amount of customizability. You never feel too weak or too strong, and you never feel like there's no way to make an impact, even from moment one. There are plenty of available weapons and even more you can unlock. Many of them are cosmetic, but others are unique weapons with many easter eggs. No spoilers :)  Honestly, if I had to play only one game for the rest of my life, it'd have to be Nekopara, any of them in the series.  PS: Vanilla still best girl

Not too long. Part 1 and 2 are like 5 hours. And part 3 is like 7 hours. But the whole series is very cute and fun. Superb voice acting. Gorgeous animated CGs with idle breathing animations, moving mouths, emoting and other things like that. So really high production value. Virtually no bugs. I had 2 or 3 occasions, where the text would not fit the voice, but nothing serious. Every character has a little arc to it, which makes it a joy to read. And there are also some emotional moments for each character and a satisfying "end" for every one. This alone would make it a really good VN. But then there's all the lewd scenes, if you decided to buy the 18+ DLCs. Those ramp up the quality to 11. They are animated in something that looks like 2.5D, relatively long and good finishes. You get a couple of thoose per character. So that's basically the cherry on the pie.  You can totally ebjoy the all-ages version. But I think, the 18+ stuff is also worth it's money.  So overall, a really great, really cute, really fun VN series.

Guys, this is exactly what you want :)
Ewan McGregor really helped sell the emotion of the movie, acting phenomenally considering that a majority of his co-stars were CGI stuffed animals. As the movie progresses, his character becomes less and less serious and more playful, and McGregor pulls this transition off phenomenally, being both funny and believable. Many actors, specifically comedy actors, would have overdone this transition, making their funny moments over the top just to get a laugh. McGregor still managed to get a laugh, humorously yet believably becoming more like Pooh as the movie progressed in a natural, yet still entertaining manner.  While the return of all of the animal characters was fantastic, Pooh truly stood out as the star of the show. Eeyore's self loathing, Piglet's anxiety, and Tigger's pride with his uniqueness certainly added their own factors to the mix, but Pooh still stood out. This movie reminded audiences of why Winnie the Pooh was such a great character to begin with: he represents everything good in this world. He teaches us to appreciate the little things and to take the time to appreciate what you have.   The genius part of Christopher Robin is that, when the movie actually started, Christopher Robin and Winnie the Pooh were polar opposites. This was an incredibly clever way to start the story, as in all of the previous Winnie the Pooh stories, Christopher Robin and Pooh were almost always on the same page. This change to Christopher Robin's character added a new twist to the movie that would certainly be relatable for any adults who watched Winnie the Pooh as a kid. This entire piece of character development was a clever writing twist that certainly helped to keep the movie incredibly interesting.  Another factor that kept the movie interesting and visually entertaining was the color scheme. While the trailers showed that it would have a desaturated look, the finished product itself had a gorgeous red tint to it. It made the sunset scenes in Hundred Acre Wood absolutely beautiful, turning the classic scenes from the cartoons and books into an even more gorgeous piece of imagery.  All things considered, the latest live-action movie from Walt Disney Pictures is a truly heartwarming experience that any Disney fan is sure to enjoy. The return of the classic characters, and the in-depth development from Christopher Robin, portrayed by Ewan McGregor, made the movie enjoyable and touching. Though it may not bring in the big bucks like Beauty and the Beast did, Christopher Robin is still a great success from Disney and stands out from the rest of their live-action movies.

[quote] Please follow our curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/4680120/]Otome Lovers[/url], if you'd like to see more reviews like this one!	[/quote]  [h1]Introduction[/h1]  Nekopara is a popular visual novel. It is mainly known for its stunning art, and for its mature content, which are unlocked through a paid DLC. This VN is fully voiced, and the sprites are all fully animated too. While the story is mediocre at best, it definitely makes up for it with the stunning art and the wonderful soundtracks!  In Nekopara, you play as Kashou Minaduki, a young adult male who is about to open his own patisserie in order to pursue his dreams. He’s all set, ready to open up the next day, when he suddenly notices two of the family’s catgirls have managed to sneak in! Unable to send them back due to their love for him, Kashou has to try and manage a business and look after the catgirls too!  [h1]Pros[/h1]  - Stunning art. Seriously. The sprites are all animated smoothly, and the cg’s are absolutely beautiful too. - Fully voiced. With the exception of the protagonist, all the characters are fully voiced. While there isn’t an English dub, the Japanese voice actors still did really well. - The NSFW scenes are really well written and honestly, some of the best I’ve seen. Which makes sense since Nekopara is promoted as a game well-known for its mature content.  [h1]Cons[/h1]  - The story is pretty bland, but most slice of life stories can be lacking in story. - Unable to play as a female protagonist. - You have to pay extra for the NSFW DLC. For a game that’s been promoted as a NSFW game, it’s a little strange they decided to lock all the mature content behind a DLC.  [h1]Love Interests[/h1]  Nekopara Vol. 1 has two main love interests.  Chocola - Chocola is Vanilla’s twin sister. She’s the more energetic and cheerful out of all the Minaduki catgirls. She can act quite childish, and hardly ever ends up being upset.   Vanilla - Vanilla is Chocola’s twin sister. In contrast to Chocola, she’s more stoic and calm. She’s happy to do whatever Chocola wants, as she loves her twin sister a lot.  [h1]Conclusion[/h1]  Most people do tend to buy VN’s for the story, but I believe an exception can be made for Nekopara’s distinct and stunning art style. Even though you do have to pay extra for the NSFW DLC, I would still suggest in buying it in order to enrich your experience! For reference, it took me about 8 hours to complete the game, but I did leave it on auto and waiting for every line to finish before moving on to the next line.   [quote] Please follow our curator page, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/4680120/]Otome Lovers[/url], if you'd like to see more reviews like this one!	[/quote]

I luv my neko lolis
Distilled catgirl cuteness!  PROS: This is a rather basic kinetic visual novel, but it plays to it's strength.  The story is coherent and straightforward, and though no end goal is given through the novel, it's the kind of story that doesn't need one.  It's fluff, cutesy and adorable with some emotional substance provided for the characters.  The art is fairly standard, as is the soundtrack, but I did enjoy the main theme, 'Taiyou Paradise.'  CONS: It is a rather basic kinetic visual novel, so the lack of choices may turn a few people off.  Having to pay extra for any sort of H-material seems to be grasping for a bit of extra cash, and feels a little odd.  A key bother, though, is the moving characters during the novel.  The way they dart about has an uncanny valley effect, and just comes off a bit stiff and unnatural at times.  The addition of a 'bounce' feature feels equally confusing.  ACHIEVEMENTS: Another visual novel that really only requires story progression.  Thanks to the style, most will be unlocked with one pass, though a quick start with the languages to round it off.  FINAL: This was a rather adorable experience that one can find enjoyment in, H-scenes or SFW.  It does feel like just adorable fluff in VN form, but it's the type of quick break that was enjoyed over the period of time played, and does leave a positive feeling for the later games to hopefully continue the story in the same charming, adorable light.

Nekopara.....  It is a Visual Novel It has nice music It has cute Neko's It has Jiggle physics You can pet the Neko's  .....and you can do the sexy.......  But in all seriousness, Nekopara is a great visual novel series which tell the lighthearted tale of a group of Neko friends who take a liking towards the main character. The stories are fun and comedic and their is deep meaning to some of them. The arts style is beautiful with bright vibrant colours and expertly drawn and animated characters and backgrounds.  The MC owns and runs a bakery and is helped by the Neko's. It is a slice of life V.N which tells the story of each character and their connection with the MC and each other, alongside them working alongside the MC helping him run the bakery. It is a nice story to sit down for an evening and read/watch and spend a couple of hours on each episode (Nekopaara Episode 0-4).  Now for the <cough> ADLUT MATURE ULTRA SEXY BIT. Yes this game is typically rated 18 as there is an option to purchase an Adult 18+ DLC which removes certain censors in scenes to show full nude of the characters and in their acts. It also includes additional scenes of the MC ...."lewding" up the nekos if you know what I mean hehehe. But yeah there's that for you ULTRA NEKO LOVERS.  Overall, its a fun game with a nice funny story and lewdness......I approve >_<

After a year and a half and at least four readings, I think it's finally time I reviewed NEKOPARA. While the thousands of meme reviews are indeed quite funny, I figured it would be best for me to put in some serious effort. So then, let me share with you why this series, particularly this first volume, resonates so well with me.  Where do I start? Well, if you've taken a peek at some screenshots, you'll likely come to some easy conclusions. You may think the CGs are plentiful and varied, the backgrounds are high quality, and the sprites are incredibly detailed. Indeed, you'd be right, except for the last bit. You see, NEKOPARA isn't content with mere sprites that you'd see with most other visual novels. Instead, you'll notice that characters are in fact rendered in 3D, but still look very anime-esque. At least, that's the best way for me to describe them. Characters are in constant animation, often moving around in the screen space, with fluid facial expressions provided by the "e-mote" system. If you believe that VNs are too formulaic-looking, NEKOPARA will be a pleasant surprise.  In addition to glorious visual prowess, NEKOPARA also features complimentary sounds. There's a healthy amount of music, and each track does a good job of setting the tone of each moment. The opening theme never fails to get me dancing! Sound effects are numerous as well, and coupled with the visual movements, I find that they do a good job of eliminating the need of many awkward and drawn out descriptions that other VNs might require (though some of them are...well, you'll know when you hear them). As for the voice acting, I don't have any complaints really. I love how even though it's all in Japanese, you'll often hear English words and phrases thrown in nonchalantly. It's charming, really. Everything works together to be a joy for the senses.  As for the story, I'm not exactly sure what I expected. You've likely seen the memes already, and they're undoubtedly part of the drive behind the series' success. That said, NEKOPARA offers more than one might expect at first. At its core, the story is a slice of life with catgirls, which leads to some interesting moments, to say the least. It's about Kashou Minaduki, an aspiring baker who leaves his home and family business to open his own store. He's accompanied by two of his family's (more specifically, his sister Shigure's) catgirls, the carefree and oblivious Chocola, and the cheeky and intelligent Vanilla. These three learn to become an eccentric family-like unit together, all while learning to manage the new store. Overall, there are plenty of humorous and lighthearted moments. Even after several readings, they still manage to get some hefty laughs out of me. Chocola and Vanilla each have their quirks as catgirls, and I think the best moments are when they interact as a duo and show them off. Kashou himself his a bit dense, but I do like him in general. Occasionally though, things can get serious, and a couple times I managed to let a few tears loose. It's silly to think that such a story could pull that off, but maybe it's that very surprise that got to me the most. I won't spoil the ending chapter, but man, that did a number on me! Overall, I found the writing to be very solid, and no doubt much of this is thanks to a great localization. I won't try and proclaim that this volume is literary high art, but it understands exactly what it wants to do and does it very effectively.  Alright, I've managed to avoid it thus far, but it's about time we talk about the naughty bits. Yeah, the very basis of most of the memes. My first reading without the lewd patch was about five hours long. Later on when I finally did install it, I think it was roughly one hour of additional content. There's three scenes in all, and wow do they get intense. This is when the animations go into overdrive, and you may find out that your PC isn't quite up to snuff for them. In fact, if you notice the opening cinematic getting out of sync with the theme, I would recommend turning off those animations. Also, my goodness, those sounds effects are strange. As to the question of if you need the patch, well, it's your call. If you really don't want to participate in that stuff, don't feel pressured to, because it's not necessary to enjoy everything else. But if you're a connoisseur of such content, expect quality. There's a reason everyone talks about it...  I've praised this volume quite a bit already, but I guess I should address some nitpicks. Even though she has some good moments, I don't care much for Shigure. She's just crazy at times. Also, the scene in which all six Minaduki catgirls are present feels a bit crowded, and you don't get to much of a sense of the others until later on. Finally, while I was alright with it, I can imagine some readers may be put off by the intense voice acting, so I could understand if you feel the need to hush or completely mute it. Ultimately though, these are minor complaints, and this is all I could really think of to mention.  Now that I've said all I need to, I can fully recommend NEKOPARA vol. 1 to anyone who might be interested. If you're a veteran of visual novels, it's practically required reading. This was actually one of my first VN experiences, and it absolutely got me interested in the genre as a whole. Fair warning though, it may not be fair to expect other VNs to measure up to this series, because it's just that unique and great. While many of the reviews are humorous and not particularly informative, the overwhelmingly positive status they give does not lie. Unless you're highly averse to these offerings for whatever reason, I can't recommend NEKOPARA enough!

best 10.3 hours of my life
i had a lot of fun with the fast paced fps aspect of this game. in the sense that you can actually feel what the other player is doing at any given moment. it really gives you a feeling that you're literally connected to everyone but at the same time competing for the most strength and getting the most powerful weapons.  i'd say the tutorial needs a bit of a rework, because when you spawn in for the first time it's always incredibly overwhelming. that happens mostly because anyone can feel anyone's strength at any given moment. in fact this game does have a chat feature but it's not even necessary. you can mostly tell the message of anyone by just looking in their eyes. you can feel what every other player does, has, needs and feels at any given moment. you can react to feeling someone's something any way you want, but one thing is for sure, everyone else will know what you felt in response to that other person's feeling. and it just leads to an endless mindfuck domino of intimate subconscious messages that could not be expressed in a linguistic language   the voice chat experience is absolutely out of this fucking world. you have to hold both ctrl and a to enable speech, thank fuck i changed that in the controls menu. but eitherway that's besides the point. what i'm trying to say is that because this game feels so intimate, talking to other players is an almost sexual experience.  all npc's in this game play more of a guiding role in this game. for example  chocola shows you how to greedily feel everything to the brim vanilla shows you a place to rest when you feel you've felt enough coconut does something related to your kpu settings idfk something like that  i swear to god one time the chocola npc was unavailable, so, with nowhere to access her "shops", some dude asked me for 3 sticks and 1 iron bar and the moment i said "yes" i felt his fucking heart skip a beat, then mine skipped two, and we were eventually in sync. that very moment i swear i turned gay. i turned gay. this fucking game turned me gay.  the most interesting part is that all emotions seem to balance out because of the way all emotions seem to connect and blend into a warm liquid in which everyone can experience everything at the same time.  it doesn't matter what race, height, weight, nationality ... or hell even what gender you are. this game teaches you how to feel love. it connects us as human beings, it throws the harsh laws of evolution out the window. sex doesn't even feel intimate anymore. competition never induces jealousy or feelings of lonliness, it only teases you into oblivion.  the interesting part is that if you start to love a player in this game you can't hide it for a microsecond, because they would immediately feel you, and they would immediately respond back with something (again, subconsciously) and you will respond back with something else and something else and someone else and if they don't reject you then welcome to unicorn world but else you will just get over it and just go look for someone else and immediately fall in love again ^ all of this happens in aprox 0.028 seconds  you can't really feel much pain from the rejection because everything happens way too quickly for your brain to be able to comprehend the negative emotions. that is because negative emotions take thought, but positive ones don't have to  this is what god wanted from us, this is what god was trying to teach us all along by putting us on this world. teaching us that in fact nothing matters, teaching us that suffering (even in the slightest) is not something you just "deal" with, it's something tied to evolution and survival, and when that dies out thanks to technology slowly we still feel it but slowly we instead start to indulge ourselves in it to the point where we are not even anything alive anymore and we just exist as something beyond comprehension  con: a bug i found with using nvidia 3040 gpu sometimes your vision turns black when in a watery place

I love catgirls(2).
Fun fact: There's a thing called "R-18 patch". I'm just saying.
I got this after hearing about it online. First, yes, it's ultimately *that* kind of game, so expect that kind of thing in here.  But what makes this worth the price to me - when I could easily find free stuff online - are the sheer depth of the characters. Chocola and Vanilla are absolutely *charming* in their portrayal, emphasized by the skill their respective actresses bring, and they both work wonderfully as natural compliments to each other, each of them making up for the other.  The story is also very charming in itself. Though it is a typical "harem"-style story with an inevitable conclusion, the writing helps bring it to life; Chocola confessing her sadness early on actually tore at me, and Vanilla's mischievous streak had me cackling at times. In this case, it is the journey itself that counts more then the destination, and the journey was enjoyable all the way through!  The supporting cast are also quite good, though a bit lacking in depth currently. Still, I know there's more volumes out there, so I'm sure they'll all get their own screen time.  My one complaint: the graphics are a bit...stiff. It sucks that only one character can seem to move at a time, which makes for some initially confusing moments. Fortunately, the writing is good enough that the confusion goes away quickly after moving to the next couple of sections, but it did detract a bit at times. There also seem to be a few glitches with the speech where you sometimes have to click twice to make the full text appear (a problem if you're not a natural Japanese speaker, as VO is only in Japanese).  Still, none of this was nearly enough to detract from my enjoyment, and I'm looking forward to trying the other volumes in Neokpara soon!  ...Oh, and for those who are new to Graphic Novels: this isn't really a "game", as there's no interactivity beyond what you might get out of an actual book (click to move on to the next sequence, bookmark your spot for later, etc). No mini-games or puzzles or other stuff like that. THIS IS NOT A BAD THING as it allows you to focus more on the store; just be prepared when you come in.

As a visual novel, nekopara is pretty solid and looks great, nice and cute character design, enjoyable soundtrack and a easy to follow story.   For anyone who doesn't know, this "game" it's not exactly that, you don't have any kind of power over the characters you are watching, since visual novels only focuses on showing you a story, kinda like a book or a novel, but they give you soundtrack, scenarios, character design and voice acting, so you won't have a lot of fun unless you really like the story behinf it.  Talking about the story, it's a pretty simple but cute one, that's why I would recomend anyone who likes slice of life anime and that kinf of stuff to buy this game, so you can sit down with a nice cup of coffe and watch those cute catgirls going around and doing cute things.  Finally, in case you haven't noticed yet, this game contains 18+ material (now though, there was a steam actualization that contained all the 18+ content for this game, when it was originally released those scenes were censored and did not appear in the game, now it's in there so... enjoy them), this scenes were not really important for the story but you can see another side of the catgirls you like, o the ones you dislike, in case you do, and I think anyone playing this game should see them.   To sum it up, this is not a game, it's more like reading a novel with cute anime catgirls and voice acting, with some lewds scenes and a happy feeling sorrounding every scene, if you feel lonely I recomend you to buy it so you can feel that warm feeling that you can't get in real life.

Knowing this, we can safely assume that a 1 year old catgirl is around the human age of 16, and you know what 16 year olds do? That's right! They get drafted into the army. First of all, I have to come out and say that Metal Gear Solid was the previous titleholder for the Solid Snake crown. With the creative boss battles and innovative style it was well worth replaying over and over despite the naysayers who complain about its length. After all, the same thing can be said for Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty with its incessant Codec conversations and movies. Strip away MGS2's story and there's a pretty short game there as well. As for its story itself there's little of interest unless you really want to spend a couple of late, smoky nights going over the details and putting all the pieces together, and they do fit together. While that's kind of interesting if you want a pleasant mind rutting, it was far from fun to watch a game eat itself.  Still, the one thing that MGS2 did right, fantastically right, was take the gold standard of stealth espionage action from MGS and update it beautifully for the current generation. The graphics were amazing to look at and with the new sets of moves and details to dig into, gamers kept going back again and again for more to try out a situation in a different way or collect all of the dog tags they could get. It was so slick and pulled off so well that it even helped the Metal Gear RAY battle go down nicely, or at least be stomached.

Strictly for seasoned veterans of Grand Strategy games, this game is BRUTALLY difficult. I would recommend watching about 5 or so hours of tutorial videos before starting. You play as Cashew, the worlds most oblivious man who has been sprayed with some kind of ultra pheromone that attracts genetic cat-human hybrids. You must resist these freaks as they advance on you as much as possible, failure to do so will result in the bad ending where our hero Cashew ends up mesmerized by the evil Chocola and Vanilla, who have their way with him. If you think you have the skills to get to the good ending, and appreciate a game where almost every choice results in faliure, then by all means give it a go. However in my 20 hours of playing I have still yet to ward off those mutants, no matter what I do it always seems to result in the bad ending. Good luck!
I don't normally play third-person shooters but this is by far the best one that I've played.  EDIT: free badge

How to make Vanilla Cake  INGREDIENTS 1 1/2 c. sifted cake flour 1 1/2 tsp. baking powder 1/4 tsp. salt 1/2 c. unsalted butter 1 c. sugar 2 large eggs 1/2 tsp. vanilla extract 1/2 c. whole milk   INSTRUCTIONS Heat the oven to 400 degrees F. Lightly coat an 8-inch cake pan with butter and dust with all-purpose flour. Sift the cake flour, baking powder, and salt into a large mixing bowl. Beat in the butter one heaping 1/4 teaspoonful at a time, using an electric mixer set on low speed, until the mixture resembles coarse sand. Beat in the sugar a tablespoon at a time, until the mixture resembles fine damp sand. Beat in the eggs one at a time. Add the vanilla and milk, and beat on medium-high, just until blended. Do not overbeat. Pour into the prepared pan and bake until a wooden skewer inserted in the center comes out clean—30 to 35 minutes. Cool cake in the pan on a wire rack for 5 minutes. Un-mold and cool completely. Ice with Browned-Butter Glaze.

When I was a little boy, I visited my father in the hospital. He was in and out of conciousness, but while he was relatively lucid he told me that I had to grow up quickly and teach myself how to be a man. He told me that, although it was going to be difficult, I would have to become the kind of person that he always knew I could be and make both him and my mother proud. He said that I needed to learn how to value my life and use my time to discover for myself what was, and was not, important to me. Two days later, he passed away... Now, ten years later, I'm sitting at my computer spending hours reading a VN about a guy who wants to f@ck genetically engineered catgirls while operating a bakery... I guess what I'm trying to say is: I DID IT PAPA! YOUR BABY BOY DUN DIDDIT! Even though he's no longer with me, I like to think he's looking down at me, alone, sitting at my computer and resting easy in the knowledge that I took his advice to heart. 13/10 would make tastless and long-winded joke about my dead father again.

A solid first entry for the Nekopara saga. The silly dialogues and (optional) nsfw are really well done and the VN was overall enjoyable even though it did drag on for a bit longer than i would have liked it to.  The E-mote tech they use to animate the sprites is great and i would personally like to see something of the sort in every VN i play, it adds more life to the characters [spoiler] (It's also awesome for the nsfw scenes) [/spoiler] .
It is a great game to just sit back and relax while enjoying the story; especially if you want to take a break from intensive games that requires keyboard smashing. I also really love how cute Vanilla and Chocola are.
Dota 2 — компьютерная многопользовательская командная игра в жанре multiplayer online battle arena, разработанная Valve Corporation. Является независимым продолжением карты-модификации DotA для игры Warcraft III. Dota 2 работает по модели free-to-play с элементами микроплатежей.  Разработка игры началась в 2009 году, когда компания Valve приняла на работу основного разработчика DotA — IceFrog, а летом 2010 года подала заявку на регистрацию этой торговой марки. 13 октября 2010 года на игровом портале Game Informer игра была анонсирована к выходу в 2011 году. 15 августа 2011 года в официальном блоге был опубликован трейлер к игре. Dota 2 вышла в июле 2013 года после того, как два года находилась в стадии бета-тестирования.  Изначально Dota 2 была выпущена на игровом движке Source, после чего в 2015 году была портирована на Source 2, став первой работающей на нём игрой. В Dota 2 предусмотрена возможность создавать пользовательские режимы игры, оформление карты и косметические предметы для героев, после чего добавить их в Dota 2 при помощи Steam Workshop. Dota 2 является одной из наиболее популярных игр в Steam и получила в целом положительные отзывы критиков за игровой процесс, качество производства и сохранение положительных сторон своей предшественницы. Среди основных недостатков игры была отмечена сложность обучения.  В игре принимают участие две команды по пять человек, каждая из которых имеет собственную базу на карте. Все игроки управляют одним из героев, обладающих уникальными способностями и различными стилями игры. Побеждает команда, разрушившая главное здание противника (англ. Ancient).  Dota 2 является активной киберспортивной дисциплиной, в которой профессиональные команды со всего мира соревнуются в различных лигах и турнирах. Премиум-турниры по Dota 2 имеют призовые фонды в миллионы долларов, не раз становившиеся крупнейшими в истории киберспорта. Самый крупный турнир по игре — The International, ежегодно проводимый Valve на стадионе Ки-арена в Сиэтле. Каждый сезон Valve также организует The Major. Крупные профессиональные турниры по Dota 2 транслируются на видеостриминговых сервисах, иногда набирая свыше миллиона зрителей одновременно. Людей, играющих в Dota 2, часто называют «дотерами». В игре участвуют две команды по пять человек. Одна команда играет за светлую сторону (англ. The Radiant), другая — за тёмную (англ. The Dire). Каждый игрок управляет одним персонажем, который называется героем. Герой может получать опыт для повышения своего уровня, зарабатывать золото, покупать и собирать предметы, которые усиливают его или дают дополнительные способности. Каждый игрок постоянно получает небольшое количество золота от своей базы, а также зарабатывает небольшие порции золота за убийство вражеских существ и большие — за убийство героев. Команды рассредотачиваются по линиям, на которых происходит борьба с вражескими героями и отрядами крипов (англ. creeps) под управлением компьютера, которые каждые полминуты появляются на базах команд. Цель игры — уничтожить главное здание на вражеской базе. Разработчики игры внесли ряд нововведений и улучшений в игровой процесс по сравнению с оригинальной игрой:  Поддержка переподключения (если случился разрыв соединения, можно вернуться в течение 5 минут, если это не сделано — игрок получает низкий приоритет поиска игры). Возможность поставить паузу в игре нажатием одной кнопки. Встроенный голосовой чат. В игре существует разделение игроков по территориальным зонам (в данный момент их четырнадцать: западная и восточная Европа, восток и запад США, Южная Америка, Россия, Индия, Южная Корея, Юго-Восточная Азия, Австралия, Чили, Перу, Дубай и Южная Африка), но при желании игроки могут играть в любой из этих зон. Проблема с задержками и лагами решена сведением к минимуму задержки между серверами и оптимизацией сетевого кода. Красочное, чистое и понятное визуальное представление действий. Доступны компьютерные боты с настраиваемой моделью поведения в виде сложности, которые могут играть вместе и/или против игроков; Продвинутая система повторов, присутствуют как обычные возможности, в виде перемотки и камеры от разных персонажей, так и возможность закладок, просмотр графиков, коллективный просмотр и многое другое. Также повторы будут храниться в Steam Cloud, что позволит игрокам не беспокоиться о потере повторов и о переносе их между разными компьютерами. Возможность присоединиться к любой незакрытой игре в качестве зрителя. Возможность быстро и легко настроить горячие клавиши. Наличие обучающих заданий, которые объясняют новичкам основы игры. Возможность просмотра информации о нанесённом уроне убитому игроку. История серии игр Dota началась в 2003 году с Defense of the Ancients (DotA) — пользовательской модификации для игры Warcraft III: Reign of Chaos, созданной разработчиком с псевдонимом Eul. Дополнение для Warcraft III под названием The Frozen Throne было выпущено позже в том же году. Модификации серии Defense of the Ancients для нового дополнения соревновались в популярности. Наибольший успех имела DotA: Allstars, разработанная Стивом Фиком с псевдонимом Guinsoo, и Фик совместно с его другом Стивом Месконом создали официальный сайт сообщества Defense of the Ancients, а также компанию DotA-Allstars, LLC. Когда Фик в 2005 году прекратил работу над DotA: Allstars, его друг с псевдонимом IceFrog стал геймдизайнером игры. Популярность Defense of the Ancients значительно возросла, модификация была одной из самых общеизвестных в мире, а к 2008 году стала киберспортивной дисциплиной. В мае 2009 года в результате ссоры с Месконом IceFrog открыл новый сайт сообщества по адресу playdota.com.  Интерес Valve к обладанию Defense of the Ancients начался, когда несколько опытных сотрудников компании, включая дизайнера Team Fortress Робина Волкера, стали поклонниками модификации и активно в неё играли. Valve связалась с IceFrog по электронной почте с намерением узнать о его дальнейших планах по поводу игры, и впоследствии наняла его для руководства над разработкой продолжения DotA. IceFrog впервые объявил об этом в октябре 2009 года в своём блоге. Dota 2 была анонсирована на Game Informer в октябре 2010 года. Объявление о предстоящем выходе привело к резкому подъёму интереса к игре и вызвало перегрузку и отказ серверов Game Informer.  Название «Dota» было заимствовано Valve из акронима оригинальной модификации как наименование недавно приобретённой франшизы. Сотрудник компании Эрик Джонсон утверждал, что название обозначает понятие игры, так как используется в повседневной речи, и не является акронимом. Вскоре после анонса Dota 2 Valve подала заявку на товарный знак с названием Dota. В 2011 году на Gamescom глава компании Гейб Ньюэлл прокомментировал это, пояснив, что товарный знак был необходим для разработки продолжения с уже легко узнаваемым названием. Сделав название Dota общественным достоянием, Фик и Мескон зарегистрировали противостоящий товарный знак «DOTA» от имени DotA-Allstars, LLC, впоследствии ставшей дочерней компанией Riot Games с августа 2010 года. Вице-президент Blizzard Entertainment Роб Пардо сходным образом заявил, что название DotA принадлежало сообществу игроков модификации. Blizzard приобрела DotA-Allstars, LLC от Riot Games и в ноябре 2011 года подала возражения против Valve, ссылаясь на право собственности Blizzard как на Warcraft III World Editor, так и на DotA-Allstars, LLC, в качестве достаточного основания для претензий на владение всей франшизой. Конфликт был разрешён в мае 2012 года; права на коммерческое использование товарного знака «Dota» было сохранено за Valve, при этом было разрешено некоммерческое использование названия третьими лицами.  Ранней целью команды разработчиков Dota 2 была адаптация художественного стиля Defense of the Ancients к игровому движку Source. Названия сторон — «Стражи» (англ. «The Sentinel») и «Плеть» (англ. «The Scourge») — были заменены на светлую (англ. «The Radiant»)

The good shit!
I don't know why this game is labelled as "Story Rich". There is no story at all. Just a guy who lives with catgirls going through his daily life. The characters are simple and bland and the catgirls are not very amusing. Though I haven't finished the game yet, I'm pretty convinced that things won't be getting any better in the later chapters.   Not worth the money, nor the time. It only has nice visuals; some sort of album version would have been more fitting than turning this into a "Visual Novel". And it did have japanese voice-acting, but they weren't particularly amazing and fit the annoying characters well.   The music was a bit loud and a little repetetive and obnoxious.   Edit: I finished this Kinetic Novel (there's no choices to make, so it's not a visual novel), and it's more boring and even less meaningful than a lame slice-of-life anime can get.  The only character in the Kinetic Novel who was somewhat likeable was the main character's sister, who had romantic feelings towards him (though she wasn't forceful and the main character brushed the occaisional weird comments as jokes).   TL;DR: Why does this game have an overwhelmingly positive rating if it's no good? Because of the people who bought it with the R18 patch for just the adult content.

Uh oh...
I highly recommend this series to anyone who likes adorable anime cat-girls.  It is exactly what it looks like.  A visual novel about cat-girls who work as maids in the player's bakery.  Most of the game is very cute and friendly, but there are scenes of an adult nature. If you aren't into anime cat-maid nudes, don't worry, you can click through these few scenes very quickly and just ignore that aspect of the story quite easily.  Truly beautiful background art, and extremely adorable character art. This is one of the few visual novel series which make me really feel attached to the places and characters in it.  No glitches or technical issues. No/few errors in language or continuity.

Okay this is a honest review of Nekopara Vol.1 and the observations i made playing this Japanese "masterpiece". To start off, i thorougly cringed and laughed playing this game, specially from chapter 4 onwards, now, i definetely don't recommend buying this game (i didn't personally) if you have any of the following things : Ethics, a life, a will to live. Let's start with the key components about Nekofuckingpara [b] OUR MAIN LEAD (harem protagonist) [/b] ご主人[master]-sama as refered to by his slaves or " Kashou " by normal people standards, this dude is an outright pedophiliac and zoophiliac to every extent. Now i'm going to be honest here, this dude being out in society is a danger for everyone, he doesn't only at first bang his SLAVES, yes, his SLAVES; because he is the OWNER of the two humanoid catgirl sex dolls ; he first bangs them for 'HEALTH REASONS', convinced that he's doing the right thing. Then he bangs them for 'love', It sounds like this dude hasn't even had a good nut for the last decade of his entire life. Remember the 'health reasons' pedophiliac sex? We'll get to it right away. [b] FILLER LOLI IMOUTO WHO WANTS TO BANG HER BIG BROTHER [/b] This bitch is outright creepy and fucked, i only played two volumes and i can already tell this person isn't 10 nor human, this is some alien wanting to infiltrate human society by seeing if a brother would actually bang his own 10 year old sister. Since Kashou has got real sex slaves under his complete sentimental and legal control then he might aswell go for it [b] ショコラ and FUCKING バニラ [/b] These are the two sprites that more people have masturbated to than they'd like to admit or everyone else would like to. The first of them is your generic anime character made for comedic relief and the second is a lesbian tsundere- yes you heard that right. LESBIAN TSUNDERE. Or bisexual, i don't even know already. They both love their master and want to embrace his D. [b] POLYGAMY [/b] This game embraces polygamy that's it. Okay, i'll be fair about this. Maybe i'm looking too superficially at Nekopara, i found something interesting about it, by paying attention to detail on all the details of it's worldbuilding. I'll start off by some keypoints:  [u] Genetical Engineering [/u] Okay, let's be honest, it doesn't make any sense realistically speaking but bare with me, i'm going to defend my thesis on how Nekopara portrays a dystopian Japan that hasn't evolved in the slightest in terms of gender equality. First of all, remember we're talking about the CAT part of CATGIRLS ; This means, all 'nekos' in this game aren't Hominids with some feline characteristics, it's Felines with humanoid characteristics, this mean genetical engineering has advanced a lot by the time of this games story. Which doesn't sound like a lot; These felines have developed a limited range of human emotions but they're not quite on the level of free thought ; in fact, with just treating them well they'll like to bang you as soon as they hit puberty, which is about 3 to 4 years in. (Chocola is legal in cat years!!! LMAO!!!) [u] Social critic on Sexism [/u] It is widely known that Japan is an incredibly patriarchal society where women traditionally refer to their husbands as their 'owners' , but Nekopara i think is trying to make a social critic, putting our main lead as just a nice dude but making the two main girls act like his slaves and at the same time entering a romantic relationship- You see where i'm getting here? The owners thought this up all along, it's a message to open our eyes and to stop sexism, and to strive for the complete freedom of all sentient life, something necessary in our galaxy- And this world! Family friendly content....[spoiler]until that scene[/spoiler]  I fucking love cats
This novel isn't for perverts.  If you're thinking about getting this game because it's got catgirls dressed up as maids with boobs, and you think that's sexy, then you *may* buy this game, you may crank up the chest bounciness meter as high as it can go, but if you are capable of sentiment, even in the slightest, then you're better off not reading it all the way through, and just sticking to the first few screens of bouncy catgirl boobs. Why?  Because, if you go any further, you WILL become emotionally attached to this game and its characters, and you won't be able to get off to it anymore. You'd best be sticking to something like Sakura Spirit for that sort of thing.  This game...this novel...it's something else. I was gifted this game by a friend of mine. I honestly didn't expect much at first. I just thought he got it me as a joke, and it was going to end up like one of those other visual novels centred on sex or the like.  I was wrong. And I think it deserves a proper review.  First off, there's the story. I'm not going to spoil anything for you, but it's very well presented. It never once felt sex orientated. For the most part, the narrative was well paced, and the content was powerfully emotional and heart wrenchingly touching at times. I mean POWERFUL. Trust me, there were a few times through the story where I nearly cried. The story doesn't just deal with the theme of love. It deals with other themes such as loyalty, determination, family, selflessness and self-sacrifice. It weaves all of these themes into a beautiful yarn that wraps hard around your heartstrings and doesn't let go. It did seem to sacrifice narrative for..."Liberties" at times, but it's only to be expected. Sometimes, that's what people come to see.  The story is also structured solidly by its attention to detail. They could've just left it at; "There are catgirls in this world, and that's that", but they don't. They provide not only a reason for the catgirls coming to be, but also detail on how politics deal with the issue of an overabundance of catgirls, information on their behaviour, as well as their place in society and how they are treated. They don't really go into detail about any "Catboys", though. What? They also give detail on the catgirls’ mating cycle and their inability to produce young with humans, but they don't mention how they have been able to reproduce. Anyway, that's just a small nitpick.  Next, the writing. The game has its own sense of humour that expresses itself constantly. Not too much, letting up at tender moments, bringing greater contrast to its sentimental narrative. It's witty, and has a varied palette of different kinds of humour, stemming from cute humour, to blunt humour...It even makes the occasional dirty joke. Again, even though there are quite a few deliberate innuendos scattered around the story, it doesn't ever feel like it focuses on sex for appeal or humour, only occasionally applying it for the effect the other audience desires. Notice I said; "Other audience".  I say this because I believe it was created for the purpose of appealing to a demographic that desired emotional relationships, not sexual ones. Sure, it hints at it here and there, but ultimately, it goes for the audience that feels, rather than the one that..."feels".  As for the graphics, it's spectacular. The cutscenes and backgrounds are well drawn and detailed, with bright inviting colours, but that's not the star attraction. What's important here is the animation. Yes, animation. In a visual novel. Oh come on, just how did you think the "chest bounciness" slider was going to be used if the characters didn't MOVE? And oh, do they. The art style may be reminiscent of visual novels of the past, but the characters are far from static. They move even when standing still. You can see every breath they take, every gesture they make, every single movement is smoothly animated and articulated, and...*sigh*, if you really care about that sort of thing, the boobs do move realistically as well, and respond well to the respective slider.  For its attention to detail, story, romance, sparkling wit and of course, the animation, I would recommend it to any catgirl fan who wants genuine romance, not just sex.  Overall - 8.5/10 A beautiful story that flows well, but the whole "cat" gimmick may be too cheesy for some. Be warned.

.//see below for TLDR summary well, to be completely honest theres not much story progression in this story and it's almost purely fanservice. whatever you see from the preview will be literally what you get, there are no choices in the game and you can practically foresee what's going to happen just before buying this game anyways. but still nekogirls, who wouldn't want that right? if you're looking for a visual novel that is more indepth rather than a typical 'semi dating sim' which has a huge storyline then this novel isn't for you.  //TLDR Pros: Fanservice Interactive Music is decent Nekogirls w/ diff personalities Explores character development You get both the girls so why not Uses real facts about cats (like when they feel heated etc) More into eroge than hentai (altho available on their official page)  Cons: No multiple choices There's not much storyline Could get boring after awhile since the story is quite predictable It's quite a light read, so I wouldn't recommend people that are looking for heavy contents  Overall, I still think it's quite decent for the right type of people (like looking for fanservice), and new readers altho it's not really a novel that suits my taste.

How to make Chocola Fudge  INGREDIENTS 2 Cups white sugar 4 Tablespoon butter 1/2 Cup cocoa 1 Teaspoon vanilla extract 1 Cup milk   INSTRUCTIONS - Grease an 8x8 inch square baking pan. Set aside. - Combine sugar, cocoa and milk in a medium saucepan. Stir to blend, then bring to a boil, stirring constantly. Reduce heat and simmer. Do not stir again.  - Place candy thermometer in pan and cook until temperature reaches 238 degrees F(114 degrees C). If you are not using a thermometer, then cook until a drop of this mixture in a cup of cold water forms a soft ball. Feel the ball with your fingers to make sure it is the right consistency. It should flatten when pressed between your fingers.  - Remove from heat. Add butter or margarine and vanilla extract. Beat with a wooden spoon until the fudge loses its sheen. Do not under beat.  - Pour into prepared pan and let cool. Cut into about 60 squares.   Enjoy.

the game is good and all but i thoguht it was an eroge and was very mislead by it and apparently you can only play the real eroge shit if its baught non-steam cause fuck steam...so fuck steam for misleading this shit so hard with the tags and shit
If you own any of the Nekopara games on Steam then odds are someone bought it for you as a joke. If you DO decide to play them, be aware of two things, the first being that it's as standard of a visual novel as you'll ever get. It looks standard, feels standard, the story is standard, everything is standard. Second, there is no H stuff unless you specifically purchase the additional patches. And even then the H stuff is standard too. Feel free to ask me how I know, but it's not worth the time.     That said, I recommend it solely on the basis that people who enjoy visual novels won't have a bad time with this. But if you don't, don't waste your (or your friend's) money.   As for me though, I thought it was a decent romp. The mood is cheery and if nothing else, the game will make you laugh. You can probably guess the plot just by looking at it and you'll have a hearty guffaw when you realize you were correct.    All in all, it's an erotic VN / 10. You know what to expect.

Praise Chocola
I got this Visual Novel for the NOVEL part, not the VISUAL part.  I got this game thinking that, because it is on steam, that the all nude parts would be filtered/removed (It seemed, according to other reviews, that a 'patch' is the only way to put them back.)   I was wrong (there is only one nude bath scene and two COVERED clothesless scenes).   Luckily, there is the 'skip' feature in this visual novel.  I personally think that all nudity is ugly (and I therefore actively avoid it), which is why I got this product on steam. I should have trusted the popular, user-defined tags. Kashou (the main character) left his home to open a cake shop. One day he receives two cardboard boxes in the mail, shipped to him by his younger sister Shigure. The boxes contain two of his adopted catgirls he left at home, Chocola and Vanilla. Kashou wants to send the cat-girls back, but they show that they can be useful as maids in his shop, so he decides to let them stay. The animations are great, the soundtrack as well as the  colourful artwork radiates happiness and the voice acting is pleasant. The story is average and pretty predictable since it's a hentai game. Be careful and play this alone, this game doesn't only have hentai scenes, but it can be cringe sometimes. If you want to be called a weeb by your friends and a failure by your family, play it where everyone can see it. Buying this game on steam will give you a censored version. good.
[i]Ooh... the heresy, he's doing an[/i] actual [i]review for Nekopara![/i] Nekopara is not really a game; it's a visual novel, more specifically, a kinetic visual novel. Think of it as a little story, since all the interactivity you'll have with this will be limited to advancing the story forward and [i]occasionally[/i] pressing 'P' to make all dem sweet catgirls jump (after of course setting the chest bounciness to whatever you want). Nekopara is essentially set in a near-future (or alternative) Japan where genetically engineered catgirls have been normalised. Catgirls are second-class citizens who must prove that they are able the act independently before being allowed to. However, this background tells you squat about what it's actually like, as this story focuses on Kashou Minadzuki (his name is usually romanised as Minaduki) as he founds a new patisserie with two catgirls who mailed themselves to the newly-founded patisserie, Chocola and Vanilla. Initially, Kashou resists their pleas to work with him, but as time goes on, his affection for the two catgirls grows until they become his 'catpanions'. Just to warn you, though, this visual novel does admit that any romantic relationship does turn sexual in the end. Because Steam is a company based in the West, they apparently ban all explictly sexual scenes from all their games (while allowing some positively gruesome violence; what the hell is going on!?) even though there exist methods to bar the little kids from experiencing them. So the Steam version has been censored from the original 18+ version, which, funnily enough, can be re-integrated with the Steam version. And, from what I've heard, it's pretty intense. Nekopara is essentially a feel-good story. Whether that feel-good comes from the heartwarming love story that unfolds through ups and downs, or from having a good ol' jerk off is up to you. A visual novel like this, though, is more than just a 'picture book for adults', since you've got music, voice acting, and beatiful animation which is probably the best you can get without using 3D animation. If you're a cultural elitist who dictates that 'all good media is deep and meaningful, and that which is not is utter trash' then boy are you gonna hate this. But if you've grown sick of how Western media has gotten so 'gritty' and 'dramatic' then this is a welcome breath of fresh air. I say I recommend this visual novel, but I only recommend it for fellow otakus. Not for normies, people who can't adequately separate reality and fantasy enough to realise that what happens here should not be concerning, right-wing Christian fundamentalists, fourth-wave feminists (just thought I'd mention the artist is female) and [i]definitely[/i] none of the 'anti-weebs'. [b]Have a fun time with your six catgirls![/b]

The whole review in three sentences: BUY IT NOW!!! IMMEDIATELY!!! ALL OF 'EM!!!  OK, here it goes. Usuallt in my reviews I try to point out pros and cons of the reviewed game but this is not the case here. The game is simply flawless. Seriously,  The plot is as simple as it can possibly be, but the reason everyone (or at least 99% of people) is not the plot. It the ambience of the game. You look at the catgirls, you listen to the music, you read the dialogues and after 3 or 4 hours you ask yourself: "Why I cannot get enough of this? Why do I want to play more?".  Everything here is adorable. Every character is drawn perfectly, the music is as suitable as it gets and the dialogues are stupid. Yes, the most stupid dialogues in the history of VNs, but it makes the game itself. If not for them "Nekopara" games wouldn't have even the half of its charm and I mean it. Anime cliches are here and there but still I cannot imagine where they would suit more than here.  Characters + dialogues = 90% of "Nekopara". It is well known that if you don't have good characters in an anime-game it is trash. Well, the cutest catgirls you can find are here. In addition to cuteness they pretty charismatic so you will love them after first couple of minutes that you've seen them.  Lots of details like a cat on the tie that Azuki wears and straight pupils of the catgirls are the rest 10% percent of "Nekopara"'s secret. One can find a lot if interesting stuff if he just stops the game and look around.  All in all the is awesome, and it hits the highest possible mark, I would strongly recommend to play it to everyone who read it.

I like this game a lot but was initially going to leave a review explaining why I wouldn't recommend it. In the midst of writing it though I came to the conclusion that doing so wouldn't be very fair and decided to talk about the two elephant girls in the room instead.  Firstly, it has absolutely no gameplay whatsoever. You can literally load it up, press autoplay, sit back and let the entire game play out before you without having to interact with it again. I'm no connoisseur of visual novels but I've played a few of them and this was a first for me. I went into it expecting to make the usual choices (which cat girl to be with, currying favour, dates etc.) and want potential buyers to aware that no such interactivity exists.  Secondly, the game is heavily censored on Steam, a platform that allows you to experience the likes of Hatred in their purest form. Patches can be acquired to remove said censorship but I was unable to get any of them to work with the Steam version no matter what methods I followed. Initially I was begrudgingly okay playing the censored version but a few points in the game made me feel like I was missing out on a lot of content - and I was. After a trip to the high seas, I realized that the hentai elements make up a sizeable chunk of the game. This became a double edged sword for me as I ended up feeling like the primary h-scene was extremely excessive and out of place with the tone and theme the game was setting. Your mileage is naturally going to vary here.  On sale, with the above in mind, if you know this is the type of thing you're into you will have a fun time.
Well used money, i have no regrets.  Cute game.

Don't let the categorizations and other reviews fool you. This game is, at heart, a horror game. When you look at all the underlying moral and ethical issues surrounding this universe, your soul will die a little. Or a lot. 10/10 would again drive people to drink by streaming this. (Note: Twitch allows the Steam version but not the uncensored version. For obvious reasons.)  Quick edit: Better yet, the main character will at times gain some understanding that this universe is screwed up and note it--the game itself mocks the players/readers for enjoying it! Glorious. And its defenders are diehard and get all butthurt when you point this stuff out, which is also really entertaining, which helps my soul after playing/reading it.
What started out as a R-rated game has turned into the sweetest thing since Diabetics blood.   It's a visual novel about catgirl slaves that love their owner, with as much cuteness as the cakes they sell in their cafe "La Soleil".  It's playful and has an 18+ patch if you are into that sort of thing.  Apparently a lot of people are [or they just love these catgirls] , as the game got 2 sequels, volume 2 and 3, a prequel, volume 0 and a 60 minute OVA broken up into 3 episodes, with further volumes and projects tied to the franchise on the way soon, according to the developers.  All are on steam.  tl;dr its the reason Appear Offline exists.

[i]The year is 2018. Random guy on the internet SILVER FOX creates a strawpoll to decide which visual novel to play next, and because his friends hate him, they all vote for the masterpiece that is NEKOPARA.[/i]  For years I have wondered if this series is actually any good and after playing it, I gotta say, not really a huge fan. I'll start off with the things I like about it because it wasn't all awful - the presentation overall is pretty nice, all of the characters have animations and I think a lot of effort went into it. They even have mouth movement! The CGs looks good too and I thought the music was pretty catchy.  The story is about a guy named Kashou moving out of his house to start up a bakery/sweets shop/whatever so he can start a new life without telling his family. However, 2 boxes arrive and contain 2 catgirls - Chocola and Vanilla. Shenanigans happen. I found the best parts of this game are when they do cat-like things like getting drunk from catnip.  Outside of that there isn't much to say. The story was predictable, the game is clearly an eroge that has been censored since they show you what happens before and after the sex scenes instead of writing them out and as a comedy it isn't really that funny. At least in my opinion. If you're interested in this game then you've probably played it already, and if you liked it then that's fine, but I don't really get it. If the sequels are the same as this, which I heard they are, then I don't think i'll be playing them.
