Rating: 6/10 ("Decent")  Recommended for: People who enjoy VNs, people who like slice of life, people who like cute things. I would not recommend this to a first time VN reader.  Nekopara Volume 1 (presumably) serves as an introduction to the series Nekopara, an episodic visual novel that centres around the main character, Kashou, and his bakery. He is helped by his multitude of catgirls, basically girls with cat ears, tails, and cat-tendencies. In-universe, they're generally treated as sub-human and as pets. They appear to have regular cat lifespans in (mostly) human bodies.  The premise is very obviously an excuse for a relaxing slice of life VN, and that is what Nekopara is. There are no choices to make and no branching paths to follow; it is all very linear. All you need to enjoy it is to click through it. It took me just under 5 hours to read the whole visual novel, which is decent, but a little short for its cost in my opinion. Of course, I read volume 1 without the H scenes, so perhaps those add a sizable chunk to reading time.   Nekopara boasts impressive production values; the character sprites are extremely detailed, and are also animated to go along with character movements and speech. Clothing is beautiful and full of different nuances. Backgrounds are very good and match the quality of the character sprites. The best thing about the game, however, is its CGs: they are colourful, vibrant, and exceptional. Without a doubt, most of Nekopara's value is in its artwork and the cuteness of the characters.  Speaking of the characters, the VN introduces Kashou, Shigure (his sister), and the many catgirls: Vanilla, Chocola, Azuki, Maple, Cinnamon, and Coconuts. This volume mainly focuses on Kashou's relationship with Vanilla and Chocola. Judging by the descriptions of the rest of the volumes, they will likely cycle to focus on the catgirls that did not receive as much attention during volume 1. That being said, all the characters are quite distinguishable, and all have different personalities.  The soundtrack was not particularly memorable, but it served its purpose.  In general, Nekopara Volume 1 was a cute slice of life VN to pass the time and relax. I might pick up the rest of the series when it is on sale.

It only took over eight years to get these two perfect catgirls of the Minazuki family into a visual novel to really bring them to life, and that's excactly what NEKOWORKs' gals do with this game's animated sprites and voice acting. Though it's relatively short for a visual novel, and kinetic to boot I feel the quality of these sweet catgirls makes up for it. Depending on how long you've been a fan of Sayori's art this is a welcomed event regardless.   Just a heartfelt little romp where Chocola and Vanilla set out to help their master run his Cafe/Bakery whether he wants it or not! With some eroge thrown in there too if you get the patch.

So I beat this game or more like Visual Novel. Usually, I dont see games on a high critical level, but this was a game I had some on. It was highly favoured and since I had some money left for the holiday sale, I said "why not?" and bought it. Many people told me "buy it, it's good, you won't regret it!" If I can share these people's opinion...we'll see.  TL;DR: 5/10. Definetly needs to be better to be actually worth 10€  The game looks very good, the graphics are (what I call them) "modern-anime-style" and with that absolutly good. It's fun reading the dialogues and it felt kind of good reading the whole thing. But this is where probelms start: The story is (imo) way too narrow, it's exactly how I expected the story to go. This happens, they do this as rection. I give you some spoiler-examples *SPOILERS AHEAD* [spoiler]The master has fun with this cat girls, he thinks, since it's a common thing to have catpanions,  loving them is ok. He gets ill, the girls help him by going out, the obligatory drama "we forgot our bells at home! we swear we belong to somebody!"[/spoiler] *SPOILER END* I tried to keep my expectations as low as possible since this is my first visual novel. But by doing exactly what I think's gonna happen...at least you dont make me completly satisfied. I do not want to say the story is bad at all! For what the story is, it's alright and enjoyable. A little thing that I didnt like that much, but isnt a big game breaker at all: (again, what I thought) You have all those adorable, beautiful catgirls and yet you get to experience what happens with 2 of them? This is where I gotta ask: Will we know more about the others in other Nekoparas? If no, then this is absolutly not ok imo. I'd really like to know more about Coconut or Cinnamon (tits yuheeeeeeee) If yes...well, the typical way to provide the user his information: We make a whole new game/story for some money. I dont want to say that is a bad thing, but I remember ye olden days where we got our stuff for free or we got games where we had so many stories in one game that we could play it for a massive amount of hours and we still didnt know anything. (yet again, I dont want to say the story is bad) But for focusing on 2 characters, the story is quite good.  Another thing I have to mention: The H-patch. Yes, there is one. you get hentaiscenes as you further progress through the game IF YOU HAVE THE H-PATCH DOWNLOADED UND INSTALLED. Google "nekopara vol 1 h-patch" and read the instructions carefully. that's it. Another thing to mention: If you have the H-Patch installed, you should be able to see if the H.Patch works if Chocola and Vanilla feel hot and it pretty much leads in an obvious way to the H-scenes What can I say about the scenes? They are well made, I actually didnt expect moving scenes tbh! But the sounds were...well, you can hear that the game isn't focusing on the H-scenes. But as a sweet, little addition, I enjoyed them (no, I did not (yet) masturbate to them).  Overall, I give the game a 5/10. But imo, I wouldn't pay 10€ for it. Maybe 7, let's say 5. But 10€ is way too much. Maybe I just had too high expectations, who knows.  Play the game for yourself and get your own opinion! In the end, it's just me who thinks this way :)

An amazing visual novel. It takes 2nd place in my heart after ChuSingura. The artstyle is really cute. The choices of theme songs is excellent. The story is interesting and well written. It has ups and downs so it isn't a simple everything-is-perfect-and-all kind of story. This episode centers around the youngest members of the Minaduki family Chocola and Vanila who happen to be twins. Chocola is a really energetic and cute catgirl whose honesty and innocance is just dangerously moe and makes your heart melt. She always acts childish but once becoming Kashou's catpanion she sometimes become really lewd. Vanila seems lazy but is actually hard-working and while she may not be too honest about her feelings it only makes her more lovable. She acts really mature and she loves joking around. She especially loves pointing out what a "pervy pastry puffer" Kashou is. Taking everything into consideration i can't really say anything negative about all this. Definetly worth a 10/10.
If you love cats -> play this game. If you hate cats -> play this game to love cats.

[b]NEKOPARA Vol.1[/b] is a light visual novel (VN) about two "catgirls" working in their owner's new cafe. The game defines earlier on "catgirls" as the "genetically modified human-feline hybrids" which are kept as pets. They are also required to wear an IAP (Independent Action Permit) item fitted with a GPS tracker, such as a bell, if they want to go outdoors without their owners (after passing "The Test").   + High quality art style with a lot of attention to detail + Entertaining voice overs (Japanese language) + Some catchy songs + Steam achievements and trade cards  - Very simple, straightforward and unintelligent plot for a VN - The sub par plot (in comparison to the visuals) offers no alternative paths choices, thus no replayability - Unless you are a "catgirl" fan, the storyline was bordering on uncomfortable - Some small glitches, i.e. black screen, no video for end credits etc - No achievements accomplishment; they dutifully drop after each chapter (+config change options)  Note: The review is for the standard steam version of NEKOPARA Vol.1, which even though it has a couple suggestive depictions, there is no adult material within (requires the purchase of external DLC to activate the explicit scenes).  ----- TL;DR: [b]NEKOPARA Vol.1[/b] strictly as a visual novel, suffers from a short, unintelligent and shallow plot but in contrast the high quality visuals, art and catchy songs perhaps will justify a purchase, especially at a reduced sales price.
NEKOPARA is a sorta okay game if you can call it that. It's not bad but I feel it should be called an animated comic. Nothing about it is bad but I was under the impression before I bought it there would be choices and routes for each of the cat girls. So I can't really judge it by a mistake on my part but I will say there is more interaction in the options menu than the actual gameplay itself. It took me about 4-5 hours of cumulitve play of a few sittings to complete it. I got bored listening to cat girls squeel and pressing spacebar after about an hour each time. If you like Kawaii/Moe type Anime this should be right up your alley, If not I would pass on this one.   Pros: - Kawaii - Well written - Art is superb.  Cons: - The most linear game I've ever played.

I love this visual novel. I love the girls. I love the art style. I'm a huge forever fan of this series <3
Okay, so, uh... yeah.  I bought this game sort of on a whim, and my initial thought process was "I've heard this was basically hentai so, being the type of person who is entertained by witnessing some depraved shit, I'm gonna get all 4 volumes and see what the deal is."  Naturally I discovered that's not all there was to it. I was missing something. Yes, indeed:  THE 18+ DLC.  I bought it after a great deal of mental preparation and hesitation. I regret nothing.  I'll start by giving a simple pro/con list for the steam version of the game, the "All-Ages" version.  PROS: -Breathtaking art style, fluent animations and excellent attention to detail. Easily one of the most beautifully crafted VNs I've seen or played. Of course, I'm also just a sucker for anime. Sue me. -The voiceovers, while entirely in Japanese, are excellent. Delivery is great, display of emotion is great, and the actresses fit their characters well, with clear differences in tone, pitch and delivery. -The story, while basically just a slice-of-life with some deeper elements thrown in, grips you well enough that you want to keep going (pun intended, you'll know why later.) -Characters are all interesting, some more than others, but you won't dislike a single one. Even Shigure, who has a rather uncomfortable big brother complex going on. -The soundtrack is upbeat when it needs to be, solemn when it doesn't. There's a pleasant mix of piano tracks and poppy, electronic tracks, along with some more traditional anime-like tracks with a jazzy vibe.  CONS: -The dialogue and general script, as is unfortunately the case with almost all JP > EN translations, fails to deliver a truly realistic representation of how one would speak in English. Things like "Ahh..." or "That's not...!" Some people might not consider this a con, especially since the characters all speak, meaning the text should be a true translation. More of a personal quirk I suppose. -Minor typos here and there. Easy to miss, honestly. -The story, due to the nature of it, lacks tragedy. Fortunately, everything else is delivered well enough that this may only be a setback for some. Still figured I'd mention it.   NOW THEN... Allow me to move on to the FULL version of the game, which I have. This pro/con list is strictly going to cover what the 18+ dlc (re)introduces. I won't be graphic in order to keep my review readable, but I will be detailed enough to get the point across  PROS: -Since the H-scenes were done by the same artist, the comment I made about the art style applies here as well. -The scenes are exaggerated, but not to the point of just not making any sense. If you're not getting what I'm saying, let's just say instead of the girls looking like they just hopped out of the ocean, they look like they maybe fell in a puddle or... something. -THEY ARE ANIMATED -The entire scene is voiced (Minus Kashou of course). This can be a con if you're the type that can't handle the sound of a voice actress making rather realistic sexual sounds. -Again, not much of a hentai guy, but the scenes are really well done for what they are. Not much else to say really... at the end of the day, you're paying $30 for hentai.  CONS: -Again, with the translations, shit doesn't always make sense. Without being specific, sometimes word usage in certain "situations" is off-putting. Even thought the VAs may REALLY be saying these things, it's still a little uncomfortable to read. Again, I'm not usually a hentai kind of dude, so it could just be me. -Frequency is... well, frequent. Vol. 1 alone, after the initial 3-4 hours of introductory story, probably has a scene every 45 minutes of play time. There are 3 scenes. The 3rd lasts well over an hour. I only list this as a con because it sort of makes you feel like the game goes from a story-driven experience with some porn thrown in for taste, to a straight up H-VN with a little bit of story mixed in. -There is almost ALWAYS some kind of wet/sticky sound effect going on in the background. Sometimes it's fine, but for the most part it's just gross. I recommend either turning down the sound effects or turning them off entirely unless you enjoy the sound of macaroni that's been sitting for a while being spooned around.  With all of that being said, the game is super adorable. ESPECIALLY Chocola and Vanilla... even if they end up being defiled halfway through the game. Feelsbadman.  If you've gotten this far, congrats, you know what to expect. If you're looking for a TL;DR, here it is:  11/10 Catgirls are cute, there's hentai if you blow (giggity) the extra $30, the game is pretty, buy it now no regrats.
fun cute game that is not for the weak of heart.  i love this series and recommend it to those who feel that they would like this type of weeb or otaku type stuff

NEKOPARA is a VN based on Pantheon becoming what he wanted, except his personal space was invited by his family's Nekos*. Instead of filing a restraining order, he keeps them with him.  The VN novel itself is mediocre at best, with a few key elements. First, it's one of the few VN's to be animated, and not some pictures wired up (Though at parts, there are pictures, though this is obvious). Another key element is that the VNs are Voice-Acted (VA), thus bringing in MORE spirit.  One of the main attractions for me, however, was that the game contains hentai. To get the uncensored version you either: -A: Pay for the uncensored version online, and apply a patch to the Steam version -B: Pirate said patch -or C: Buy the uncensored version online, then set it to be a Steam game.  The main problem is that the game lures you with hentai, should you be a fan of hentai, and then makes you pay an extra 10 dollars, which just screams BS.  One of the problems I've had that's very common with the game is ''Invalid character AE''. If you don't want to deal with said problem, install the VN on C: instead of D:.  Verdict: A VN that is definitely worth checking, but pay online or pirate the patch for the hentai.  Final Verdict: 7/10 for the base VN, 8/10 for the hentai parts. The hentai parts did not feel empty, yay.

10/10, would be emotionally coerced into sleeping with nine-months-old anthropomorphic house pets again...? :s  Slightly more seriously speaking, I've probably approached this game from an unusual angle, as I wasn't looking for porn and didn't download the 18+ patch, but I knew how much praise the whole series gathered over the years and wanted to check it out for myself. What I found was:  + Absolutely beautiful visuals, with sprites, CGs, Backgrounds... Everything being georgeous. + Awesome scripting with animated sprites done maybe better than anywhere else, creating a lively experience you wouldn't expect from a VN. + Tons of cuteness and adorableness. + Good music.  But also:  - Extremely creepy owner/pet romance that made me uncomfortable even without seeing the H-scenes. - Creepy brocon subplot with the protagonist's little sister (who would be otherwise an adorable character). - Paper-thin story and absurd setting that doesn’t really try making sense. - Writing generally not on par with the visual quality.  [b]As a kinetic novel, it was definitely well-produced and fun to read, but not really exceptional in anything but the graphics. If I looked on it as porn, I think the power dynamic and characteristics of the catgirls (especially Chocola) really makes it quite horrible. If you don't get discouraged by this description though, you should have a blast with this and all the other chapters of the series. I don't judge. The characters in Nekopara are way too cute. Each have their own unique personalities, which are easy to get attached to. From an artistic standpoint, this game is also fantastic. While there aren't necessarily any branching storylines or choices, I never really considered this a negative aspect of the game, just a wanted addition. I'd definitely recommend you pick up Vol.0 to get a feel for the game and see if it's something you'd enjoy. Also the 18+ patch for Vol.1-Vol.3 adds quite a bit to the overall game - and lets be honest, that's what we're intrested in. However, you have to purchase these from the developer's site "Denpasoft" and they're quite expensive.

NekoPara Volume 1 takes place from the perspective of a man named Kashou Minaduki, whom is part of a long line of Japanese confection makers. His sister has also been raising quite a few catgirls, some of whom have become attached to him over recent months and years. Seeking to forge his own path in the industry, Kashou decides to leave home and open his own patisserie by the name of “La Soleil” – completely in secret to avoid the attention of his family. Originally it was his plan to run this cafe by himself, without the assistance of either his family or any catgirls he left behind. But this all changes when he finds two unopened boxes sitting in the shop with some perplexing notices on them. The noises from the box show that two of the catgirls his sister was raising: the enthusiastic Chocola and more docile Vanilla, have decided to stay by his side and help run the shop. Although willing to send them back home at first, events that follow see him deciding to keep the two on board – as they begin their life of running La Soleil together.  + r18 patch + cute nekos + boobs bounciness (press "P" to see the magic)

Even though this game has single handedly ruined my life, at least I have virtual catgirls.  10/10

Played with the patched version -- Wonderful game. Enjoyed every bit of it =)
Got to admit, I think the sexual content actively interferes with the novel. Steam's censored version is the version I played and thankfully skips past the actual adult scenes and is one of the only instances where I feel like it would have been an inferior experience, but even in Steam's version the implications of what happened doesn't feel quite right.  Fortunately, that's about the only notable issue for me. It's otherwise an enjoyable experience in seeing the relationship develop between Kashou and his unexpected catgirls Chocola and Vanilla, especially as the catgirls struggle to fully understand the way humanity works. Seeing the three earnestly try to pursue what they believe to be the best for them all while trying to understand the bonds they have was very nice.  Nekopara is not without its humour and the novel delivers well on this too. A lot of it ends up tying into the catgirl tendencies to slip into cat-like behaviour, and while I wouldn't say every joke worked it definitely hit the mark more plenty to make it worthwhile.  It was also great to see the E-mote system in use for the visuals. The last time I'd seen this was Tokyo School Life, and the implementation here is even better as they're able to give some illusion of talking, walking about or leaning to the side as a few examples. While it's not the norm for visual novels the impact is massive and I do wish it would become more commonplace.  There are no choices to make in the novel though, with a single linear storyline to the end.

携帯の使い方について考え ます。青少年の携帯の使用による危険や犯罪、使いすぎによる依存症の問題について多 くの人に知ってもらい、考えてもらうために新聞と学校のニュースレターに特集の記事 を書きます。この話題についての情報量は多いので、記事を書くことにしました。記事 は様々な読者、特に携帯を利用している生徒や、その親にも一度にメッセージを伝える ことが出来ます。三つのテキスト(ニュースコラム、ブログ、記事)を読んで、そこに書 いてあるスマホ依存症という問題は、現在大きな問題であるという事を知りました。こ の記事の中で、まず携帯の役に立つ点と所有者が急増している点について紹介します。 携帯使用について親の...

[h1]Well, NEKOPARA vol.1[/h1] When first time I ran NEKOPARA, my mind was almost at my cuteness and kawaiiness limits :3 Those Nekos are amazing. Never seen such adorable and vivid kawaii characters before. I love all of them. They are completely adorable.  [h1]Characters[/h1] [olist] [*][url=https://youtu.be/yH4R0MwExvo][b]Azuki[/b][/url]. Aaah, my favorite one. She has me to crush on her with that frolic character and sarcastic enjoyable quips, always on a perky mischievous mood, more likely [i]tsundere[/i] character. Don't get me wrong and pls stop calling the cops - she's the eldest Minaduki neko! Also her responsibility and tender insides just makes me thrill. Guess I like her bluntness + shyness on the other side pretty much. She's a [i]Munchkin[/i] neko.  [*][url=https://youtu.be/ZmIqFqnMj60][b]Vanilla[/b][/url]. Well, she's also one of my favorites. With that corteous behaivor, cold and mysterious look in her eyes, sharp piercing phrases, calm and reserved barely recognizable emotions, rare soft and genuine tenderness - all that kindly teasing stuff makes [b]Vanilla[/b] truly catching one. Oh [b]Vanilla[/b]'s really makes my mind melt. She's more [i]kuudere[/i] than [i]dandere[/i] character to me.  [*][url=https://youtu.be/MWDFRIL7LoQ][b]Chocola[/b][/url]. [spoiler]Eheh, that's where the verge of crime becomes barely visible[/spoiler]. I like Chocola, her energetic mood always cheers me up, she's a really adorable one. A happy-go-lucky neko, I'm in love with her sincerity. Her innocent and genuine elated character, truly optimistic, sparkling eyes, exciting cute voice - all of it makes Chocola really really great. Truly, genki + moe char. [*][url=https://youtu.be/isJEI88_ZgI][b]Coconut[/b][/url]. Oh my, she's the best. She's quite different from the other nekos. Tall, athletic, smart, doing some martial arts. Even she's young, you can suppose like she's the elder one. Confident and cool, she's really modest and kindhearted from the inside. As she says about herself: [i]"...I think I'd rather be a cute catgirl than a cool one"[/i]. Also she's little bit shy, has some issues with low self-esteem and jelaous to other catgirls for their appearances. But for me, she's more than just good. She's gorgeous. Btw I really enjoy huge cute&clumsy shy girls too. She's a [i]Maine Coon[/i] neko [*][url=https://youtu.be/qVmrIZTE06U][b]Maple[/b][/url], kind, proud and also vigorous and extrovertous neko. She's quite a young lady. Sophisticated in some way. Well, trying to show that all the time - how be perfect and versatile. She's an [i]American Curl[/i] neko. [*][url=https://youtu.be/ccIkbzFxwjc][b]Cinnamon[/b][/url], kinda perverted Neko, maybe too much. Cinnamon makes me feel really awkward sometimes with her lewd and lecherous polysemantic phrases, but she's rather nice in her own special way. She's tender, even voluptuous character. [spoiler]Never liked overweighted melons though :D[/spoiler] So, I guess it's just a common moe character. She's a [i]Scottish Fold[/i] neko. [/olist]  [b]Kashou[/b]. Don't think that I might be able to say much about him, but, well, he's ambitious,  responsible, polite and most likely collective character, reasonable and collective in order to be compared to the player. Typical [i]"nice guy"[/i], he's the one the catgirls surely can rely on. [spoiler]Also, sometimes he's quite dumbass[/spoiler] To be honest, i like him anyway. I guess I should mention one more character, [url=https://youtu.be/WgJM99I_IAw][b]Shigure[/b][/url], [b]Kashou[/b]'s younger sister. To tell you the truth, she's not the person who can actually make you feel something more than common character interest. Not really catching. I guess the very plot needs her in order to be more logical and sense-making, to make whole story cohergent. Because of highly developed anime voicing industry in Japan, all those characters are greatly sparkling and outstanding, I am really enjoying their different personalities. [spoiler]Aaand...in R-18 cutscenes the voice is actually doing about half of the work, ya know ;)[/spoiler]  [h1]Plot[/h1] Well you all should know the plot, it's simple and consistent, just th way it should be in such game. Well, I wish I could have had more influence to the game process like choices or smth, but whatever.  [quote=Wiki]Kashou Minaduki is an aspiring chef who moves away from home to open his own confection shop. While he is unpacking in his new shop, he discovers that two of his family's Nekos, Chocola and Vanilla, came along with him by hiding in cardboard boxes. After the two Nekos convince Kashou to let them stay and live with him, the three of them work together to run his shop, "La Soleil". Throughout the story, Kashou is frequently visited by his younger sister Shigure, as well as the other Nekos owned by his family.[/quote]  [h1]P.S.[/h1] [b][url=https://youtu.be/TQudvxDriz4?t=8m03s][quote=Noble, 2014]You know what? Economists assume all humans act rationally. That is to say they act in terms of marginal benefits and marginal costs, and behave in their own self interest. Now, as an economist, do I think a rationally acting human would purchase this good? [b] NOTE: This review is made for the uncensored version, without uncensoring no H-scenes can actually be seen afaik.)[/b] [strike] [url=steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=370848130] Instructions for uncensoring here [/url] [/strike] My experience with Nekopara Vol1 was amazing! i really loved the theme and artwork. This visual novel is not really a game in any sense of the word, it has zero interactivity except for *ahem* a certain button that makes a certain thing bounce by which i mean [spoiler] cats [/spoiler] and thus does not have multiple endings or branching, which most visual novels do have. You have to be [strike] a fitlhy weeb [/strike] a fan of Manga style art or anime to get the best out of this game, if you dont then you may or may not get the point of this "game" [b] Pros: [/b] - Awesome artwork - Good voice acting - A sweet love story - Well-written - Eroge to the max (lot of h-scenes, probably uncensored only) [b] In-betweens: [/b] - Japanese voice acting ( which i loved) - Settings are pretty basic (not a con, since this is very normal and understandable for visual novels) - No interaction - Very easy to get 100% achievements on - Absolute singleplayer - you will want to play this when you really are all alone. - requires tissues, socks or towels to play, will crash-to-desktop without them [b] Cons: [/b] - On the short side (my play time being calmly reading and getting trough the whole story) - side-characters have little to no development (but, it seems the developers are going the route of making new volumes focusing on the other side characters, with Vol. 2 having 2 of the side characters in the spot light as what i assume are main characters) -  [strike] not actually a con [/strike] [spoiler] DEAR GOD I JUST FAPPED TO 2 FUCKING CATS, SEND HELP  [/spoiler]  All in all a good game for you [strike] to play with your daughter to show her why her cat had kittens [/strike] to play with when you want to play with yourself. NEKOPARA Vol.1 looks like it fits 100% into an outsider’s view of visual novels; a dull, fandom-focused story with pretty girls who do nothing but dote on you. Yes, these catgirls are pretty devoted, but there’s more going on than a simple harem storyline. One can’t help but be intrigued by Kashou’s devotion to baking, understanding both catgirls, and wanting to see everything turn out well. With that said, some may be put off by the sexual storyline aspect which suddenly shows up. Others might be mad knowing they’ve missed out on some scenes due to Steam’s restrictions on adult content. Still, NEKOPARA is a light and fluffy visual novel that fans of catgirls will enjoy their time with.
August 26th 1964, The Xin Wu dynasty.  In ancient India a great German windmill engineer came to offer his help in exchange for chocolate chip biscuit cookies, The ones wich where loved by many British farmers far in the south west.   As it stands the Federal line of Russian Democratic Countries has combined its forces to sexual harras the people of Turkey, Ofcourse the Communist state of global economic replublicans wasn't all too happy about this, so they sended out the People's Army of United China to fight these space monkeys wich led to an all out war of diplomatic aggresion against Africa, And thus nuclear winter begun.  You are given full control over Alkeb Mussin he's an european communist party advisor of the great Mexican wall production industry, As the player you're tasked with some pretty lame stuff "To make this city of united space rats run like crisps of baked cow oil." it's like a dream come true. This particular story features some amazing moments such as the one time you flew a Tu-144 into United Austrian Space Territory and Generic Black Male had to come and save you... Well that's about it, I guess.  More filler, Potato baking competition of united global potato states funded by the African Aqua Powerd Car Fuel ..eh Company yes that's it. Nekopra is a well told dystopian story about a race of genetically engineered slaves, cleverly told from the point of view of the slave owners. With near human intelligence and an apparent need for sex to stay healthy, the "catgirls" are used for sex, companionship and free/cheap labor. Is their affection towards the protagonist and his family authentic or simply an act to aviod the greater horror of being an un-owned catgirl; hunted by the authorities and forced to live as fugitives?

As far as I have noticed, this is the best visual novel out there. High quality drawings, decently animated, and enjoyable story with solid writing, nice music, etc. This is a great first visual novel if you've never played one before, it's leaps and bounds beyond others. I would recommend installing an R18+ patch for the full experience though. This steam version has a lot of censorship that takes away from what you're likely expecting.

ERASE ALL WEEBS
So having completed Volume 1, I have to say that this game was surprisingly entertaining.  I picked it up in a bundle deal and I just thought I'd give it a spin to see what it's like.  The character art is certainly NEKOPARA's strong point, the character desings are well done and having them have an animated aspect really put it a cut above the visual novels out there with static graphics.  Chocola and Vanilla are able to emote and thanks to the stellar art it really helps drive home the emotions of the script.  And as someone who worked in the culinary industry I could relate to the struggle the MC was dealing with; which is always a plus.  The only downside is that this game is that you're locked in to one route, so you better enjoy the ride. I suspect that since there are other volumes of the game out there, they might focus more on the other characters introduced in Volume 1.  Though there is one character that I hope they don't, just to avoid dealing with certain taboos.  This game is at it's best when it's light hearted and silly.  So in conclusion; give NEKOPARA a shot.  The art, combined with the animation and voice acting make for a potent combo.

A truly distopian world wrapped in a kusoge shell.  [spoiler] Some time in the recent past, scientists have created a successful human-cat hybrid creature, all of which are female.  Their growth patterns are bizarre, combining "cat years" and human physiological growth to develop an adult at a mere one to two years of life.  As a side effect of the hybridization, they are born infertile.  As the hybrids grow in popularity, Japan's legal system develops a crude set of regulations to keep the new pseudospecies in check.  Catgirls, as they are informally regarded, must have legal documentation on hand at all times, or they may be arrested and detained.  They must be owned by a documented citizen, and may only be employed by express concent of their owner. [/spoiler]  All of this is explicitly detailed in the roughly two to three hours of text composing NekoPara Vol. 1.  There are no choices to be made, little player interaction, and basically no replay value. It's a technologically sound, high quality Visual Novel, with perhaps the strangest, most thought-out plot for getting cat ears on french maids even written.  Regardless of whether you download the 18+ patch for explicit nudity, and this truly is a plot spoiler, [spoiler] you unambiguously mate with both cats. [/spoiler]  It's not for me.  But it delivers moderately on every promise it makes.

Hentai
At 4 and a half hours worth of content, Nekopara Vol 1 doesn't have a ton to offer. The plot is a slice of life about opening a bakery and living with nekos that will either work for you because you wanna bone one of the characters or not work because it is, penultimately, boring. The writing isn't particularly good but the voice work is cute, the translation is one of the better VN productions I've seen in a while as well. The art is fantastic, I've been a fan of Sayori for a number of years so you won't be let down. Pretty much if you buy this, you know what you're buying it for and will enjoy the cuteness of it and the shallow self-insert fantasy. But if you're looking for a decent plot to complement your "plot" I'd check elsewhere.   But overall, it's a fun VN. I'd purchase it on sale though, the price tag is a little steep for the minimal content you get.
It was a gift I swear.
Where can I start? This game follows a Male Protagonist, Kashou, as he tries to stand on his two feet in society by starting his own cafe. Kashou discovers that two of his family's cats, Chocola and Vanilla, has followed him and allows them to stay by helping out with the new store.  Nekopara is slightly different compared to VNs of the past where sprites are not used. Instead the game relys on "E-mote" system where characters are brought to life.   This game has a very light hearted tone and vague storyline. Everything is done over the top like most VNs in Japan. There really isn't anything majorly wrong with the game per say, but I could imagine people not enjoying cat servicing.  I really enjoyed playing this w/o the 18+ DLC as it keeps it very light hearted. I do wish however, rather than skipping the 18+ scenes and placing the story just after the deed it done, the story should be skipped directly to the next chapter.  For the price of the game, it's definitely worth buying even without the 18+ DLC.

444 NEKO take my soul
I expected this to be a mindless, plotless bit of cute fluff and lewdness that I could tab over to during downtime in other games.  Instead, I plumbed the depths of human depravity in an unintentional horror story about an eerie world in which people are chattel, either abandoned to die hopeless and alone or treated as a mix of animal and idiot child unless their owners feel like fucking them. The developers of Nekopara needed to tackle the question of how their faceless, voiceless player self-insert vehicle would come to live in a cramped apartment with a bevy of amorous catgirls.   They had many options. They chose, apparently totally blind to the implications, the option in which humanity uplifts another terrestrial species to human levels of intelligence, but then elects to keep them as pets/slaves/sex toys, maintaining a system of psychological degradation and police-enforced dependence in order to keep them docile and reliant on their masters.  And nobody comments on this intensely unethical behavior--in fact, it is so normal that people publically praise individuals who chose to maintain sexual relations with sophonts who are a) their property, b) in an extremely submissive relationship (in terms of power dynamics), c) viewed as nonhuman animals or children by most of the population.  That's purely the worldbuilding. I could comment on the fetishization of mating seasons or the usual pseudo-incestuous relationships, but frankly none of that could top the entirely unintentional creepiness of the worldbuilding which makes the plot possible.  Of course this probably came about because they used 90% of the budget animating sex scenes and boob jiggle, leaving their writers to subsist on the packaging from the instant noodles the rest of the team ate. Long-term dehydration and malnourishment probably doesn't help the creative process.  "9/10, needs more mosaic censoring." -IGN

[h1]OVERVIEW[/h1] Nekopara Volume 1 is the second in the Nekopara series of anime visual novels from developer NEKO WORKs, published by Sekai Project. It was actually the first game released, but now has a fan-made prequel: Volume 0.  Nekopara Volume 1 introduces Kashou, a young man who has vacated the family home and moved into an apartment above his new bakery, Patisserie La Soleil. The game hints at various previous happenings in the family that have led Kashou to move out and attempt to start his adult life again on his own. While moving in, Kashou discovers that two large and unfamiliar boxes have been left in the bakery by the movers. When he opens them, he finds Chocola and Vanilla, the two youngest catgirls in the Minaduki family, waiting inside.  If you're not familiar with Nekopara lore already, catgirls are genetically modified human female / cat hybrids, who are partly treated as pets and partly as valuable family members. They are human-sized and with mostly human looks, but with ears, tails, and very feline personality traits. The Minaduki family's youngest member, Kashou's sister, Shigure, owns six of them, all with very distinct personalities: Vanilla, Chocola, Cinnamon, Coconut, Maple, and Azuki  For various reasons, not the least of them being emotional blackmail, Kashou ends up keeping the two catgirls around to help with setting up the bakery, and chooses to hire them as the shop's poster catgirls when La Soleil opens. He soon finds that to be legally employed or to travel around by themselves, the catgirls must pass a test and carry a bell-collar license with them at all times.  Volume 1 focuses on Kashou, Chocola, and Vanilla, in their efforts to open and run the bakery while also learning to live together.  [h1]Graphics[/h1] Graphics are extremely similar to Volume 0, with beautiful paper-doll cut outs and animated models of the catgirls over slightly blurry digitally painted backgrounds. As with Volume 0, animations are much more detailed and frequent than in any other visual novel series that I've seen.  The game has some different drawing styles in parts, including 'chibi' art.   [h1]Sound[/h1] As with Volume 0, both title and in-game music fall into the typical anime theme-song style, with upbeat electronic instruments and an elevator-music feel. The music is well produced and inoffensive, but not the sort of thing I'd listen to while on a long drive.  Sound effects are good, but few and far between, being used to punctuate the music and speech at appropriate places in the story.  All characters except the protagonist, Kashou, are fully voiced. Though I don't understand Japanese well, they seem quite professional to me and suit the personalities well. Sounds and voices are normalised well.  [h1]Gameplay[/h1] Nekopara Volume 1 plays like a traditional visual novel, with no player choices and thus only one available ending. The norm in the genre is to promote replayability through multiple available choices and multiple endings, so it seems a little bit of a letdown to have only a completely linear path with no real interaction available.  The game engine appears to be exactly the same one that is used in Volume 0, with features such as autoplay, skipping, backlog, multiple languages, animations, and the all-important chest bounciness. There are no real interaction points on the screen; all you do is click to advance to the next line of dialogue or the next scene where appropriate.  Though the game has the sexual content and nudity tags on its Steam store page, without the official adult patch it's actually very tame for an anime-themed visual novel. There's a mildly raunchy still shot of a shower scene, with censored nudity, and sex scenes, which are implied or talked about, but not actually shown. The patch is prohibitively expensive -- often more than the game itself -- so I wasn't able to review the adult version of the game.  The story is fairly typical of a manga, anime, or visual novel plot, with no real twists or surprises. It's mostly light hearted and fun, and there are a few genuinely funny parts. The translation isn't the best, but it's definitely passable. You may notice some poor grammar and weird sentences: "She smiled with her usual tone of voice."  The Achievements are almost all unmissable, though there's the same secret Achievement as in Volume 0.   [h1]PROS AND CONS[/h1] Pros: + The same attractive catgirl characters + Steam Achievements and Trading Cards + An adult patch is available, but ...  Cons: - ... the game is already a bit pricey, and the adult patch doubles the cost - Some grammatical errors and other weirdness - No choices or control; just watching and clicking  [h1]CONCLUSION[/h1] Nekopara Volume 1 is an enjoyable visual novel with beautiful, lovable catgirl characters, but a somewhat banal script and no choices or real replayability. Anyone interested in the adult version of the game needs to realise it will cost them double the price of the 'safe' version on Steam, and the Steam version completely skips the erotic scenes that are included in the patch. Here's the review at least a few of you have been waiting for!  For those of you new to visual novels, Nekopara and games like it aren't really games. There are no decisions to be made, no changing the outcome of the story. Just like a book or a movie, you're merely observing as everything plays out.  This story is set in a world where genetically modified cat-girls are kept as pets and servants. The main character opens a bakery and his (oddly obsessive and possibly incestuous) sister sends him two cat-girls as companions to help him out.  The story is, to put it mildly, odd. It gets even stranger when the cat-girls become, ahem, "interested" in their master.  GAMEPLAY  There basically isn't any. You can advance the dialogue and you can interact with the characters in a limited way (by petting them). Again, this isn't really a game.  STORY  There's basically nothing else to Nekopara, so this had better be good. And it is. You'd never expect a story about running a bakery with two "curious" cat-girls to be interesting, but a good visual novel gets you invested in its characters. The two cat-girls are well-written and their personalities are quite distinct. The relationships develop somewhat naturally, as naturally as relationships between humans and genetically-modified cat-women can.  I *did* say it was weird.  GRAPHICS  Honestly, these matter more to a visual novel than you'd expect, since they're half of the game (the *visual* part of visual novel). And here's where the game absolutely shines. Not only are the characters extremely well designed and drawn, the animation is lifelike and fun. Since it is an H-game, there is adjustable bounce, but it seems somewhat odd to include it when neither of the characters it affects are particularly busty.  The backgrounds and settings are pretty average, but the characters themselves are so eye-catching and fun that it's never really an issue.  CONCLUSION  The game's weird, and not really a game. Those are two key points here. It's also (if modded to its intended content) an adult game. However, the story and art are fantastic and the animation is the icing on the cake. If you're the sort of person who doesn't mind games with extremely strange premises that are basically waifu simulators, then this is a really great game.  I give this game five cat-girls out of five.

I swear I am playing it for the plot
Before I begin, yes. Yes this game is almost exsactly what you think it is. If you can't draw judgement from that, I'll elaborate.   This game is a visual novel, so not so much a game as much as it is a short story with some pictures and animations to go with it. You do not play it at all.  For what I was expecting, I actually got a lot more, though I"ll say my experience with visual novels is extremely thin. It has a great menu system. Everything is where you'd expect it to be, and there are a lot of options to help fine tune the game should you feel the need to. There's even a "Bust bouncyness" option, which thank the lord because it's akward to see them flounder like a fish whenever they make a move. It even comes with 80 save files for whatever reason.   Visually, it passes all the tests. Backgrounds and characters are detailed, and said characters are animated and fully voiced, minus the one male in the game. They even have proper lipsyncing and animations that play on queue to what is said. Though the farther into the game you go, the more you'll see repeating animations and movements. They serve their perpose well, but it does get old after a while.  The music is fine, good even. Nothing to hum to, but enough to set the mood. There's only five of them though, so expect to hear the same tracks many times.   Lastly, the writting... Kinda a mixed bag. What little lore they put in place makes complete sense and makes a great backdrop to the happenings of the game. Things don't tend to "Just be like that". It's coheisive and straight forward.  However, they hit all of the sugar sweet troupes for an anime of this type. Everyone loves the none discript main charecter, everyone is amazing by in game standerds, yadda yadda, you get the idea. You'll catch on to the true motives of the game really quickly. It's dangerously sweet, to excess even. I'll admit I was having fun for a while, but it wore off right around chapter 5 when things started settling in. The pacing is pretty shotty, like a photo album someone made of their favorite parts of a story, the biggest exsample being [spoiler] When the two cover catgirls are trying to obtain their bells, a sort of right of passage permit. One day the little sister know it all comes over to help them study for the first time  to the end of some hijinx, and the very next scene they're coming back from a delivery, bells firmly hung from their necks. No signs of an endevor or anything. [/Spoiler]  Can I reccomend the game? Honestly, I don't know if I have the right to. It's obvious that it has a very specific market it's trying to pitch itself to, even more blatently so in the R-18 version which, thankfully, was edited down in the steam version. My positive recomondation score is based purely off the effort that was put into the workings of the game and the effort that was obviously put into it. What you get out of the game is up to you. Just trust you gut on this one.  TLDR: Sugar, hold the spice, but leave the everything nice. What you see is what you get.

Look at my playtime and buy it. Soundtrack is nice, Story is short but nice. [b]And there are catgirls.[/b]

:3
Bad
I have a love-hate relationship with visual novels. I love the medium and its potential, but the unfortunate truth is that the vast majority of them -- even many popular ones -- have downright execrable writing. Fortunately, [i]NEKOPARA[/i] does not.  While [i]NEKOPARA[/i] occasionally stumbles by including a few of the typical "visual novel-isms" such as a bland protagonist (not too bland, thankfully), characters who state the obvious (though the game doesn't assume we're dumb), characters who announce their feelings ("You can't just have your characters announce how they feel! That makes me feel angry!"), and unnecessary flashbacks (mercifully few and brief), it is, to my amazement, well-written and intelligent for a visual novel and eroge.  The dialogue is, for the most part, passable with occasional flashes of brilliance and poetic constructions -- yes, really; there can rhythm and beauty in seemingly ordinary prose, even in the gutter -- and I have to admit that certain word choices really provided some much-needed scratching of itches. In addition, the dialogue often made curious use of English-language idioms which, to my utter disbelief, were not only used [i]correctly[/i] but also used in evocative ways. For that, I commend the writers and translators for their work.  You may find this hard to believe, but there is some thoughtful and intriguing world-building going on in the background of this silly little erotic visual novel. The idea, for instance, that the catgirls will be arrested if they wander around on their own -- that some catgirls have turned to crime to support themselves -- provides a brief but tantalizing glimpse into a world in which the visual novel's cute, nonsensical premise clashes with a serious, harsh reality. Even the idea of the Bells the cats wear -- the idea that catgirls can educate themselves in human culture in order to be more autonomous -- is fascinating, not the least because the idea's foundations rest on a very old English-language proverb with political connotations: "bell the cat." Think about it.  I'm a writer, not an artist, so I can't give any in-depth review of the art, but in my opinion, the character design is fine. Some of the secondary characters are a little too forgettable in their design, but the main characters are appealing enough. (My personal favorite is Vanilla.) I think the breast bouncing is a bit silly, but the animation during story scenes is often striking. And the animation in erotic scenes is quite good, indeed.  The music is all right. Some of the tracks wear a little thin after a while due to their short length, but others are quite evocative. Some of the sound effects are bad, and they're made even worse by how short they are and how frequently (and unnecessarily) they're looped. The licking/sucking sound effect in particular is irksome -- ugly, even. I would rather have just silence between lines of dialogue than [i]that[/i] particular sound effect.  The voice acting is good. You will likely find some characters more enjoyable to listen to than others, but for my part, I liked all of them. Chocola and Vanilla's voice actresses, of course, deserve particular note. They went above and beyond in recording erotic dialogue. I often found myself astounded by their voice acting.  I have high praise for the UI. It's simple, aesthetically-pleasing, and the configuration menu allows you to change a number of aspects about the game, which I appreciated.  [b]One final thing, and this is important:[/b] if you buy this game on Steam, note that [i]you are not getting the full version of the game[/i]. You are buying a version of the game which has apparently been heavily censored -- all the erotic scenes have been removed from it. I [i]strongly[/i] disapprove of that kind of censorship. [spoiler]Fortunately, there is an unofficial patch available on the patch18 website which (in my experience) allowed me to effortlessly restore the originally-intended content.[/spoiler]  I believe in the right of all artists to write, draw, and otherwise depict whatever they wish. And there are other erotic visual novels available for sale on Steam -- completely uncensored -- so why was this one subjected to such heavy-handed and needless censorship? I don't know the full story, but I can say this: if not for that patch, I would not be recommending this game. To me, it is unconscionable to sell only part of a product but market it as the whole. Perhaps this is Steam's fault. Perhaps it's the distributor's. I do not know.  Overall, I would say that [i]NEKOPARA[/i] is worth taking a look into if you're looking to play an interesting and sexy visual novel with fairly good dialogue. I would especially recommend taking a look at it if you are interested in, as I am, writing and developing erotic visual novels. It has many elements that it does well -- dialogue, voice acting, character design, animation -- and you could certainly do worse in finding games to guide and inspire your own work.

[h1]Nekopara is a visual novel where the main character moves out of his home to start his own cafe in the city. Not too long after moving, he learns his kawaii catgirls decided to tag along with him.[/h1]  [i]When I boot up this game, many of my friends call me a creeper, a weirdo... and some even call me a nerd without a girlfriend, and one even called me a weeaboo freak. When I look at the cute neko girl faces in this visual novel, I don't care what my friends call me.[/i]  As a visual novel, [b]Nekopara is just a game you play for the story[/b]. Listening and/or reading dialogue, and seeing the characters animate (which they animate pretty well). This game is pretty short, and [i]could be completed in about 4 hours on autopilot.[/i]  [b]There is an 18+ version/patch available not on Steam, if you would like to see cutscenes involving intimacy with the neko girls[/b] (I personally have it).  Is it worth the $10? I personally enjoy anime/manga, so a visual novel of this quality is actually fine for $10 in my opinion. Is the 18+ version worth $20? Well, I'll admit it's the first time I've seen an 18+ visual novel with animated scenes, but uh... no comment...

I know these kind of games usually gather the funny styled reviews but I will try and give it a more serious one for people who are geniounly interested in Visual Novel titles (Hentai or not).   Let's start with the positives first. Everything in the game is well drawn and all characters during dialogues are animated giving it far more flair than most games of this genre which are usually consist of static images. The voice overs are decent (even though there is no choice for other languages other than Japanese), and the translators did a good job not butchering the script. Also if you apply the 18+ patch the sex scenes are well drawn and animated, so if you bought this game just for the porn aspect you will get your money's worth.    And those are all the positives of the game. Unfortunately the negatives outweight them by quite the margin. For start there are no choices to be made in the entirety of Nekopara. You just read the dialogues with no way to alter the story. And since I mentioned the story, basically there is none. It tries to tell a story of a world were humanoid cat girls exist and what is their place in the society but quickly it stops bothering. After the half hour mark it only cares about the sex and every conflict it tries to create is resolved in a couple of panels. Also, not only the game last around 2 hours it doesn't have multiple endings.   All in all, a well drawn Visual Novel with decent echhi scenes but nothing else. No decent story, no memorable characters, no multiple endings, extremely short. Get it only if you are into anime cat girls.

Japan holds technology capable of breeding a race of humanoids who reach maturity in about a year. In most cases, this would lead to an army of easily and quickly replacable samurai assault troops with the capacity to conquer, say, the South China Sea. In this case, however, we take a sharp left through a brick wall and create a race of adorable, female only, human-feline hybrids, whom cannot produce offspring with humans and have no logical means of maintaining population, and are also quite dim-witted. World conquest grows ever farther, but cuddles and fucks aplenty here.  Nekopara is a kinetic novel about a guy/possible robot who finds family and companionship with his ever loyal twin catgirls. Yep, that about sums the plot up. That said, the animation is pretty amazing, with characters that sway and blink and whatnot, appearing quite lively compared to most VNs I've seen. I was quite taken by the animation, and the catgirls are endearing characters, although I sure as hell wouldn't want a real one. Overall, I'd recommend it, especially if its on sale.

I won't go into the pro's and con's of visual novels, nor will I discuss the.....Adult...contents that were cut away in this one.  Frankly, this is one of the best I've ever read through, in terms of visual novels. Why? Because the characters are so poignant. I don't know how else to explain it, but there are points where the characters just tugged at my heart, dealing with rejection, love, family, and so on.   Definately worth buying, not a single regret on my end.

This is what they mean by "A catgirl is fine too."~  Pros: - Enjoyable BGM~ - Fun, fluffy and bouncy Nekos~ - Animated Nekos, gives them more personality~ - Multiple Language Selection~ - A few humorous exchanges~ - Voice Over (although Jap only)~  Cons: - Too much Comedy/Slice-of-Life, not enough Drama (imo)~ - Story is kind of repetitive after first H-scene~
NekoPara Vol 1. is an adult oriented, though there is an All-Ages version available, VN featuring adorable catgirls and is the 1st of a series of 3. There are no choices to be had just plain ol’ reading/listening & a few vanilla sex scenes in the 18+ version, this is an Eroge not a Nukige, so the sex is not the aim of the game, one does not equal the other. It features only Japanese voice acting, a lot of it & for everyone but the MC. The story follows Kashou Minaduki, an aspiring baker who has recently moved away from his family for reasons to open up his own shop. Metal Gear Solid style our 2 main catgirls, Chocola & Vanilla, have snuck in inside of his moving boxes. After some back & forth they convince poor baker boy to let them stay.  Right out the bat I will say that the overarching story is a bit drab as this is an introductory game, though individual characters show some growth so it isn’t all that bad & has its funny as well as its share of sad moments.  The story is presented in the VN style of text boxes & sprites, though the sprites are animated using ‘E-mote’, a system akin to Live2D. It is pretty amazing seeing what would normally be plain static images come to life as they express themselves in various ways as they talk. This feature is also used on most of the sex scenes to great effect. Standard art is also used, with some chibi art used on comedic occasions & backgrounds fitting the overall style, which I appreciate. Music is decent with most of it being cheery stuff and a few somber tracks.  Option wise, it is also the standard VN affair for the most part, with sliders for sound volume, text box transparency, etc. The game features Chinese along with Japanese & English text, as mentioned voices will always be Japanese. You can customize the sound volume for each character along with extra voices. The ‘E-mote’ system allow for... chest bounciness (Press the ‘P’ on your keyboard, trust me) which you can customize with a slider too, though I must be blind since I didn’t see much change.  All in all, Neko Para Vol. 1 is a beautiful, but only ok storywise VN that would be of best value when purchased at a discount as the story was very tame & serving as more of stepping stone to the sequels. The art & usage of ‘E-mote’ to bring to life sprites is pretty amazing & something to be experienced & will definitely continue to experience as soon as I get my hands on the sequels. With a 3rd one in the works along with an anime OVA fans are sure to have plenty of NekoPara for a while to come.

My hand hurt...
Well, 2017 (well, the Winter Sale, actually) got me to give in and try these "Light Novel" things.   Now, as an anime fan, I thought this was cute. Since all you can really do is watch it go by (automatically or at your own pace) it's another show to watch / experience.  As a gamer, this was boring as HELL!!! There is little to no input on your part. All you really do is click to continue the script and that's it. If there were any choices, that would have made it more of a game (and IMO, more fun) but as it stands, it has none and shouldn't be considered a game.  But, all in all, this was a fun experience (if, at times, a bit uncomfortable - I never will understand the Japanese fascination of sisters wanting to get it on with their brothers) and I recommend it if you need a break from long gaming sessions. I can definitely see the appeal for Fan-Service fans and anime fans alike. If the Nekopara franchise ever makes an actual game where you can do things, I'm in. An anime is planned, I believe, and that will be something to look forward to as well.  TTLD: If the price is right, pick up this little show but don't expect any actual gameplay, there is none.

Ok, I want to be honest.  NekoPara is my favorite visual novel.   I mean, come on, agree with me. Who never thought about Nekos and how nice it would be for them to be real. Well, NekoPara lets your wish come true. IN A VERY GOOD WAY. First of all, I should warn you, since it's on steam, this is the ALL-Ages version, means no "special" scene's and censorism, but still, that doesn't kill this for me. I love the story and the characters into the absolute. You really recognize that this visual novel was made with lots of love and hard work. The drawings are good, the story better and the characters are the best. I love how vanilla changes her way to think of her "master" Kashou. First, she dislikes him a bit, but then slowly she begins to fall in love with him. Also, the music is just great.  Huh, I love NekoPara. 10/10, You should definatly buy it if you like Nekos and Visual Novels!  (Btw, an Anime is coming soon. Before someone insults me, I mean an "OVA"!)

Huge fan of Sayori but the... "game" was plain boring.... The visual are pretty as expected from Sayori but... Man I was so bored but Im not a visual novel fan at first so... Eh.
Note: I played the non-patched adult version, meaning no sexual content was shown or told, but time lapsed over.  I had to read these in short bursts, like a chapter each.  People kept implying it was a porn-game with the screenshots I kept seeing so wasn't interested in getting it. A friend gifted me this and Vol 0. I read vol 0 first and wrote a review for that then started reading this. (Vol 0 review here: http://steamcommunity.com/id/BluePaw/recommended/385800 )  There's a lot of tear jerking moments that at times seems overwhelming or ubundent, or just drones on as filler that it gets annoying and want to move on. The characters you meet are unique in their own way. The animation for a VN seemed good. Voices... I guess were okay? Usually prefer english dub in Anime so... what do I know?  How the story ended left a sour taste in my mouth... felt it should've ended a few chapters sooner.  However... despite all that, I loved it. I was slowly warming up & understanding the characters and the world they lived in. My only constant irk was catgirls always refering to their owners as "master"... I understand it's part of that world but just felt awkward, always, when they tell that to the guy you're viewing from that it feels like they're saying that to the reader directly.  There was suggestive themes that I didn't mind since it didn't get carried away or annoying, as they were either comical or romantic... however some parts were overly romantic that I wanted to throw up! (I'm not a romance person, obviously.)  This is a good read though. The story is actually interesting overall and the characters have their purpose in the story, regardless of how they were designed. This isn't a porn game, this is a story with minor adult themes but not focused on such things.  I have no interest in getting the 18+ or patch as I prefered, in this VN, to time lapse them and let me speculate what could happened on the after-math scene. Wouldn't feel comfortable to see such a thing with these characters.  -----  Check out more games I see that deserve more attention from my curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/BPUGL]BluePaw's Underrated Games List[/url] Join and/or follow if you wish.

Nekopara Vol. 1 is a Japanese anime Visual Novel. This story is an alt future slice of life story with an "eroge" love triangle. I thought it had good, understandable, cute, funny and interesting story. It has great artwork, japanese voiceovers, english subtitles, animation, music and sound.    Has more animations of characters, including a chest bouncyness slider.  It is a cliche anime story, characters and fanservice.  There was no choices, but Good for 5 hours of "Reading". Has Easy steam achievements and badge cards.  Has a movie gallery and a scene gallery.  It has a free hentai patch, wow nice extra hentai material, blurry xxx.   Warning: NSFW, NSFH and could give men a boner. I needed a shower after finishing this. Nudge Nudge Wink Wink.  Might be worth the full price, but better to get this on sale or with the Nekopara Bundle. This game just looks so pleasant and Weebie! who wouldn't like to play it.  Of course if you're unsure then this may help you decide if it's for you -  It's a VN so there's little gameplay and no choices but the story is quite nice and the art is really clean! the characters speak and even move and erm... Bounce. The game nicely caters to your fanservice needs with cat-girls, but it's all very linear like a kinetic novel.  You don't have choice between your hoes, despite it saying "dating sim" in the tags, it in fact follows the two simple-minded neko girls Chocola and Vanilla as they're being cute around Kashou Minaduki, the owner of La Soleil. The whole Nekopara bundle is probably about 20 odd dollars all up so it's reletively cheap for such a pleasant experience.  It's basically a kinetic novel but if you like cat girls you should buy it.

cuz nekos
In consideration of the ageing population of Japan, it is a relief to find that there are still young members of the workforce who are able to take the next step forward in small business ownership.   NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a visual novel that deals with the startup and establishment of a small business in the local economy. While not so much touching on the subject of financing and legal procedure associated with new entrepreneurship, NEKOPARA Vol. 1 does delve into the issues associated with human resource management particularly those of the interpersonal relationships between employees and employer. As with any SME (small and medium enterprises), delegation has long been an issue in the first few years of ownership. In fact, inefficient assignment of responsibilities is a major cause of business failure.   NEKOPARA Vol. 1 follows a young business owner in Japan as he works through the bumps and kinks faced by new business owners. It touches on subjects related to the securing and development of human resources which in turn leads to the promotion of organizational growth. Subjects such as: - pampering your kawaii neko-chan employees through intimate skinship - sleeping with those same neko-chan employees to indulge their lust as they sexually mature - acquiring the most kawaii desu attire for your neko-chans to wear to satisfy your filthy maid fetish - appease your imouto-chan who calls you up every second day to get off to your alpha male-testosterone filled voice - baking cakes.  I'd highly recommend this game to anyone who is looking for insight into the development of SME's in Japan under the parliamentary guidance of Shinzō Abe during his second term as PM.  And lolicons.

I played this game during a bout of heavy insomnia, stress (moving houses/downsizing) and anxiety. at first i was intriuged at the thought of girls that were also cats (once a wholsome concept to me i assure you) but around the time of the "give us a bath"scene (if you've played it, you'll understand) i began to realize the true horror that was "NEKOPARA Vol. 1" after the aforementioned scene i clung to my chair as the lights in our neighbor's house flicked on and in my desk mirror, i watched my neighbor's eight year old son stare on in horror through  his livingroom window into our diningroom window (moving houses so no curtians) as the cat girls "chesticles" ungulated at high velocity. at this point i could do no more than turn off my monitor and then all the lights in the room untill his mother escorted him sternly (assuming) back to his bedroom. after that, i decided to tempt fate and return to the game (i have to finish what i start... i'm also sort of a self loathing masochist) i ended up completeing the game with all but two achivements (something that jiggles...) and by the time dawn rolled around my face was frozen in a perpetual scowl and my voice obliterated from screaming "NO!" as loudly as possible. overall, not a bad game for someone who's into this sort of thing, but for eight year old boys discovering voyurism for the first time, curiosity definately killed the catgirl.

This is a visual novel about You opening a brand new bakery away from home. Your little sister is left in charge of the Nekos (catgirls) at the home. However she is rather good at being a troll it seems. While unpacking you discover that there are two boxes that are quite heavy and also making noises. Two of the Nekos, the two main Nekos of this chapter, have stowed away and are now living with you in the bakery. This follows You and Chocola and Vannila as they try and become official workers at your bakery.   This story is awesome. It is full of adorable voice acting and scenes. Slight animation on the characters help to bring them more to life. The pros and cons will follow now.  Pros: 1. Excellent Voice Acting 2. Adorable Characters 3. Well written story 4. Quite fitting animation 5. Written text is available in English for us Muricans 6. Character development is pretty natural in the story flow and not choked in with exposition. 7. Voice over is only in Japanese 8. Optional H Patch  Cons: 1. Optional H Patch ruins the purity and cuteness of the Characters. 2. Animation can be a little jumpy and can glitch out the character sprites. (Happens very rarely) 3. Voice over is only in Japanese  4. Story is over a little to quickly
[Note: There is an unofficial 18+ patch for this game.  Don't use the YouTube video tutorial, there is a different page with an actual download for an installer.  The game will still blur out certain things due to Japanese law.]  Played some Sakura games prior to this and was suprised by this when I started getting into the story.  (Sakura Swimclub was pretty weak, just there for the patch...)  This is really funny and cute.  Even if you want the kid friendly version it's worth playing for the lols. Will probably play the other games in the series.
Came for the cat girls. Stayed for the "plot"
I really want to make a serious review on this title as I actually quite enjoyed it not because of the mature parts, but more so for the art and music.  Got this game when it went on sale as I wanted to try and see what the appeal of visual novels were and why there were so many on Steam. My reasoning for choosing this one is actually pretty simple: it's very colorful and the characters all have glass-shine eyes which I really adore. Anime in general always inspires me to be creative whether it be art or writing.  Anyway, the story itself is not bad. It's a simple story of a guy wanting to start a life of his own only to have to deal with his catgirls which are considered pets. If I recall correctly, they're not Humans made into Cats, but the other way around which kind of gives me some moral issues. That's just me, but each their own.  Each character is a stereotype of some kind. Chocola's an airhead, Vanilla is calm-minded but always goes to the extremes, etc. About halfway through, I actually stopped caring about any of them apart from Vanilla who at least stayed consistent enough to not have me smash my face against my desk. There's one minor arc in here that I made me sad which I won't spoil here.   Music in this game is fantastic, each track sets a perfect mood for the scene even if it's cliche as hell. Art, as I said before, is really beatiful and very well done. For me it was worth the price I paid which I think was $8. As for the suggestive scene(?) it's not really that bad. Definitely want to make sure nobody is around, though.  Also, I want to gripe about this because there is absolutely [b]NO REASON[/b] for this, why the hell are there 10 pages of save slots? Also, deleting them corrupts the file so if you accidentally saved, I don't know of a fix right now other than probably a fresh install. Back to the point, no visual novel, I don't care how long, does not need 170 save slots even if I were to save at every single scene.   I recommend this if you are looking for something simple that you can read for an hour.

[i]Joke reviews aside[/i], this VN is pretty good! The artwork is superb, the VA is great and it has animations, that's right, animated characters! Be wary though, because the animations in this VN is quite taxing on your CPU/GPU (It might not be the case on your PC, but it's a little too heavy on my netbook). Also, make sure to set your [u]mipmap quality[/u] setting for this game in your GPU control panel to [u]"High Quality"[/u], since setting it to "Performance/Low Quality" will make the characters in animated scenes blurry. How about the story you say? Well it's there and it does its job, but it's there so you can see cute catgirls moments and nothing else really. Also there's no different conversation choices and ending for this VN, but you're going to see catgirls anyway, so i won't worry too much about that part. In conclusion, if you like animated catgirls and you don't mind going through texts to see more animated catgirls, go buy this VN! -billy96
I thought about going out and maybe finding myself a gf but now I'm thinking I'll be just fine.  Side note: If you're not playing with the 18+ patch, you ain't playing it right.
The world of NEKOPARA sounds interesting enough. At some point, genetic engineering has progressed to the point where catgirls are available as pets, companions, and whatnot. Nowadays, there are less stray catgirls, and there are hints of problems with some involved in criminal activity. To combat this problem, catgirls with owners can have their pets take an exam to get a Bell collar that allows them to be monitored and walk in public by themselves.   Unfortunately for those who like visual novels with serious storylines, this is not one. Kashou leaves his strict household to open a Western-style bakery. However, two of his family's cats, Chocola and Vanilla, follow him, and refuse to leave. He ends up hiring them, and light, fluffy, slice of life romance ensues. Made somewhat awkward by his initial impression of the two as daughters, the romance is pretty much tacked on.  Thankfully, the ero scenes have been removed from the Steam release.  However, as someone who loves cats, there are some interesting questions that just don't get any answers. Catgirls, despite their humanoid appearance, age at the same rate as real cats. People refer to treating their catgirls as their children. There's a bit of fridge horror in that question. Catgirls seem to be genetically engineered to be sterile, presumably to save them the trauma of a surgery. The criminal element is not explained, though for some reason, catgirls stealing people's food, knocking things over, and causing trouble by climbing tall things comes to mind.   So do I recommend this game? That depends on the player, really. Too bad there's not a 'so-so' button. Despite that, I want to see how Kashou and his cat family do running the bakery. I'm actually curious about the background of this world. Will I like what I find? I'll find something, I'm sure.
