Nekos or plot ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) ? why not both ?
Bread is a staple food prepared from a dough of flour and water, usually by baking. Throughout recorded history it has been popular around the world and is one of the oldest artificial foods, having been of importance since the dawn of agriculture.  There are many combinations and proportions of types of flour and other ingredients, and also of different traditional recipes and modes of preparation of bread. As a result, there are wide varieties of types, shapes, sizes, and textures of breads in various regions. Bread may be leavened by many different processes ranging from the use of naturally occurring microbes (for example in sourdough recipes) to high-pressure artificial aeration methods during preparation or baking. However, some products are left unleavened, either for preference, or for traditional or religious reasons. Many non-cereal ingredients may be included, ranging from fruits and nuts to various fats. Commercial bread in particular, commonly contains additives, some of them non-nutritional, to improve flavor, texture, color, shelf life, or ease of manufacturing.  Depending on local custom and convenience, bread may be served in various forms at any meal of the day. It also is eaten as a snack, or used as an ingredient in other culinary preparations, such as fried items coated in crumbs to prevent sticking, or the bland main component of a bread pudding, or stuffings designed to fill cavities or retain juices that otherwise might drip away.  Partly because of its importance as a basic foodstuff, bread has a social and emotional significance beyond its importance in nutrition; it plays essential roles in religious rituals and secular culture. Its prominence in daily life is reflected in language, where it appears in proverbs, colloquial expressions ("He stole the bread from my mouth"), in prayer ("Give us this day our daily bread") and even in the etymology of words, such as "companion" and "company" (literally those who eat/share bread with you).  Contents [hide]  1 Etymology 2 History 3 Types 4 Preparation 4.1 Formulation 4.2 Flour 4.3 Liquids 4.4 Leavening 4.4.1 Chemical leavening 4.4.2 Yeast 4.4.3 Sourdough 4.4.4 Steam 4.4.5 Bacteria 4.4.6 Aeration 4.5 Fats or shortenings 4.6 Bread improvers 5 Properties 5.1 Chemical composition 5.2 Serving and consumption 5.3 Nutritional significance 5.4 Shelf life 5.5 Crust 6 Cultural significance 6.1 Europe 6.2 Latin America 6.3 North Africa 6.4 Asia 6.5 North America 7 Religious significance 7.1 Abrahamic Religions 7.2 Paganism 8 Anti-bread movements 9 In Medicine 10 See also 11 References 12 Further reading 13 External links Etymology The word itself, Old English bread, is most common in various forms to many Germanic languages, such as Frisian brea, Dutch brood, German Brot, Swedish bröd, and Norwegian and Danish brød; it has been claimed to be derived from the root of brew. It may be connected with the root of break, for its early uses are confined to broken pieces or bits of bread, the Latin crustum, and it was not until the 12th century that it took the place—as the generic name for bread—of hlaf (hlaifs in Gothic: modern English loaf), which appears to be the oldest Teutonic name.[1] Old High German hleib[2] and modern German Laib derive from this Proto-Germanic word for "loaf", which was borrowed into Slavic (Polish chleb, Russian khleb) and Finnic (Finnish leipä, Estonian leib) languages as well.  In many cultures, bread is a metaphor for basic necessities and living conditions in general. For example, a "bread-winner" is a household's main economic contributor and has little to do with actual bread-provision. This is also seen in the phrase "putting bread on the table". The Roman poet Juvenal satirized superficial politicians and the public as caring only for "panem et circenses" (bread and circuses). In Russia in 1917, the Bolsheviks promised "peace, land, and bread."[3][4] The term "breadbasket" denotes an agriculturally productive region. In Slavic cultures bread and salt is offered as a welcome to guests. In India, life's basic necessities are often referred to as "roti, kapra aur makan" (bread, cloth, and house). In Israel, the most usual phrase in work-related demonstrations is lekhem, avoda ("bread, work").  The word bread is commonly used around the world in English-speaking countries as a synonym for money[1] (as is the case with the word "dough"). A remarkable or revolutionary innovation is often referred to in North America and the United Kingdom as "the greatest thing since sliced bread" or "the best thing since sliced bread". In Cockney rhyming slang, bread means money; this usage is derived from the phrase "bread and honey".[5]  History Main article: History of bread  Bread shop, Tacuinum Sanitatis from Northern Italy, beginning of the 15th century Bread is one of the oldest prepared foods. Evidence from 30,000 years ago in Europe revealed starch residue on rocks used for pounding plants.[6] It is possible that during this time, starch extract from the roots of plants, such as cattails and ferns, was spread on a flat rock, placed over a fire and cooked into a primitive form of flatbread. Around 10,000 BC, with the dawn of the Neolithic age and the spread of agriculture, grains became the mainstay of making bread. Yeast spores are ubiquitous, including the surface of cereal grains, so any dough left to rest will become naturally leavened.[7]  There were multiple sources of leavening available for early bread. Airborne yeasts could be harnessed by leaving uncooked dough exposed to air for some time before cooking. Pliny the Elder reported that the Gauls and Iberians used the foam skimmed from beer to produce "a lighter kind of bread than other peoples." Parts of the ancient world that drank wine instead of beer used a paste composed of grape juice and flour that was allowed to begin fermenting, or wheat bran steeped in wine, as a source for yeast. The most common source of leavening was to retain a piece of dough from the previous day to use as a form of sourdough starter.[8]  In 1961 the Chorleywood bread process was developed, which used the intense mechanical working of dough to dramatically reduce the fermentation period and the time taken to produce a loaf. The process, whose high-energy mixing allows for the use of lower protein grain, is now widely used around the world in large factories. As a result, bread can be produced very quickly and at low costs to the manufacturer and the consumer. However there has been some criticism of the effect on nutritional value.[9]  Recently, domestic bread machines that automate the process of making bread have become popular.  Types  White bread (left) and brown bread. See also: List of breads Bread is the staple food of the Middle East, North Africa, Europe, and in European-derived cultures such as those in the Americas, Australia, and Southern Africa, in contrast to East Asia where rice is the staple. Bread is usually made from a wheat-flour dough that is cultured with yeast, allowed to rise, and finally baked in an oven. Owing to its high levels of gluten (which give the dough sponginess and elasticity), common wheat (also known as bread wheat) is the most common grain used for the preparation of bread.  Bread is also made from the flour of other wheat species (including durum, spelt and emmer), rye, barley, maize (corn), and oats, usually, but not always, in combination with wheat flour. Spelt bread (Dinkelbrot) continues to be widely consumed in Germany, and emmer bread was a staple food in ancient Egypt. Canadian bread is known for its heartier consistency due to high protein levels in Canadian flour.  Pita is an ancient semi-leavened bread widespread in the Middle East, Levant and South Eastern Europe. White bread is made from flour containing only the central core(endosperm). Brown bread is made with endosperm and 10% bran. It can also refer to white bread with added coloring (often caramel) to make it brown

NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a great game, theres are countless hours of fun and there are a lot of aspects to if that a similar game league of legends is lacking.  1. The workshop, this is where the community really has its biggest aspect on the game, most of the items put into NEKOPARA Vol. 1 come out of the workshop and community artists that are dedicated to their work! 3. Unlike League of legends, all the catgirls in NEKOPARA Vol. 1 are unlocked when you start the game, giving the game a total different aspect and feel. 4. The catgirl pool is very big and very diverse, all the catgirls have differing abilities and there are multiple catgirls for everyone. 5. The catgirls looks beautiful - I personally prefer NEKOPARA Vol. 1 graphics and they way the catgirl  is layed out far more than that of League of legends, I just think its a smarter design. 6. It is usable through steam - My biggest complaint with LoL was that I couldn't play it through steam, but NEKOPARA Vol. 1 solves those problems. 7. If you have a full party or at least 3, the game can be super fun - I think this game is way better with friends, as it adds a whole new aspect to the game. You can show off your gaming skills and honestly have better gameplay with friends, as you know you will be able to communicate with them and pet catgirls much bettter than if you were playing with a bunch of randoms.  There are many more pros but those were just a couple i wanted to say. however there are downsides to NEKOPARA Vol. 1.  1. The community, many members of the community are hostile, or dont communicate or just cant understand you, For example, when I try to que in US West, half the time my team mates are from mexico or just dont speak any japanese. Than you get the people who just mic spam for no reason. 2. It can be really hard to get a match sometimes because of the people who take forever to accept or the people who dont load into the game. I have had times where my games have failed up to 6 times in a row! 3. NEKOPARA Vol. 1 Reborn. For people who may have played the game previously and stopped for a while, NEKOPARA Vol. 1 reborn may be a shock. NEKOPARA Vol. 1 reborn was pretty unecessary and has made the game much more confusing than it needs to be. With NEKOPARA Vol. 1 reborn they are trying to make NEKOPARA look like a much more fancy game than the old loading screen stuff did before, but instead has just made everything more confusing. It will take them a while to work out all the kinks but I think in the end they will work it out.  This is one of my favorite games, it is up there with the likes of Counter Strike - Global Offensive as my top all time most played games, also, living in the NorthWest region, I did get the chance to attend the Sakura-Con, which was one of the best Experiences of my life and would recommend it to anyone interested in going.

This game, much like vol. 0 did, will make you question your life. [i]What am I doing with my life?[/i]  This game, is unique to it's story, it teaches you a lot in the relationship between 2 catgirls, how to care and look after them, and what to do and not do as an owner. [spoiler]But let's face it, you just came for the explicit content...[/spoiler]  The game starts off quite what you'd expect, you are a business owner and you have just moved out of the house to try and make a living. But of course, let's not forget, you have extra boxes of stuff that you [i]didn't[/i] order. Which turns out that someone else ordered, you and the delivery woman take care of that and so it then on progresses to you noticing 2 boxes with strange labels on it, that has no delivery notice or anything. You hear a sound from the boxes, and notice that it's the catgirls from the home you moved out from.  As the story progresses you become more and more attached to them, eventually making said catgirls your "catpanions". In other words, they are basically your girlfriends in bed and for life. [spoiler]( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)[/spoiler]  If you are like me, then you will probably chat with other people 90% of the time and the remaning 10% just not care about the explicit scenes. Though, this makes the game appear longer than what it is, partially because it's not really suited for everyone's taste.   To summarize, I enjoyed the story, the details were good and, (I never thought I would say this) felt some kind of attachment to the catgirls. Don't blame me, I like to read, but I aint a bookworm.  It's a good game to "troll" your friends with, but I wouldn't recommend buying it for full price unless you basically have no worries about your economical situation (unlike me).  [spoiler]Though, you should convince them to install the "special patch" for full effect[/spoiler]  10/10, would learn how to get emotionally attached to virtual catgirls again.

The revolution has begun people... Go get some NEKOs now before it's too late...
Characters: 6.5/10  The main character is relatable, and his role seems to be something of a bastion of reliability, and, well... normalcy. His sister, although quite quirky, is also well written. The two main catgirls, by contrast, often behave instinctually, and can be unpredictable. To be honest I found their characters a little exaggerated at times, and difficult to engage with.  Story: 6/10  The story is long, but slow. Character develop and plot development happen in relatively discrete steps, rather than a gradual progression, which for me made immersion difficult. The development of relationships between the characters similarly seemed a little difficult to credit. The story reads like a chapter-based fairy tale or sorts. The fantastic nature of it is good, but it lacks the kind of interal consitency and attention to detail that make other stories believable.  Visuals: 7/10  The artwork is quite nice. Animation is basic. If you have a particular interest in catgirls in maid outfits, or the loli aesthetic (ribbons, bows, lace etc.), it may take your fancy.  Sound: 6.5/10  Voice acting is good. A few nice soundtracks as a backing to the story.  Overall score: 6.5/10  As a visual novel, this story just doesn't have quite enough going for it for me to recommend it.  It's worth noting here that while there is a mature content patch available for this game, it's not the product being sold here on Steam, and as such it's not what I'm basing my review on.

Best "game" ever.
As far as erotica goes NEKOPARA is on about the same level as stuff you can find for free. There's no real gameplay, so the achievements are pointless. Thanks to Steam's ban on adult content you can't even get the full package unless you resort to an unofficial patch, so if you are interested you need to make sure that's still available before you even consider purchasing.  The only reason someone might have to pay for this is the art and the voice acting. Unfortunately, the art and voice acting are in support of a dumb harem-style adventure. The plot is over-written at times and the main character is a jackass. Not the worst jackass I've ever had the displeasure of reading (the male protagonist isn't voice-acted), but still annoying. He's also kinda condescending, but considering he's basically a slave owner that's to be expected.  The weird cat-girl slave-race thing is both omnipresent and ignored, like in most pretend-monsterworld-japanese-fantasy-things. Some of the issues that might result from having to share society with less-intelligent genetically-modified human-like creatures is almost touched upon at times and swiftly discarded, because no one wants to go there even if it's hard not to wonder at the twisted possibilities the writing skirts. They make it clear that humans can't breed with cat girls, say nothing about cat boys, and leave the player to fap.  Not worth paying for unless it's heavily discounted or your really into stupid sappy hentai plots and meaningless achievements. Or, if you don't care about buying actual games on Steam. I'm still hoping there's a failure state in here somewhere :(
The japanese are some kooky folk

[h1]Short Review[/h1] NEKOPARA is one of the best VN's available on Steam right now. You play as a startup cafe owner joined by two catgirls. The story is a slice of life revolving around these three main characters with a few cameos from your sister and the rest of the catgirl bunch. The character development and voice acting are well done.  From a VN standpoint, NEKOPARA utilizes great animations and a full voice cast (besides yourself). The layout is clean and a few game features, such as: repeat voice dialogue, CG/scene/movie viewer, text speed, menu opacity etc., sets this VN above other generic pieces.   Also fyi, the Steam version of this game is censored. There are many guides out there on how to unofficially patch it to the uncensored R-18 version.  [h1]Score[/h1] Great - 9/10
I was in the mood for visual novels and this one looked interesting, plus it was on sale, so I thought why not? And well... seems like I got the wrong visual novel

NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a visual novel about uh....Nekos x). The story is about Kashou, who has always wanted to be a western ''pâtissier''. He decided to work his own way to manage his bakery named ''La soleil pâtisserie''. However, arriving at his bakery, he found 2 of his old cat friends - Chocola and Vanilla. At first He tried to make them leave, but soon after, he knew that he was actually forced to accept them to work together with him. You will see how they are going to co-operate and develop their relationships between them little by little, following the story.   This one is quite exclusive and different from the other VNs with its ''E-mote'' system, which adds movements and changes to their attitudes and gests during the dialogue, even without clicking it. Which is almost a perfect combination with those cute catgirls since it makes them even more attractive. [spoiler]Notice that there are quite some sexual themes in the original version of this VN, you can still enable it on steam by an add-on system; albeit I still recommend you to play this VN with a feeling of ''pure'' love, not that kind of ''feeling''.[/spoiler]  Positive remarks +E-mote which makes this game more lively +dynamic and romantic soundtracks  +very well-designed graphics +actually appropriate for all ages if you play the steam version +a different genre of characters- cats!^^  Negative remarks -the R18 version (or positive for ''some'' players) -a little too short

I feel like I'd watched a long movie rather than playing a game... But it'd done good and didn't disappoint me.   HIGHLY RECOMMENDED IF YOU'RE NEKO LOVERS EVEN IF YOU DIDN'T COME TO THIS GAME FOR H-SCENE. . . . . . . . . or maybe you did.
I launched this game once and my entire friend list had to bug me about it.
Had been wanting this game for a while, and was lucky enough to have it bought for me for my birthday by my younger brother (not to make this sound more concerning).  After playing the teaser game Vol. 0 I was a little sceptical about the value for money in this instalment- had I paid for it myself at full price I might have been a little disappointed. Waiting for the sales is what you want to go for here.  Don't get me wrong- the game is beautifully made, probably one of the best well put together linear VNs I have played to date, the artwork is gorgeous and the character movement is fluid and natural (Ahem, apart from the balloonified chests of most of the characters). The music is cute and quirky, and the reading speeds for autoplay can be tweaked and saved for a relaxing smooth experience. 10/10 for aesthetics on this game.  Now for my criticisms, (Or more positives, depending on what you look for in a game I suppose, who am I to judge?)- the main running story is cute, set in a bakery that is in it's first few weeks of opening... yada yada.... Not much ACTUALLY happens in terms of storyline. It's definitely more of a slice of life thing going on- though a majority of the text in the game is repeated over and over throughout the entire thing. It's all so samey- teary eyed cat girls "Master.... Master....". I enjoyed the final chapter- as this was the only one that seemed to explore different behaviours and emotions from the main characters, all the rest are sadly quite bland.  Secondly, as others have pointed out- the way the relationships between the main characters are explicitly portrayed was a little disheartening. I feel it would have had so much more effect if more had been left to the imagination- Spoiler alert- [spoiler] At one point in the story the catgirls stop being coy and outright express their desire "to have sex with master"	[/spoiler] , it just saps all of the flittery tension that these novels are enjoyable for. I get that this is about fanservice, and that is WHY people are playing the game, but I dunno. Putting it there in black and white takes away the curiosity of what's actually going on.   Another point- leading on from this... The player character explicitly mentions several times that he sees these two AS HIS CHILDREN. It's a little unnerving- i'm no newbie to bizarre ecchi, but even I think this is pushing the boundaries a little. "As pets, no... family. Even lovers" are not words that should be put together like that. This is all made even more cringeworthy from the fact we know the two girls are somewhere around 6 months of age, obviously growing far faster than normal humans- though by the time they are going through their heat they still act relatively innocent as a child would... Each boundary here (Pets/kids/family) has been pushed a little too far out of the comfort zones to create a weird blend of "Um... is it even okay for me to be reading this?" kind of thing.  Final notes: + Great art/ animation/ music + Good set of attainable achievements + Adorable characters with strong personalities - Weak backstory - Weird almost forced relationships - Repetitive  8/10, would Meow again

It's a great survival horror, when you're not being viciously assualted by the Cat Human Hybrid Mutants you're being tormented and emotionally abused by them. This game is hard for new players to get into, it has many advanced mechanics and follows a very emotional, dark and horrific underlying plot.  A recap of my experience with the game: -Moved into a new house to start my business. -Weird things start happening on the first day, two of the boxes in the house begin to move on their own. -Two Cat Human Hybrid Mutants leap out of the boxes when I open them. -Absolutely Terrified. -They feign friendliness after failing their intial suprise attack. -Young possessed girl claiming to be my sister brings more Mutants to my dwelling. -A few days pass without incident. -Out of the blue. my eyes are assualted by their true form. -Saved game and hid under the covers of my bed quivering in fear. -The next day I played and things seem okay. Then I'm assualted during that night by the Mutants. -Alt+F4  If you love Psychological Survival Horror games I completely recommend this game to you. This game is NOT for the faint of heart or easily scared.

It is more than its thematic turbulence that makes NEKOPARA Vol. 1 extraordinary, actually. Excellence abounds at every turn in this open-world role-playing game: excellent exploration, excellent creature design, excellent combat mechanics, excellent character progression. But the moments that linger are those that reveal the deep ache in the world's inhabitants. In one quest, you reunite two lovers, one of which is now a rotting hag, its tongue lasciviously lolling from its mouth. In another, a corpulent spouse-abuser must find a way to love two different lost souls, each of which test the limits of his affection. Don't worry that these vague descriptions spoil important events: they are simple examples of the obstacles every resident faces. On the isles of Neko Paradise and back home with Shigure, there is no joy without parallel sorrow. Every triumph demands a sacrifice. Overall nice cheap porn - 9/11

BUGS/CRASHES: I encountered a bug in this game that causes it to crash if you press SHIFT + TAB while playing it. Haven't found a way to remove the bug but it only triggers if you press those two buttons. Just don't do that and the game works fine. The bug doesn't stop you from getting achievments/cards and other combinations like ALT + TAB(you'll probably need that a lot with this game!) still work.

good game
Nekopara is one of those feel good games (and I'm not just talking about the sex). The plot is very basic, so it's more about the interactions and conversations the main character has with the cat girls. Every moment is an opportunity for the cat girls to act cute, say cute things, and do cute things.  The graphics are beyond par for this type of game, with incredibly beautiful visuals and details, and impressively animated using Live2D. The vast array of gorgeously frilly lolita inspired clothing will make you constantly fawn over how adorable Chocola and Vanilla look. The character voices are also very good. It's a bit on the trope-y side, but it helps tying it all together in a comfortable familiarity. You'll quickly find your favorite character.  Since this is the first volume, a fair bit of the first few chapters deals with setting the stage, and introducing you to the personalities of all the characters. The "plot" doesn't really "pick up" until about half-way through.  One thing I do like about this particular game is the small attention to detail that they've designed. Things like automatically moving the mouse cursor to the center when selecting yes/no for loading/saving. The user interface is intuitive, and the colors are welcoming.  In terms of gameplay, there really is none. It's a non-interactive, visual novel. Don't expect more than that. That's not to say it's a bad thing. It's just to be expected for this kind of game.  If you're thinking about purchasing this game for the sex, you will be disappointed to know that Steam has made the developer completely cut the sexual content. And relatively speaking, that's about 40% of the game! Fortunately, if you google it, you can find an easy to install patch that will restore all the content. So at the very least, buy this game to support the developer!
Greatest vidyar gam of all tim very nice
shut up and take my money

Set in an alternate timeline during the Cold War, the greatest minds of both Russia and Japan combined their knowledge to create a great superweapon in the hopes of destroying western culture. After years of tireless research and 10,000 Gulag prisoners the first catgirls are born. With the catgirls being intergrated into their society western civilizations surrender to their Russian overlords with the promise of an endless supply of catgirls.  The game begins 40 years after these events and now catgirls outnumber the humans with many families owning several catgirls and the majority roaming the streets.You play as Kashou the prototype in a line of Russian bakery robots assinged to a family who own 6 catgirls. Watch him find and lose his humanity as he attempts to manoeuvre the harsh political landscape that is the cat paradise.

First and foremost, this game is strictly 18+ so the rest of the review will assume you are aware of that fact and are ok with it  Nekopara Vol. 1 is a simple Visual Novel where you follow the adventures of kashou and his attempts to make his living running a bakery, but there's a surprise in store for him once he starts unboxing in his new home 2 Catgirls, Chocola and Vanilla   The story itself is good enough, I give it a 3.5/5 character development is poor but it has plenty of humor combine with serious moments  But I'm sure if you're looking to buy this game it's for the 18+ content There is a patch avalible on the internet (I just googled Nekopara 1 patch and it was the first result) It add explicit sexual scenes into the game at certain points, they involve the main character(you) having sex with the 2 mentioned cargirls so if you want to play the game with the patches I suggest playing at night, and always be ready to switch to something more normal, like pornhub  The artwork is pretty nice, a solid 4.5/5 for me, I would of liked something that involved a couple of darker colors as well as the light ones common through the game, but that's just a personal preference  In Summary, if you want something only cost a couple bucks and you can use for fapping then this is a easy choice, though I beg you to keep the volume down at certain parts

Nekopara Vol 1  The Nekopara series is a wonderful series where its a world of humenoid modified catgirls were they are either pets, partners, or companions, some work as emplyees in the stores of there owners, or some are just friends to the owner or the family and or they can become a life partner to there owner.  The story is about a young man who decides to move out of his families house and start a new life and buiness by opening up a baking store, but it turns out that two of his families catgirls snuck in by hiding in some boxes and thats were the story begins. Thats all ill reveal of the story and plot.  The game is written very well full of funny moments and filled with some sad moments never to much of one type of drama they keep it very even and not repetitive I found myself laughing alot from the jokes and i also felt the feels when it was either a sad or seriouse moment.  The artwork in the game was done very well I love how the sprites have so much movement and such expressions within the game including the sound effects and voice over its a very good combination the devs have done with the game.  The music was composed very well it fits the mood of the situation within the game there is alot of songs within the game so it will not get to repetitive while you play the game.  I highly recommend this game if your a fan of anime,neko's,or just visual novel's this is one of the best vn's I have played in a good while I hope you all will enjoy the game as much as I have   ~Bloodwolf

[h1]An actual serious review[/h1] This is the first visual novel purchased I've purchased on steam. The VN itself is very well presented (good VA, music, art). It should be noted that his release is toned down (i.e., H-related content was removed).  [b]What I liked[/b] - Music and Art - Characters are nicely constructed and their VAs are great. - Story was decent. There's not too much exposition which would pull you out of the flow of the story.  [b]What I disliked[/b] - Not a fan of the "imouto" which is almost oppresive with one of the characters. Just not my thing. - Maximum in-game resolution was 1600x900.  [b]Other notes[/b] - I quite enjoyed going through this VN. I'm very tempted to pick up Vol. 2 when it goes on sale.  - Vol. 1 is a passive VN. You just go from one panel to the next with no interaction with the content on-screen. Vol.0 and Vol. 2 are more interactive.  - VA is Japanese only.  - The eroge content has been removed, which requires [b]re-purchasing[/b] the game from the developer at it's true full price to obtain. The steam version is actually half-priced compared to the full-game due to content cuts. Purchase the steam version if you want access to the cards and achievements. Should you wish to have both, there are guides/posts in the community on getting the developer's full version to "patch" the steam version which will get you all game content and all steam content available. Vol. 2 actually has an official content patch that costs extra.

NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a phenomenal game; it's respectively one of the most popular visual novels on Steam. Though the main story-line of the game is fairly average without much action, it still manages to keep the user entranced in the game. What it lacks in action, it makes up for in character development; this resaulting in the adoration of the main characters (Chocola and Vanilla).  I highly recommend NEKOPARA Vol. 1 to anyone interested in visual novels. However, if you've only come for the NSFW content NEKOPARA is rumored to contain, I'm afraid you won't find that here. The Steam version of the NEKOPARA series is the non-NSFW version.  I'd also recommend checking out NEKOPARA Vol. 0 for some insight to the story-line and characters of the game. Although Vol. 1 is entirly playable without having played Vol. 0.

First of All, for those who doesn't know this is "STEAM CENSORED" version, which mean there is no S** Scene in it  On to the Review  The game is pretty straight forward, you don't need to do anything but click through the story (LITERALLY, there is even an auto play feature to save you all the problem of clicking your mouse).  Pros :  The art are pretty nice and smooth, it pretty and will satisfy any otaku,anime, and cat lovers. The story is short but still heart warming.  Cons :  It really doesn't have much difference from other VN games, which is a shame cause it has potential to be a bit more original in the story, and this game has LITERALLY 1 path and 1 ending, there are no choices need to be made during the whole gameplay, you only need to keep clicking and move along with the story, which is a real shame that made this game has no replay value whatsoever, considering the short story of the game itself, and for the price tag, its not really worth buying if your not really into the VN game genre or cat girls  Overall, i think this game is really good (even though considering the cons are longer than the pros) for those who love VN games in general, it has almost has everything you wanted from a VN. The cute and loveable character combined with a heart warming story makes up for it lacks of replay value and choices within the game. as for the price it self, its maybe a litte bit too expensive considering you only have 1 story line to play, but the beauty of the art within the game is pretty much worthwhile, especially for those who love VN games

The year is 20XX. In what would later become known as the 2nd Great Thermonuclear War, Russia and the United States of America, the two great superpowers of the Earth, launched an all out nuclear offensive against each other. The sheer volume of warheards launched was so gigantic, that many of the missles collided over the North Pacific. This caused the atomic fallout to blow over to the neutral ground of Japan. The pollution reacted with the double X chromosomes in Japanese females, causing over 60% of the population to mutate into catlike hybrids.  In this fast paced first person shooter, you play as a special black ops soldier who is a member of the strike force known as NEKOPARA, callsign "Master". His mission: to eradicate the catgirl abominations with extreme prejudice.  The game incorporates a new morality system of choosing to spare or kill various catgirls you meet during the story. Spare earns their trust, but killing them seperates you furthur from your humanity, allowing you to take more damage in battle.  The choice is yours, decide the destiny.

A short kenetic visual novel. Overall it is not a bad game.  Why not recommended then? Simply because there is really only one single reason to play this game. That being to look at very nicely drawn pictures of catgirls. Apart from that there is really nothing here. So if that is something you would enjoy, by all means go ahead and play. If you are wanting something a little more substantial in terms of content though, there is really nothing here.  The story plays out sort of like a 4-koma. In that there are chapters, but these are further divided into several short vignettes. It is basically a slice-of-life story about a man opening a bakery and training two catgirl staff. In a relationship that later becomes sexual in nature. And yes even this Steam version makes certain you know you are missing sex scenes, they just show the before and after.  I think if this game were a comedy, it would have turned out really great. The style would have fit a comedy really well. But this is unfortunately not a comedy. For such a rediculous background story and world, the game is remarkably terse and serious in tone. There is some situational stuff and jokes, but nothing consistant enough to make the reader have fun. In that sense taking this solely as a story, it is fairly generic and boring. It is just cute girls doing cute things, that personally isn't really enough to carry it.  The main saving grace is that it is short. If it were longer than the 2-4 hours it is, it would have outstayed its welcome being as simple as it is. That said the value for money at $10 seems a little lacking because of that. Vol. 2 really will have to do something to change up the situation a little. Unfortunately I expect it will be more of the same, just more catgirls in the shop.
I'm going to admit that I am probably not very qualified to review this title. But I'm going to give it a go anyway. The reason I don't feel qualified is that I didn't understand what the tag "visual novel" meant. I didn't realize that there was no actual gameplay. I thought it was some kind of little cafe-shop-simulator or something. So we'll set aside the head-scratching and slow-realization that dawned over me as I began to understand what I had purchased.  However, I like to get my money's worth, so I did click through the story to see what a visual novel was like. It isn't terrible, but it's also far from interesting. It's cute, I suppose, but even as an avid fan of anime, I wasn't impressed with the narrative at all.
the entirety of human history and technological advances has lead us to this game, the culmination of the human experience: anime catgirls with exaggerated breast physics. god has truly blessed us- the great pyramids are nothing when compared to nekopara.
My overall rating for NEKOPARA Vol. 1: 80/100  This is a game, that does not have to be taken seriously. Or has to? This visual novel is a lovely, relaxing game, where you can find both amusement, but also deep ideas about love, friendship, loyalty and things, that accompany us in our lives. Let's see this in detail  GAMEPLAY  + Decent animations + Format + Chapter selection o Some anime clichés   I absolutely love playing this game. It is true, that I picked it as some not-so-serious game, but I was pleasantly surprised. The story is simple - the hero, Kaishou Minaduki, is opening a bakery and his two most loyal catgirls are coming to join him.  The Visual Novel format suits this game well, you are progressing through chapters and revealing the destiny of not only Kaishou and his two Catgirls - Chocola and Vanilla, but also support from his sister Shigure and the rest of Minaduki's family Catgirls - Azuki, Cinnamon, Coconut and Maple. Present times are switching with memories in the right time, so the player will not get bored.  Also setting of Catgirls role in society was interesting, many procedures are similar to our in our lives (getting of personal identification card is a metaphore to Bell exam etc.).  Only what bothered me, were some anime clichés, like to much boob shaking (I know this will bring negative points for this review :-D ), but besied that, I liked, how this novel was able to change from completely funny, to very serious and vice versa.  CHARACTERS  + Chocolla + Vanilla + Kaishou + Shigure + Steam cards, backgrounds, emoticons o Azuki, Cinnamon, Coconut, Maple  Also characters shown a variety of personalities. Kaishou is on a big crossroad of his life, full of both hopes and worries. Chocolla is a typical extrovertial person, on the opposite, Vanilla is an introvert. All of this characters are transforming, they are becoming more responsible, feeling how it is to be in love and get closer to someone.  Setting of characters is brilliant, both Chocolla and Vanilla are at the age of the first love, filled with innocence and romantic dreams. Many things are shown metaphorically, but they suit their needs.  Shigure is also important, as a younger sister she looks up to Kaishou, but also gives him important advices. The rest of Minaduki's Catgirls were just an addition, game could be also good without them, but they were not something disturbing.  Also extras as Steam Cards, backgrounds and emoticons are nice and lovely, one of few games with that accesories.  SOUNDTRACK  + Lovely according to the atmosphere + Music player + Interjections  I liked the soundtrack, it was suited for not only funny and smiling moments, but also for serious times and thoughts. Very satisfying, also as the presence of music, movie player and gallery of most conmemorable moments.  Onomatopoeia is a very important part of Japanese games and here it was used perfectly. I did not know, that so many sounds and activities can be pictured in this way!  VISUALS  + Perfect, lovely  There is nothing to complain here about, everything was right as it should be. Animy style is a bit close to Shoujo manga, but it is not overfilled with sweetness. Just several clichés, mentioned above.  SUMMARY  NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a game that should get its chance to be played. I have to say, that you need a specific mood for playing, and when you have it, the story will catch you to the very end (I finished it in two days :-D ).   I think this game should deserve a higher score, but it is suitable mostly for genre fans and most player out of it, can see this game as childish and disturbing. That is why I have chosen this evaluation.  Anyway, it is perfect and worth to try. Catgirls paradise!  PS: There is a mature version, but I have not tried it. If you would, I will not stop you, but I do not think it is necessary to spoil the nice metaphores of the game. I leave it up to you.

nosebleed
My friend got it me for me....
Let's do a review without all the jokes here, hm? Nekopara is a fantastic visual novel, both in appearance, and in features. With Steam starting to take a shine to allowing Visual Novels, we're getting a lot of them recently, and it's hard to know what to look for. In Nekopara's case, it's lighthearted fun, certainly a bit perverse, but never takes itself too seriously or goes into an awkward zone that makes you feel uncomfortable.  Sure it's catgirls, but this series knows it's not to be taken seriously, and it knows it's very heavily anime styled, and they don't hold back. There are moments characters get chibi styled, the eyes show silly, emote style expressions, and they really feel very fresh, lively, and amusing all at once.  Characters as shown in the vids feel alive, as they are always moving a bit along the screen. Whether it's their eyes trailing from one side to another or pupils shrinking, it's them bouncing about and getting active, changing perspective, ears perking or drooping, or even the 'chest bounce' or so, the characters are very smoothly done. It doesn't change from panel to panel and sprite to sprite, instead it's animated, and it really feels like they're a bit more lively than your normal visual novel.  As for settings, there are some fantastic touches that make this game so easy to manage. The usual quicksave and quickload is there, but you can add 'notes' to these and your regular saves to really know exactly where you left off. The sliders allow text speed for normal and auto, window transparency, even individual voice volumes per character, music volume, sfx, and just voice in general, really giving you a lot of ways to adjust it and make yourself comfortable with the game.  The english translation is fantastically done, and the series is presented in 'chapters' with even a fantastic intro after chapter 1 that made it feel like a legit anime. Each character is very different, and while it seems to focus a bit more on two in particular, every character gets a lot of love and spotlight.  Overall, I've always been a huge fan of visual novels, from the really deep stories, to sometimes a fun and lighthearted one, and sometimes a few are forgotten or just aren't worth completeing. Nekopara though is not one that will fade away from my mind any time soon, and is worth the playthrough. Great sound, fantastic voicing, beautiful animation, user friendly, and just silly, fun, and adorable ride worth taking.
Exceptionally great plot

Yes, there is an R-18 patch. No, you're not really missing out on too much if you don't patch your game. It's pretty obvious what's going on and, if you *really* want to see, that's what Tumblr is for. The only reason I didn't patch is because, frankly, I'm lazy.  Story wise, it's very cute and does a good job of establishing characters and scenes before diving into sexy tropes. The art is simply beautiful to look at and all the animations are very smooth. Music and voice acting are also lovely to listen to. Even though their cat girls, they're never THOSE kind of cat girls, if you know what I mean.   Characters are very cute and there is some solid humor in the game too. The only downside is that the story does leave some strange implications that make you want to take a long shower to scrub away the shame though.   While I do wish that Steam had left the R-18 version intact (especially when you have to be over 18 to view the store page), it's really not needed for this title. It's just as enjoyable and explicit without it.

If you're one of the people who found the "funny" reviews regarding this game less than helpful, here's a review that covers actual game play:  Totally and utterly adorable. Definitely worth a play if you're into anime of any genre. I know most of the reviews only mention how sexy and suggestive the game is, but it's unfair to ignore the other factors that make this game shine. Nekopara Vol. 1 is also...  Cute. Insanely cute. Funny. Quirky. Tear-jerkingly sweet at times.  The artwork is beautiful and the translation is, for the most part, very good. As you've likely read around, this was originally a hentai game. That being said, the game is very, very short (I finished it in a little over 4 hours, but that's only because I took my time and wandered away from my PC at times). Calling Nekopara a game is a stretch, however: it's a visual novel through and through. You click, you read, you enjoy the story presented to you. Plain and simple. But that isn't to say it isn't worth a look--especially if you can get a deal for it. I'm happy to say I played through this from start to finish and enjoyed it in it's entirety.

tl;dr: 5/10. It's all right. Mostly just cute stuff and a lot of nothing happening.  [h1]Full review:[/h1]  Upon release, I heard Nekopara had become a cringeworthy, BnP-tier meme and unfunny Youtubers were doing let's plays and reaction videos and whatever other garbage that pre-teens love to slurp up. I quickly forgot about this, along with the game, until I saw it on sale once and decided "why not?".  First off, the story. It's certainly existent, but that's about it. Other than NotShirou preaching MUH MORALS at people who really don't want to give him the time of day, the story literally goes nowhere. It's quite honestly on the level of porn without plot VNs, and although the story isn't supposed to be the selling point, the game is strictly a visual novel, so it's worth a mention.   Contrary to this, the technical points were more or less up to scratch, the worst of it being no lower than "subpar". There are a good number of CGs, sprites and backgrounds despite the game taking the better part of 2 hours to finish, and the soundtrack, although nothing really to write home about, doesn't subtract from the overall enjoyment of the game.   Another feature I liked was not the chest bounciness slider (though that was a welcome addition), but the option to play in Japanese. Although this translation isn't as bad as some of Sekai Project's other releases - being barely up to scratch this time - I felt like I got a lot more out of what little story there was once I switched over.  Overall, it's cute girls doing cute things with H-scenes you can patch in. I wouldn't buy it at $10 considering the amount of content, but if this is what you're after, then it wouldn't be a terrible buy if it were on sale. [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/blankaex/recommended/385800/]On the other hand, Nekopara Vol. 0 is an entirely different story.[/url]

This is a horrifying tour de force.  In the grim near future, mankind has genetically modified cats into humanoid "catgirls." This in itself raises MANY to question the ethics of the world at large if this were to pass: but it gets darker. They don't have the brainpower of a human, they are essentially children with some cat instincts as far as their minds go. So: without an owner they cannot sustain themselves in human society, and they are not physically equipt to survive in the wild like feral cats do. Not that they could sustain themselves even if they could function in either light because the rabbit hole goes deeper yet. At the time of writing this i have not finished the game but there is no mention of a male counterpart: the species is "catGIRL", they are incapable of (to put it delicately) unassisted procreation. They also go through life with all the biological failings of a cat (going into heat, GREATLY accelerated aging).  In his arrogance man hath birthed a lifeform incapable of anything but being a pet at best and a stray beggar at worst: and that must be (again, delicately put) assisted to perpetuate their species. A race of humanoids too human to survive as an autonomous community or being in the wild, yet too animal and simple minded to go through life in human society fluently.  And perhaps the worst part is that they lack the faculties for the deeper thought on these issues to even realise their horrifying place in the world at large.   If I had to rate it on a number scale, I'd give it a "SCIENCEHASGONETOOFAR" out of Ten it really makes you think

All the perverted jokes and silly reviews aside, Nekopara Vol. 1 is actually a very cute/funny read. If you're not super uptight and don't have some vendetta against cliches, it's worth the few hours you'll spend read-watching it, even if you go with steam's prudish version (BOOBS BAD GORE GOOD, right Steam?). I certainly laughed far more than I was expecting to.  Cons: Short-lived story VN, (non-skipping readers will get a good handful of hours out of it atleast), not enough entries in the series. Hopefully it becomes a long running VN series.  Pros: Very soothing soundtrack, with built in music player extras for your listening pleasure. Goofy cliches everywhere, pretty much guaranteed laughs for all but the most uptight/boring/sheltered of minds.  All in all, anyone who likes romance and CATGIRLS!!! . . . ahem, anyone who likes romance, catgirls, goofy cliches, 3rd-person speaking, and general sillyness, will definitely enjoy this. Having completed NEKOPARA Vol. 1, I ask myself three questions: 1. What is the purpose of a visual novel game? 2. Are visual novel games for me? 3. What the flying fuck am I doing with my life?  Playing a visual novel is essentially reading a book with beautifully drawn and animated pictures but with voices to offer that extra bit of immersion. Nekopara is a story about leaving home, running a patisserie and looking after catgirls (I was  especially interested in Nekopara because of my unnatural weakness to animal girls.) What I did find especially interesting is that if you were to collate all the information you find out about catgirls in the world, and try to understand it, it doesn't make too much sense, let alone give a reason for the existence of these scientific 'abominations'.  On the other hand, they're SO CUTE, and I totally want one. Nekopara does a good job of telling a rather sweet story (or erotic story, if you buy the uncensored version) that is in actuality quite mediocre as I can summarise it in about two sentences.  The 'player', if you can call them that, is told the story from their perspective, which is as far as the game goes to involve you. Honestly, I was a bit bored, having just finished 'Hotline Miami' before playing Nekopara I felt a bit psychotic and was surprised to find myself a little disappointed that I didn't get to kill anything in the visual novel (anybody else feel like that after playing video games - perhaps you can recommend a good psychiatrist?) For people who need a dose of "kawaii", who are too restless to watch anime and too lazy to play a 'proper' game.  Ending on a positive note, you can speed run the game, with only one hand, in about 5 minutes or 20 minutes for the uncensored version ;)
To my dearest friend who wondered if the catgirls say "nya" during HHHeHeHe-scenes,  Yes, they do.

You get this game gifted and cannot decline (like in my case)   Now, im not gonna lie, this game is all about... Catgirls! Surprising, right? Long story short:  Its a Visual Novel about a character (you) moving away from his family to open his own bakery and get things done.  Unfortunately (unfortunately?) 2 old acquaintances of you get "delivered" to you. Chocolate & Vanilla, 2 very charming Catgirls.  Unfortunately (unfortunately?) you can't get rid of them so you have to live with them together in your flat.  Thats the start of this incredible journey.   The visuals are top notch, the dialog is acceptable and the fan service is great. not fluffy enough
OK let's get the first thing out of the way: this is a kinetic novel, as in a visual novel with absolutely no choices. The characters are very well animated and the voice acting in Japanese is fantastic, at the level of "real" anime. The catgirl characters are very, very cute. The story lasts somewhere between 4.5 and 5 hours if you have it on auto-play. On the basis of these things I do recommend it.  There are some negative points though. A small negative point is a small number of mistakes in the text of the game: an apostrophe that shouldn't have been there, a word that doesn't exist and some awkward phrasing. The story is a bit rambling and oddly-paced in places and I felt like a "real" anime would have probably been paced better. This brings me to another point: I did enjoy this but a real anime would probably have been better with more varied animation and so on. I felt maybe I only enjoyed this so much because I haven't watched a real anime for a while.  In terms of adult content: most of the game is just cute: there's almost zero fan-service but there are one or two pretty adult things in the text (not in the pictures).  Anyway that's it. Please stop reading now because I want to moan about something in the plot but it is possibly spoilery and since the story is the whole thing with this, you don't want to know it ahead of time:  SPOILERY BITS UNTIL THE END    SPOILERY BITS YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED   Ok, so I'm really not some tumblr kind of "feminist" or anything, and I hate that sort of person who goes around being "offended" and "triggered" by everything but really there are some pretty "off" things in this story. You have this whole category of women: catgirls who basically resemble women except for having tails, ears and certain feline behaviour traits, but apart from that they are women. These women are "owned" by "masters" as pets (but basically slaves, I suppose). They are utterly subservient, pathetically eager to please and very naive about the world and have to be told everything. They are used for work and for sex; If they go out on the street without displaying their bell that proves they passed an exam where they have to suppress their true nature, they get arrested. This is not just like the normal "harem" type of anime like Tenchi Muyo, Oh My Goddess or Love Hina: it really is a step beyond that in the treatment of its female characters. Anyway, I'm not really complaining about it or being offended, it's just something I didn't like about the anime.  Apart from that you have the main character saying some line about being a bit confused about seeing his two catgirls as both daughters and lovers which was a bit creepy; the drawing of them both in bed with him they really are drawn as underage; then there's the incestuous masturbation of one catgirl on the other (they are supposed to be twins), and the incestuous love the main character's sister has for him.  I'm just saying really that despite enjoying the story I was creeped out by a few of the lines in it
Catgirls that love you unconditionally... both as pets and as women.  10/10 would meow again.  P.S. get the 18+ version elsewhere also if you can.

Honestly, this game is way over-rated. There's practically no conflict in the story, and what little exists is solved within a few slides of being created. There are *literally* no choices to make so that kills replayability.  Basically, you're this guy opening a bakery and everything just seems to go your way and everyone seems to love you for no appearent reason. The "love" everyone has for you doesn't feel remotely real and feels incredibly forced. As for the sex scenes, this is the pg edited version that has awkward jump-cuts jutted in there jumping straight to the aftermath when they're asleep and under the covers.  However, I will say if you're looking for a feel-good, happy-go-lucky, cutsie story, then this is for you.  Overall, I'd give this game a C+. It's a passing grade, but it's not all that great.  P.S. If you're looking for fap material, you can put the tissues away, because there isn't any. This had very little effect on my rating, because, tbh, I dislike visual novels that randomly throw in an extremely graphic sex scene here and there, making it risky to play with someone else in the room.

Ok first thing you're a guy named "Kashou" who moved out of his family home to open up his very own pastry shop called "Passitre La Soliel". After he moved boxes out from the truck, he noticed 2 boxes were heavier than others. He checked it out, it was Chocola & Vanilla, family catgirls. From there, the story starts with three of them on a way to become the most popular pastry shop in the district.  The story is straightforward with no multiple choice options of getting through different endings unlike common VN.  Its blant. You cant choose the way it ends since it only has one ending. NEKOWORKS overcome this lack by producing a very beautiful art and outstanding voice-acting. 6 catgirls with 6 cute voice-acters. [h1]A lighthearted story... with catgirls.[/h1]  A Visual Novel about a man, his bakery shop, and his catgirls. The story's light and fluffy,  great to read for a few evenings. It's music suits the game's light tone and should not  annoy throughout the gameplay. While sadly there are no choices for the player to make, I assure you that there wouldn't be a reason to. The Visual Novel's elements are modernly made, and makes enjoying the game an easy task. Character sprites are animated in a modern way, which I was strongly impressed by.   [b]-Pros-[/b] [list][*] A happy 'fluffy' story, perfect for a strained heart from all those Evangelions and Madokas... [*]Visual Novel elements are modernised which makes the reading all the more fun. [*]Lovable characters. Cheerful and fun-happy catgirls, must I say more? [/list] [b]-Cons-[/b] [list] [*] Veteran novel readers may find the length of the story rather short. [*] The sexual hints between characters may put off people,  who are strictly there to enjoy daily lives of characters. [*] The story's simplicity may also turn-off those who enjoy a rich, deep story  as there are not even a single choice to be made by the player. [/list] In overall - Nekopara is a pleasant experience. If you're up for some relaxation  accompanied by two lovely catgirls, I 100% recommend this game to you.
played the whole game, dissapointed that there was no incest.
I wanted to like this game.  But the more I played it, the less I liked it.  The story just didn't appeal much to me as it developed.  The ethics of this society where catgirls are pets despite having basic human intelligence is perplexing, and people having romantic and sexual relationships with them draws further question.  Plus, how do the catgirls reproduce if they're all female and cannot procreate with humans?  Lastly, little sister characters in love with their older brothers is a character archetype that really bugs me.  Story is the basis of a visual novel, and this story did not work for me due to the reasons listed above.  I know I won't make a dent against this game's great reputation, nor will I convince anyone not to buy it, but I feel it necessary to voice my opinion as to why I really didn't enjoy this game.

I liked it. Pretty good storyline. Very linear and mostly predictable, but spruced up with enough humour and ‘oh my god lol’ moments that make it enjoyable. Perhaps, a bit to my surprise, but... This game turned out to be quite good.   The story itself, while simple, is enjoyable. It's silly, it's fun, it's told well, and it does the job.  More unexpectedly, though has been just how well the unvierse has been set up. From quite early on, we know how this game's interpretation of catgirls operates, their limitations, how the world they live in interacts with them, and how they integrate into society. The biggest surprise has been, though, that there have been a number of hints of some particularly dark undertones to things going on within the world of this game, many dealing with the consequences of human actions.   I'm looking forward to more, whenever that happens to drop.   P.S. Vanilla is best catgirl n_n

Well, playing through this Visual Novel was a breath of fresh air for me, and I did quite enjoy reading through the story.  Aside from that, the novel had some good and bad points in my opinion that need to be noted.  Do note that this is my opinion and to respect my opinion on this game.  Why do I like the game?  1. The Story is interesting, and different that one you would not expect from the Visual Novel genre. 2. The characters are very interesting, and each character plays off one another in interesting and humorous ways. 3. The E-mote system in the Novel is a wonderful addition to Visual Novels.  (Characters can move, seen talking, sway, jump, all sorts of stuff.) 4. The art style is amazing.  What am I neutral about in the game?  1. The Jiggle Physics slider.  Don't really care much about it.  It goes from unresponsive to Armegeddon level movement for anyone and everyone.  I just left it neutral for a more realistic experience. 2. The Earthquake Button... 3.  No dialouge choices... as long as the story is entertaining and fun. 4. Shigure... 5. The English sub could be written better.  I have seen a good share of bad grammar and misspellings in the game.  What do I dislike about the game?  1. The story is interesting, but It really isn't that deep of a story.  I know It's the first volume, so It can be different later on.  but that was a bit offputting when I finished the game. 2. Extreme lack of other minor male characters.  This made me feel like I was in a world losing a lot of it's men.  The only other male we know the existance of is Kashou's and Shigure's father. (I do hope the story includes their parent's in a future volume for a much better story.) 3.  Extreme lack of other character portraits in general.  The only other character that got a portrait was another catgirl you see early on in the story. 4. The Catgirl lifespan.  This was quite annoying that they could read and write in under a year after birth, this making them smarter than humans in that regard, and growing to human size much faster than a human was creepy.  Besides, they are a mix of the 2 species, A lifespan of 35-50 years would be more fitting for them, instead of a cat's 20-33 year lifespan.  (Maple is only 2 years old as said in her trailer for the game.)  Other than that, It still is worth the buy for all the shenanigains that go on in the game, the characters, and the story.

In other words, the writing is as good as in porn movies.  The +18 version offers additional nude scenes. Like so many others, I had gotten this game expecting nothing more than an easy fap to nekos. That was seriously the ONLY expectation I even had coming in to the game was sexy catgirls. First thing I did, before I even opened it, was download the uncensored patch from online. Then I actually started playing...  See, the game (story really, there aren't any options) met my very basic expectations, and added substantially. It really made me a PART of the story, I really felt a connection with Chocola and Vanilla! I didn't think of them as the catgirls, I thought of them as MY catgirls. I know that's a looser thing to say, but I mean it.  The story is very touching, happy, and bubbly, and is told with EXCELLENT art and animation. Seriously, they characters were always moving (except in the rare, beautifully made still images), and that little element really added to the story.  Overall, this game was far more than anything I had expected.  I highly recommend it to anyone who likes nekos, and to be perfectly honest you can enjoy it very much even without the uncensored version; the story is DEFINATELY sound enough on it's own.  And as a bonus, there is definately going to be a Vol 2, based on the ending of this and the success of Vol 1.

Loved This Hoping for Vol.2 :D 10/10
NEKOPARA Vol. 1 is a VN where there are no choices to make. It uses the E-mote 2D animation engine, which allows characters to show a variety of emotions, and adds some physics effects to the characters. Parts of the game are missing from the Steam version, and can be obtained elsewhere.  Story: This story is about the protagonist, Kashou Minaduki, moving away from home to open a bakery. Two of his family's Catgirls, Chocola and Vanilla, decide to follow him there and help him with his work. Kashou, with the help of his sister and the other four catgirls of his family, learns how to take care of Chocola and Vanilla, while managing his bakery. The story is a "slice of life" story and is too clichéd since many elements can be found in VNs, Anime and Manga. The universe/setting of this story seems a bit dark; I still wonder how catgirls came into existence, why some are criminals and some are abandoned on the streets without a owner. There are a lot more questions I have about the universe/setting. Overall, I would rate the story 6/10.  Characters: The personalities of the characters are very clichéd. There is some character development for the main characters. It is really awkward how you only encounter one male character, the protagonist, in the story if I am not mistaken. All other characters, including the police officer, customers, etc., you encounter are all female. Overall, I would rate the characters 6/10.  Music: The music is great. Nice catchy songs, and even has an opening and ending song. Don't have anything to complain about for the voice acting and sound effects, except that there are only Japanese voices. I would rate the music 9/10.  Artwork: The artwork is amazing. Really good animations and physics effects for a VN. Some scenes are reused too much. Overall, I would rate the artwork 9/10.   Overall: I would rate this game 7.5/10. I do like happy endings, the artwork, the physics effects and animations. The story and characters are lacking, and I would not recommend buying this game just for the story; although I do not know why anyone would buy it for that.
[h1][b]Score: 6/10[/b][/h1] as a VN +1 if you like anime +1 if you like cat girls +2 if you are into hentai  [b]Similar Games[/b] Tokyo School Life  [b]Summary[/b] The main character has moved away from home and is opening up a bakery. He finds the two cat girls hiding in one of the moving boxes. The game provides a history on why cat girls exist which is nice. Chocola is obviously in love with the main character and Vanilla follows Chocola in everything she does.  [b]Positive[/b] The art style in these games is pretty much as good as it gets for a VN. The facial expressions and animations are all but flawless. The humor parts a great, but don't occur often enough. Strangely the romance comes off as totally normal for the world that it takes place in.  [b]Negative[/b] Well at the end of the day this is still a Hentai game with the Hentai removed so it could be put on steam. Thus the main character ends up sleeping with both Chocola and Vanilla giving you no date sim type options. Although back story is given for why this must take place it still feels very wierd. Wierder still is the fact you have a younger sister that must be the devil because it appears she set it all up for you to get hanky panky with them. The game seems to cover every type of anime fetish known to man and instead of giving you date sim options just has the main character sleep with everybody... which may in later volumes include his own sister.  [b]Conclusion[/b] This game is a strange creature. Somehow a hentai game without the hentai is proving to be a better product even for those with no hentai interest. Maybe this type of title will set a higher bar for the future of VN's on Steam.  [b]Value[/b] Honestly it's probably worth close to the asking price even if your just a VN fan. If you like cute anime girls it's worth full price. If your a cat girl fan it's worth more. If you want hentai go buy the non steam version where it isn't removed.
If you're looking to read a cutesy slice-of-life story then you'll probably like this.  Otherwise, if you're looking to actually play a game with a compelling story this is not worth your time. There are no choices to be made and no interactivity whatsoever. It wouldn't be so bad if the story were interesting and compelling but it's really not. Just some lighthearted cutesy stuff with no genuine conflict anywhere in sight and characters who are one dimensional.  The nudity tag is also a lie, in case you buy this game hoping for that. You'd have to go dig up the 18+ patch for the actual mature bits as they've all been cut out.

This game has a good length, but it's deceptively empty. For all the claims of a 'great' story, it's mostly fanservice and build-up. Vol. 1 is an apt part of the title because it definitely doesn't feel complete. I think after finishing the storyline you're definitely going to be crying out, "BUT WHERE'S THE REST OF IT?", but that alone should tell you it's a pretty good game. I'm disappointed that the story didn't develop as much as I hoped it would, but I can't argue that I was delighted the whole time I was playing due to the colorful characters and the question of where everything was leading (although unsatisfactorily answered). As part of a series this is a great start, but woefully inadequate (especially compared to fantastic FREE novels like Katawa Shoujo) as a standalone VN.   But catgirls are fucking cute so 10/10.

I have no words bad to say about this game. None at all.
The game and story was great. Light and Bubbly... the only thing I found that was kinda uneeded rather ironically for a H-Visual Novel was the actual Hentai Scenes themselves. It seemed kinda forced onto a story that would've been fine without it, especially considering that they come so suddenly and out of nowhere that it actually slowed the story down in my opinion. (no pun intended) I guess due to this being Sayori's work however some hentai had to be somewhere.   Basically if you purchase this game to only reap the H-scenes... I'd suggest going to Google. You wont miss much at all. However if you want a light-hearted story with excellent artwork, music and satisfactory characters... you wont go far wrong with purchasing Nekopara.

My pants flew off.
Kinetic VN are getting more and more amazing. This one is more like playing an anime than most.  If you like anime this is the game for you. It's colourful, lovely and surprisingly story rich albeit a bit brief.  You play Kashou the most alpha male super baker in all of Japan and live in a world where some god among men scientists have created geneticly engineered cat girls. Where all of them even your underage sister is magneticly attracted to you.  These cat girls are like real girls but better in everyway. They're cute, submissive, have the IQ of a primary school girl, cute and despite being barely a step above real house cats are perfectly being happy being locked up in a home or use at a non breeding slave. Sounds like heaven right?  The cakes you make as a baker give girls orgasms and your family is so rich buying and opening a bakery in your name by yourself is chump change.  These cat girls which cost obviously more money than actual cats in food, hair care and clothing that your middle school sister owns 6 of them. Many of which are only 1-4 years old and have the fully devellopped bodies of girls in their teens and late teens.  You (Kashou) and your 9 month old 14-15 year old bodied cat girls in skimpy outfits run La Soileil, A bad french grammar bakery where you exploit your cat girls Chocola and Vanilla to dance around cutely and sell cups of sugar to suckers for insane prices.   Chocola is a low IQ brunette with bigger emotional ups and downs than an amusement park ride and Vanilla a stone faced albino.      Ok Joking aside it's a damn good VN and has alot to give. No choices in dialog and it's just an anime with no male VAs when set to autoplay. This version has no sex scenes in it and 100% honest to god truth, doesn't even need any. I'm serious, this could stand alone as just a story about cute girls with some lewd-ish moments. The characters are well voiced and it's an interesting world to catch a glimpse of.  The art is spectacular to watch and having it animated in a kinetic VN is better than nearly all before it. This isn't a new concept but it's nice and about damn time stuff like this comes to the west.

First of all, in case you might not know yet, the Steam version of Nekopara is censored. If you're looking for erotic pictures of catgirls, this is not where you'll find them. If, however, you are looking for a heartwarming story backed up by charming characters and stunning graphics, then this game is perfect for you.  	Nekopara's story is simple and straightforward, with no multiple choices or endings. If you thought you'd have to choose between one of the 2 main catgirls, Chocola and Vanilla, don't worry: You get 2 for the price of comparing every real life girl you ever fall in love with to cats for the rest of your life.  	The lack of any kind of player input doesn't, however, detract from the story. What could have been just about any kind of tale with girls who inexplicably have cat ears and tails, instead turned out to be a well-crafted narrative that will leave you craving for more. The fact that the catgirls display a significant variety of real cat behavior, instead of just acting cute for the sake of acting cute, should by itself speak volumes about how much went into making the story the best it could be.  	Alongside the well written story are a gorgeously adorable art style and great voice acting, all of which come together to make lovable, talking, moving and breathing characters with varied personalities, emotions, likes and dislikes, to which its incredibly easy to get genuinelly emotionally attached. That said, Chocola is my immaculate little angel, and all filthy perverts who dare lay a finger on her shall be publicly castrated*. >:v  	If you REALLY must have the censored scenes in your game, you can obtain the uncensored version by other means, such as the official Nekopara website. If you have both steam and original versions, you can even patch the original scenes into the steam version... ... ... I won't judge you... ... ... [strike]I will judge you immensely[/strike]*. It's difficult to write a review of such an overwhelmingly positive game, since being fair is relevant hard enough, meow.  The key feature of the game is "very cute", cute enough to dissolve your heart with eye-candies like Chocola and Vanilla.  It made me wish to have a catgirl accomplishes my daily task in Japan. Meow? How come? And yet, it's definitely a common feeling from a lot of us.  Other than that, I am not very sure how to comment it as a visual novel. The length of the story is fairly short { about 8 hours for average gameplay, and I guess we are dying for more }, the story itself is not very...memorable: it's a boy leaves his home for the 1st time trying to make a living by opening a bakery shop himself along with 2 catgirls by his side.   However, with 50% off, I believe it is a no-mistaken strawberry cake that is worth grabbing even just for purely leisure. It's Sayori's original characters stepping onto the visual novel stage! The artwork and production values are as high as expected. The novel uses the e-mote system which allows for animations with full CG quality. The story itself is somewhat simplistic but fairly adorable. If you're looking for branching paths or any form of gameplay, though, there are none. It's a few hours of story and considering it's one of the very few high quality from-Japan VNs on Steam right now, it's well worth the $10, IMO.   It needs to be noted that there are two versions of this VN, though. The Steam version is the all-ages version with the sex scenes cut out. The 18+ version is only available from DLsite but it costs twice as much so there is a trade-off. If you want more info about the 18+ version, you can probably find it on the Community Hub.

Nekopara: A Japanese Visual Novel (VN) which explores the intimate relations between catgirls and humans and the complex interworking’s of pimping Nekos in a free market  economy during a recession. The story delves into Kashou’s (main character) recent life experiences; a self-absorbed baker who is struggling to reclaim his independence while soaking up the love and affection from Nekos that pine for his attention. Struggling to gets his business going, Kashou must also navigate through the complex nature involved with raising and understanding two needy catgirls that fight for his attention, all while coming to terms with the fact that he finds his neko “daughters” sexually attractive. When the endless flirting no longer “cuts it” for the master of Chocola and Vanilla (Nekos), he pursues a more intimate relationship with the catgirls. Despite the increasing acceptance of “catpanions” in Japan, Kashou (your character), struggles to accept his fetishes and publicly acknowledge his relations with this sex crazed kitten girls. This 7-9 hour game leads up to a fun filled day at an amusement park and a night full of scandalous, pleasure driven, raunchy, boner popping, cream filled sex leaving Kashou feeling emptied, tired, slightly dizzy, and running a mild fever. This of course sends your Nekos into a full tilt panic driven meltdown culminating in a mild conflict with an incompetent rent-a-cop guarding the outside of a random pharmacy where they girls sought medicine for Kashou’s weak ass immune system. After drinking some Nightquil and a day of rest, Kashou awakens to find that all 5 nekos and his incest driven baby sister all dressed up as maids willing to exploit themselves for Koashou’s profit. If you’re into prostitution, incest, Nekos, and a fair amount of kwai, than this game is for you.   Pros: •	Voice acting is decent •	Coconut and Maple are actually proportionate and good looking •	The art is pretty solid, decent gameplay length •	Neko Kitties/titties  Cons: •	Gameplay length  •	Incest •	Gender exploitation •	Prostitution  •	Predictable outcomes/situations and dialog
