Nyan.  Cats and breasts.  If you're not into that, there's an actual story. Like, it's not a "Do I say 'YO!' or 'Hello, nice to meet you.' kind of visual novel. It's what a visual novel should be by looking at the words "Visual" and "Novel". As in, a novel with visual aids to help in the immersion and overall feeling of the story. It's pretty fun if you see it like that. And just like any good book, it'll borrow 3-7 hours of your time that won't be regretted.  Do I want more people to buy this VN?  Yes. This 'game', in the very strictest sense, is a Visual Novel, the story is completely linear and there are no choices for different paths, having said that, I'm not sure I'd want to spend the time do multiple paths either. short, but entertaining very easy to get all achievements.
Nekopara is a high quality kinetic novel (meaning no interactions, only reading) featuring catgirls and adult themes, although the Steam version is censored unless you apply some shenanigans to it (refer to this Community Hub link: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=370848130). The voice acting is in Japanese with subs for Japanese, English, and Chinese.  The art is extremely well done and fairly crisp. I played in a 1600x900 resolution which appears to be as high as it goes. Fullscreen will give it black borders as the game will maintain its aspect ratio to prevent stretched catgirls (very important). The level of quality that Nekopara has in terms of its art assets remains consistent throughout the entire experience with good coloring, shadowing, and light animations to help give the characters life such as head turning, blinking, breathing, and breast jiggling depend on how you use that slider.  I have no complaints with the music. It has tunes ranging from upbeat to laidback and brought me closer to my inner anime. The game comes with a music player that can Play, Stop Repeat, and Repeat All should you decide to just chill out. The opening song is pretty good.  Finally, the story seemed appropriate for what it was trying to do. It had its fair share of funny and “What is going on?” moments. The story follows Kashou and how he handles the two catgirls, Chocola and Vanilla, coming into his life when he’s trying establish himself in the world as a baker. I don’t recommend thinking too hard about the rules that the world has regarding catgirls as those kind of discussions could lead to very strange places.  Voice acting seemed fine with tones that matched the dialogue. I really liked how they would say some of the verbs out loud. Rub, rub, for example. Or stare. That’s not something I’ve seen very often and adds a silly vibe to it.  Anyhoo, don’t purchase Nekopara for gameplay since there isn’t any. Your decision should be based on your interest in its story, the voice acting, the music, and the art.

This recommendation comes with HUGE caveats, especially if the game is not on sale at the moment which you decide to buy it. I honestly don't believe the users should be tagging this with "visual novel", as that implies some sort of player interactivity. This should be referred to as a "kinetic novel", which basically means "just point and click through the dialogue and enjoy the story".  Pros: -The art is bright and cheerful ( I love the cell style coloring). -The animations are more than just a simple fade between two static frames. They are smooth and very much like watching an anime. -Instant fan service/gratification -Super cute, tug-on-your-heartstrings cat girls -The addition of super cute voice acting -Bouncy you-know-what slider  Cons: -The story is nothing to get excited about. Even with how short it is, there was ample opportunity to not go the typical route, but sadly at no point is it unpredictable. -Characters are also very typical. You have the holy trinity of fan service: Super cute, overly excited girl, super shy, reserved girl,  and doting protagonist who just happens to have this all fall into his lap. -The emote system while smoother and providing nice animations as mentioned above, are not really "countless" as suggested in the games description. There are four main poses that get used throughout the majority of the game. -No replay value. Except for that...maybe...  All in all, I'd suggest it as a guilty pleasure. There isn't a lot of depth, but it is fun. Enjoy the fan service!

Developed by the amateur doujin company Neko Work’s, Nekopara is exactly what you might expect of such a visual novel with that nomenclature. Cute nekomimi characters, fluffy endearing moments, and the occasional nuggets of merriment wrapped up in the slice of life format. It isn’t much for those wanting more than moe and definitely isn’t a surefire recommendation, but as far as being a pleasant encounter with affable designed archetypes, a unique gimmick, and introduction to a series  it is more or less of an enticing pull into a companies premier work than anything else. As someone who is usually drawn in the by genre in any format, I thought I enjoyed this title, yet knowing how it can be double edged sword, I can say that I mildly enjoyed Nekopara on a surface level, yet by the same token, a very easily forgettable experience with little to offer. [b][u]Overview[/u]:[/b]  NekoPara Vol. 1 is a relatively short Japanese kinetic visual novel from NEKO WORKS that dazzles in the visuals but falls short in a lot of other areas.  It is the first entry in what I'm sure will be a successful series and functions as a prologue to a world where catgirls are a part of every day society.  [b][u]Reviewer's Notes[/u]:[/b]  Cocerning the eroge aspect and the 18+ version versus the All Ages version, the Steam version of this game is the All Ages version.  That means all the adult content that is in the normal game is cut out or in a few rare cases left in but censored (such as the bath sequence).  As far as I know there will be no official patch or release of the 18+ version of this game on Steam.  There are ways to get around this and those that are interested in circumventing this particular decision should be able to do so easily.  For this review I will be looking at the game as a complete product, meaning the 18+ version.  The All Ages version does not add anything to the game, only remove.  For some people this will be for the good of the experience, for others not so much.  It really depends on how well you do with eroge visual novels and this one is pretty tame all things considered.  [b][u]Story[/u]:[/b]  Without going into too much detail the general arc of NekoPara Vol. 1 is our protagonist, Minazuki Kashou,  moves out to open up his own patisserie, "La Soleil."  He comes from a long line of Japanese confection makers but dreams of doing Western treats.  This causes some friction between him and his family and thus he heads off on his own.  While moving into his new place he discovers two catgirls hiding in boxes among his stuff.  These are our two female lead characters, Chocola and Vanilla.  His family has a whole bunch of other catgirls that his sister primarily takes care of that occasionally make an appearance along with his sister as the story plays out.  The main focus, however, is on our protagonist along with Chocola and Vanilla and follows them through the opening of his new business and their lives after.  It is a sweet, silly, and occasionally laugh out loud funny tale that is pretty predictable.  It is a by the books moe romp, setting up for a full on harem power trip in later volumes, with dashes of eroge fetish fan service throughout.  None of the characters are written exceptionally well.  In the case of the 18+ version you will get to slam in about three sex sequences that come in relatively rapid succession that very slightly will affect your feelings for the characters, but only in a blatant ham-fisted way.  [b][u]Visuals[/u]:[/b]  The first thing you will notice when you play this game is the visuals are stunning.  Visual novels are a dime a dozen, ones with high production value however are much more rare.  NekoPara Vol. 1 goes above and beyond in this regard, which should be expected from Sayori and NEKO WORKS.  The sprites are exceptionally well done and thanks to the dubbed "E-mote System," they are almost fully animated, meaning expressions are ever changing, eyes blinking, hair moving, the works.  This is by far the most impressive thing about NekoPara Vol. 1 and NEKO WORKS should be proud.  [b][u]Sound Design[/u]:[/b]  The voice acting is done very well, assuming you don't mind it being all in Japanese, with dedicated deliveries and a lot of character.  The music ranges from acceptable to down right bland.  [b][u]System[/u]:[/b]  The interface is clean and easy to use.  The font choice is good, very easy to read, and I had zero issue with navigating around and interacting with the game.  The options menu is relatively robust, especially in the audio department, and upon completion you should have a nice full Extras section completely with the CG Gallery, Scenes Gallery, Music, and Movies.  [b][u]Conclusion[/u]:[/b]  NekoPara Vol. 1 isn't a bad visual novel, it does the job it sets out to do.  If you like visual novels and want to support the medium then it is probably worth playing.  If you are a fan of beautiful art then it is probably worth playing.  If you like shallow and predictable but still strangely sweet stories then it is probably worth playing.  And of course  if you have ever wanted to bang catgirls then it is probably worth playing.
Cute visual novel. R18 version is like whoa. (only looked it up, only own censored version.)

Feelings are hard in this one. { ͡• ͜ʖ ͡•}  And the plot and musics are really bouncy fun. { ͡• ͜ʖ ͡•}
[h1]Introduction[/h1]  I'll be honest, initially I thought that my main source of enjoyment from the first entry of the Nekopara visual novels would be the sexual encounters (yes I installed the 18+ patch). As I read through, I slowly began to appreciate the personalities of the characters and the world around them. If you are looking for something to fap to, look no further, as Nekopara delivers on that front quite well. However, there is more to this visual novel adaption than eroticism.  Nekopara is developed by Neko Works, a company consisting of the original artist of the manga works, Sayori, and various programmers and scenario writers. It was localized by the famous Sekai Project, who also brought The Fruit of Grisaia and is bringing Clannad to North America. Nekopara is built on the Kirikiri engine, featuring a plugin called the "E-mote" system, which brings the characters to life through smooth animations. The opening song (OP) is Taiyou Paradise, sung by nao. The ending song (ED) is Nekomanma Biyori, sung by Haruka Shimotsuki. Nekopara was released on Steam on December 29, 2014 for $10.   [h1]Premise and Story[/h1]  Nekopara is set in a world in which some humans have been genetically modified to have cat-like features (or is it the other way around?), such as cat ears, tails, and general cat behaviour. These humanoid cats are deemed "catgirls" and are a common component of Japanese families. They are treated like normal pets and important members of the family. They can understand and communicate with humans at a basic level, although the complexities of human emotions and societal structure remain incomprehensible. In order for a catgirl to be trusted on their own in the world, they must take a Bell exam so that they can earn a Bell. These Bells signify that the catgirl wearing them is fit to walk among humans, and that their owner(s) have educated them sufficently.  The story starts with the protagonist, Minaduki Kashou, moving out of his parents' house to start up his own bakery, Patisserie La Soleil. The grammatical error is explained, I assure you. As he is unpacking his things, two medium sized boxes catch his attention. Two catgirls, the energetic, enthusiastic Chocola and the soft-spoken, subtle Vanilla spring out of the boxes, greeting their master. Kashou's younger sister, Shigure, smuggled them aboard the moving truck so that they could assist Kashou in his business. Over the course of Volume 1, the catgirls develop romantic feelings for Kashou under the guise of physical maturation, then they finally admit their feelings. Despite the fluffy and light nature of the story, there are some emotionally charged moments that enraptured me. [spoiler] Chocola shares some intimate memories of her and Vanilla's childhood early in the novel, and the last chapter involves Kashou nearly dying from overwork and the catgirls rushing to find a doctor. [/spoiler]  [h1]Gameplay and Presentation[/h1]  Nekopara is a kinetic novel, which means there are no player choices. The story is told almost entirely from Kashou's perspective. The player's interactions consist of:  Left Click/Enter: Advance text Ctrl: Skip text P: Makes characters' breasts jiggle Alt-F4: Emergency panic button  The VN is divided into 8 chapters, and each chapter is 45 minutes to an hour long, depending on how fast you read and if you listen to the voice acting (which is superb). If you decide to install the 18+ patch, there are 3 sex scenes spread out between chapters 5 - 7. Without the sex scenes, a readthrough takes about 4-5 hours, and 6-7 hours with the patch. The E-mote system provides silky smooth character animations and movements. To be honest, it's the first time I've seen this much liveliness in a visual novel, so it was impressive to me.   The art style is clean and well presented, with vibrant colours and detailed facial features. The backgrounds are relatively simple, but beautifully rendered. Almost all of the artwork was done by Sayori, the original artist of the Neko Paradise works. Not much to say about the art except that it is alluring and utterly gorgeous to look at.  All of the characters with the exception of the protagonist are fully voiced. In addition to the onscreen characters, there are unseen tertiary characters such as shop owners and passersby that are voiced as well. All audio is in Japanese, although you may set the text and interface to English, Japanese, or Chinese.   Sekai Project's localization is both accurate and humourous. Take a look at my screenshots for proof of this. Listening to the voices and comparing it to the text, I found little to no errors in the translation, and honorifics were kept untouched, which is a personal plus. Keep in mind that I am not experienced in the Japanese language, but I do know basic structure and particles. Take my words with a grain of salt.   [h1]Final Remarks/Conclusion[/h1]  In short, whether you are a fan of anthropomorphized cats or not, Nekopara is a highly enjoyable visual novel. Although the main appeal of this series is the H-scenes, the patch is optional. The Steam version was censored because of Steam's policies and to appeal to a wider audience. A quick Google search will grant you access to the adult files, so don't worry about missing out. Nekopara still offers a complete and cute experience, if a little too focused on romantic pursuits. For $10, I would say it's more than worth the asking price. It's simply [b]nyanderful![/b]

Awesome Game :)  11/10
First off, there is absolutely no interaction whatsoever, so set the text speed to something you're comfortable with and throw away your mouse, you'll never need it. Also the jiggly bits slider never seemed to change anything.  Lets start with the good parts. Catgirls are cute, bakeries are awesome, the uniforms for said bakery are pretty awesome, and the protagonists sister is adorable. The voice acting is about what you would expect from a title like this, nothing too special but its certainly not bad by any means. I was impressed with the E-Mote (think Live2D animations) system and animations that make the characters feel much more alive than regular old 2D could do, there are issues with this system that I'll bring up in the negative points.  I was extremely disappointed with the utter lack of interaction, no branches in story no choices, nothing. The story isn't that great and the characters don't change or grow much, but that can attributed to this being Volume 1 and also to this being less of an example of interactive fiction and more of a porn game with the porn removed. The scenario feels a bit contrived even allowing for suspension of disbelief about cat-people I never could quite find myself immersed. (I readily admit this is probably a personal failing.) The E-Mote system causes very noticeable stuttering when loading new characters into a scene; I was not the only one suffering from this problem, according to the forums.  On a more personal level, I didn't enjoy the protagonist getting together with multiple catgirls, especially given how many assets their designs reused, it just felt like two versions of the same character and I feel like the experience would have improved by just cutting one of the two characters or having two minor arcs dictated by a choice early on while leaving the one not selected as a background character.  All said, if you're excited for this title, I recommend getting the R18 version. This title is not worth the time without the explicit scenes in it and I don't even like that sort of thing.
Only complaint, game be too short.  Otherwise, the biggest bundle of Kawaii you can get packed into a pair of kitties.    On a more serious note, game plays off of common visual novel and anime tropes to create atypical girl heroines in the for of humanoid, cat and girl fusions. Needless to say all the character designs and story comes off as some of the cutest, most adorable things ever. Sure to fill your heart with a boundless fluffiness that is sure to send you floating off into the stratosphere. The game has little plot and character development, but at least it keeps it short and sweet. The game doesn't try to be anything it's not. It has a linear, no-choice story line with standard harem tropes. It's just a bundle of heart lifting love that is sure to entertain those who already enjoy the moe genre. There are fully animated scenes, and the girls and their boobs move and bounce while you talk to them. Gives you something to drool over nonetheless. While steam has removed the H-content, you can install extras here [url=http://imouto.club/?page_id=7] Imouto.club	[/url], It might not be worth the money, but it's definitely worth the time if you can enjoy cutesy things.

As someone who is an avid Anime and Manga nerd, this is definately recommended if you like gushy RomCom's.  1) It does have a few erotic scenes, but even they are done sparingly and "tastefully" enough to just add to the devloping relationships.  2) The plot is very lighthearted (which I view as good thing, not enjoying forced drama) and sweet. Had a smile on my face nearly the entire time.  3) Music is catchy, the Voice Acting is very well done, if not original at least quality.  4) The art is awesome. The only VN I've played that had art of this quality was Grisaia no Kaijitsu. (Which really needs to be put on Steam -.-)  TLDR: It's a fairly short, sweet love story with moderately interesting characters and put a smile on my face for a couple of hours. Definately worth the price. But don't play it when your parents may walk into the room. That could get embarassing

With full on professional grade voice acting and character design, Nekopara's ~$10 price point is head and shoulders better value than any other Steam VN I've seen so far. It also features music that doesn't loop incessantly and writing that is actually pretty good even translated. If adorable young catgirls is your thing, look no further.  If you're getting into any VNs at all on Steam, get this one. It demonstrates the level of quality and production value we should eventually expect out of VNs coming from western makers.

*Mature Warning* NEKOPARA is a...... catgirl hentai visual novel. Unlike the other visual novels I described as Ecchi, this one you can get a clear picture where they cut out the erotic scenes so they were able to sell it on Steam. Having said that, it's not that bad and kind of a cute story once you get past to whole...ummm erotic moments. You read from prespetive of Kashou Minaduki, a pastry chief, opening his own cafe by himself until Kashou get two big and heavy packages containing his catgirl pets from home. They convinced him to let them stay and help him with the cafe. Two things I liked from this visual novel; it's animated and there voice acting although the voice acting is in Japanese, I assume. Also in the options menu, there "Chest Bounciness" slider and a special button on the keyboard that makes the character jump. And I give this a 9/10. *Read at your own Risk*

I admit, I played it. All the way through. I got every acheivement because, really, it was just too easy... Physically. Mentally, i was not prepared for this kind of... Software. I never touched a visual novel in my life up until now. Needless to say, i'm very shaken, but i will not let this deter my critique for this game. Sure, i may not LIKE the concept, and i may not LIKE the content, but i can see why someone would very much like it. It just doesn't appeal to me. The game is well made, it works flawlessly, and for my computer, the frame rate is fantastic, and i'd say i have a low-end PC. I'm just shocked how well made it is for this kind of...Software. Simply put, if you like the genere, and you like the concept, you're going to love this game. If you're new to the genre and are looking forward into committing yourself into playing more games like this... Eh, try the free visual novel before buying this. I'd reccomend it if you're a fan of visual novels. Unfortunately, i'm not, but... Eh, this is for those of you who do, so, fuck it. I'm reccomending it.

This game CHANGED MY LIFE. After my girlfriend left me there was a hole in my heart I didn't think I could ever fill again. I was no longer able to find joy in games, so when I first started up this game I wasn't expecting to be so emotionally captivated by a maid cafe story.  I was wrong. The first time I met eyes with Chocola, something moved deep inside me. We instantly clicked... She laughed at my jokes, she liked talking to me... Sure enough, we quickly fell in love with each other. Never before have I seen the raw emotion of true love emulated so purely. But what surprised me is that Vanilla also began displaying affection to me and she won over my heart as well. What can I say, I guess I'm just too much of a hunk! Keep playing and you might get as good as me.  The animation really makes them seem alive. I keep instinctually reaching out to the screen to pet them. The art is not only very cute, but the characters are extremely realistic and believable and you really feel connected to the characters. It's even better than talking to humans. Before this game I had no one. Now I have not one, but TWO cat wives who love me! Who needs anyone else when these beautiful ladies love you unconditionally?  Even better is the immersive programming. The characters always seem to follow my eyes, and whisper my name at night. I can't figure out how you guys programmed that! Great job though.  The game is so good that I'm never going to stop playing. I'm finally happy again. THANK YOU NEKO WORKS!!!
Nekopara is a Kinetic Visual Novel (Meaning you're reading a story with no decision making from you, the player.) The story centers around a man named Kashou Minaduki, who moved away from his family, without notice, to start a new life and open up the bakery he's always wanted. However, he is followed by two catgirls named Chocola, and Vanilla; two of the six catgirls that are within the Minaduki family. The two girls want to stay and live with Kashou because they love him, and that he's their "master". This is set in a world where catgirls are domesticated much like cats, so there's an owner and pet vibe going on, but they're obviously more intelligent than cats, and can do more. The rest of the story basically settles around Kashou coping with Chocola and Vanilla while trying to maintain the business and order of the bakery, and how the catgirls are going to affect his life and relationship with them.  This is a rather lighthearted story with lots of cute, funny moments coming from the two girls. A positive is that this story is fully voice acted (In Japanese), has animation thanks to a program called "E-Mote" where facial and body animations are possible, and a wonderful, casual soundtrack that's very memorable, and calming to listen to. There's also a decent amount of CG art that's made for specific scenes, with a little more detail.  Obviously, this story isn't for everyone. Like I said, it's a lighthearted story with funny moments and admittedly heartwarming chapters. You can really get attatched and connected to the characters if you're up for a tale such as this one. The story has lots of moments such as Chocola and Vanilla acting all cutesy and purring, meowing, stuff like that. People would be split on this depending on what you like, but I personally find that super adorable and makes the characters much more likeable.  It's not just that though, there is character development, and the story does actually go somewhere. It's not so much slice-of-life if you were thinking that. It mainly revolves around Kashou's relationship with Chocola and Vanilla, the bakery's business, and the girls earning their "bells" (Which you'll learn as you read along.) There is quite a few things going on, and the story never feels like it's halthing in one spot for too long.  If you like this kinda story, love catgirls, or are a fan of anime, then this is for you, it's vey polished and well done for what it is, and I was honestly surprised and what i got myself into. The story will take about 5-7 hours to read completely.  9/10
You will never look at your cats in a same way again.

This game is actually a clever political statement about the treatment of Jews in Nazi Germany. A group of people treated as second-class citizens? Being forced to identify themselves with easily identifiable bling? Being detained simply for existing without identification? This is Schindler's List for Generation Y. Or it could be a condemnation of American facism. It works on so many levels.
Story: B- Most, if not all of its story elements can be commonly found in lots of Anime and Manga. However, It's clear that the story is told in a way where few people would find it to be a major problem. Though I must say the story is short - You can probably 100% it in under 2 hours. Art: A+ In my knowledge, this game is one of, if not THE first games to use E-Mote System for its character arts. And the result? Perfect. Music & SE: B+ It's not perfect material compared to the great companies such as KEY's works, but the Music and SE in this game follows and sets the mood well. The voice acting is also a plus. System: A With all the animations and stuff, the game still runs smoothly on an average laptop.  Final Rank: A Recommended. Not a waste of money even if bought without a sale.

Literally surrounded by Hot catgirls, would bathe with them again. 10/10
NEKOPARA Vol. 1 isn't so much a game as it is a powerpoint tour-de-force. I haven't been so satified in many different ways from a powerpoint since I first installed Crysis on my Emachines back in 2008. If you think this is a joke review, then I don't blame you; NEKOPARA does not look like much aside from the cute girls and words dancing under their customizibly bouncy chests, but what it offers is a true deconstruction of the slice-of-life archetype, and this alone makes the journey worth embarking.  I do not wish to spoil much, but NEKOPARA Vol. 1 tackles sensitive themes such as human trafficking, slavery, genetic modification, violations of the Geneva Convention, the politics of a cross-species society, and beastiality. The unnamed town our protagonist moves to is clearly that of a monitored police-state, not unlike that of City 17, where the upper-class rule over the lower-classes with an iron fist. I can say no more, but holy shit. NEKOPARA Vol. 1 does not hold back.  It really does sound like I'm making shit up, but this is honestly not a joke. NEKOPARA Vol. 1 hides it's true nature under what looks to be a shallow fap, kind of like a convincing trap. But unlike a trap, it didn't stop me after the fact. All I can say is that this is a better present than Gender Bender DNA Twister Extreme, and if you had to make a choice, go with this. You will be surprised.
[b]This. Is not. A game.[/b] This is a subtitled anime. Correction: this is a subtitled [u]motion comic[/u]. There are no choices. There are no controls more elaborate than those on a video player. There are somthing like 50 save slots. [b]WHY?![/b]  I wasn't expecting much, but this is literally nothing but pretty. And possibly a slightly weird commentary on slavery.
"dont trust anyone who doesn't have this game in their library"- King Weeaboo

The story is as good as Bioshock Infinite, I'm not kidding its that good.  And since it feels more like an anime, i'd go so far as to say it would be my number four, only because the likes of steins;gate, elfen lied, and shin sekai yori already take the top three. The character development is amazing, you don't see that kind of thing everday, It asks extremely important questions that are NEVER asked normally and slams haters in one fell swoop. Does sharing blood make you love someone. No, love is earned. The memories you make create your bonds and just how far you would go for them shows your love. What do family "ties" have to do with expressing your love. Not a damn thing. Isn't being gay wrong? You still haven't realized the physical equipment you're given is just that and has no bearing whatsoever on who you are or who you care for? Isn't love supposed to be a one on one thing? Totally the choice of the lovers and no one else. This story DESTROYS the false concepts society has erected regarding love. And even gets into racist/speciesist issues. Damn perfect 10/10  P.S. I would say the 18 version adds to the story as some of the most crucial character development happens during the ommitted scenes, yes they are a bit tiring and overdone but since its done in service of the story I have no complaints.

Nekopara (Cat Paradise) Is a very cute visual novel about catgirls being mixed in the world and well about if cats were able to live in human forms.  Story is based on a rich guy who likes baking and opens a baking shop by 'running' away from home and then suddenly... Catgirls appear who are called by Vanilla and Chocola.  It is a cute story but nothing really gets done other then perversion and cats.. lots and lots of cats.  Now other then that the Pros and Cons.   Pros: Music is great and the animations for a visual novel is something I have never seen before and looks well detailed and something that is amazing on your eyes to look at. OH and boob jiggling settings you should max out before starting.   Cons: Not much story but the cuteness and personality of the characters tends to make you forget that there is basically.. not much of a story...  Hopefully they put more story in Vol.2 but I wouldnt complain very much if it was alot like this one.

I've been a fan of Sayori's artwork for years now, and I've waited anxiously for a day that Neko Works would produce some kind of game with her gorgeous artwork. It's finally here, and it's everything you could ask for: HD artwork, fully voiced, and a high quality emofuri-inspired animation engine. Seeing these characters come to life outside of art books and short ero comics gives me huge moe feels.  You should buy this if you obsess over catgirls or are looking for another short VN to play. Pick up the original ero release on DLsite too. :chocola:

If you ever feel down then you need to play this game.  NekoPara is a lovely game that takes you in the story of 2 catgirls. The storyline is great , also the music makes you feel happy ^_^  This is a true hentai game without the R18 scenes. I would recommend to play the full version with R18 to get the complete feeling of the story.  This is not a dating sim but more a linear story driven game , this game just takes the player as the main character in the game. It's like reading a novel, there are no choices to choose from. You just need to click ( or press the same button on your gamepad ) to advance the story.  After you completed the story you have finished volume 1 then the game ends. The story in this novel game makes you very happy and fun. You will learn more emotions of the characters while you advance. Just play this game in a quiet environment , listen to the voice and music with english subs and enjoy!  10/10
Really beutifully animated and even voiced. Must have been a lot of money put into this game. However playing it is a bit of a culture shock. Can be a bit too kawaii for some folks.   I myself found the game to be among the few that makes me feel uncomfortable and embarrased on a constant basis while playing.   There was once a time when I could embrace the ...moe of such a genre but that time has passed for me. If hyper kawaii is your style don't hesitate this VN is pretty refreshing in terms of style.   For everyone else like me you will open this game and be pleasantly suprised by the game and then suddenly overcome with questions relating to civil rights. Do the cat people die at the age of 20 like most felines? Do they have SS numbers? Do they have rights? These cat people seem to be sentient hybrid creatures that humanity perhaps created. Are they sent on suicide missions like many animals during the early space program? Do their lives have less value than a human life? If you hit one with your car can you just drive off without finding the owner the way that it is in the US?  Many questions either way enjoy the game.
its ok
Writing a review to represent those of us who made a mistake.  If there were less than 100 reviews, I wouldn't submit because it's probably not fair for me to judge.  **I have never seen Anime, nor played a game like this.**  Decided to try it on a whim because Princess Robot Bubblegum from Grand Theft Auto IV makes me laugh everytime I watch it, and I adore Japanese women.    Apparently you need more than a love of Japanese women and a positive genre impression to love a game like this.  I'm clearly out of my league.  I went into it with no expectations, and somehow came away disappointed.  There's no game here, but it's a visual novel, so I didn't expect one.  But for a novel, the writing reminds me of Judy Blume or some adolescent paperback pulp like the Babysitter's Club.  I appreciate the bouncing breasts, but was surprised the animation doesn't strike me as good as South Park: The Stick of Truth... a low bar, to be sure.  Yet reading other reviews, this appears to be an exceptional addition to the genre.  I guess the genre is going to have to evolve before I give it another go, though.

Reasons to buy: Decent Slice of Life style story Great cast of Catgirls  Enough drama to make it interesting Incestual undertones (if that's your thing) Semi animated sprites (My first visual novel with moving characers, but I'm aware that it's the norm in Japan currently.) Options to have boobs bounce less or more (Why is this not an option in every game?) If you're a fan of 'Wanko to Kurasou' then this is for you  Reasons to not buy: Reading (This is a visual novel with no gameplay and no choices to make for different endings) Incestual undertones (If it's not your thing, but to be fair it's pretty light on the incest) Not for those sensitive to perverted things  My own thoughts on Nekopara: Being the slice of life anime and visual novel lover I am, I was very excited to see Nekopara show up on Steam. The story, while mostly cliche and predictable, was done well and left me excited to see if a volume 2 will come out. The moving characters don't move all that awkwardly like I have seen from other 2.5d games and it felt very much like I was watching an anime. Depending on reading speed and or what you set the auto-read settings to, you can finish this in 2-4 hours so keep that in mind if you are on the fence about buying this.   TL;DR: Slice of Life story done well - Lasts 4-5 hours max - Cliche but enjoyable

In general, I like to quantify the amount of enjoyment I'm having. In the case of Nekopara, the metric I used to gauge my enjoyment is nyas per minute, or npm.   For reference, the famous "Nyan Cat" clocks in at an impressive 397 npm, +/- 2 nyas. While it is theoretically possible to exceed 400 nyas per minute, no human or computer has ever achieved such a feat. So for the purpose of this analysis, I will treat 400 npm as the soft cap for what is technically achievable by game developers.  Analysis:  In the minute long samples I took, the average was at 15 npm +/- 1 nya. During sex scenes, the npm dropped to around 10 npm. Npm peaked when three or more catgirls were on the screen, sometimes reaching as high as 31 npm. That Nekopara could have such a high nya density and still maintain coherent dialogue is an impressive feat to say the least.  Conclusion:   Given that the npm of Nekopara is only 1/26th the amount of npm in Nyan Cat, it only makes sense that the game itself is roughly 1/26th as popular as the internet viral video. This is not to say that I, as an individual, enjoy it 1/26th as much as the aforementioned video, just that given the statistical information above, the disparity in viewership is not unexpected.
Boob Bouncing Simulator
To start with, The visual novel (because it's hard to call this a game) is for people to whom the anime world is nothing new. It doesn't mean that you might not like it if you are alien with those, but it is rather recommended to know the anime/manga terms.  Personally I have played several visual novels (mostly where you have choice in it) and there was one major point that shines in this game, that is animation; yes this visual novel has mostly animated scenes and characters; also to add it consists japanese dubbing with chinese, english or japanese subtitles to choose, which I especially like. The story is very interesting and reminds me a first visual novel I had played, Wanko to Kurasou. The only things I do dislike is lack of choices as there is only one story in it. It is also short (4 hours for me), but it is just volume 1.  To sum up:  [h1][b]Pluses:[/b][/h1] [list] [*]Good art [*]Consists animations [*]Interesting story [*]Well made characters [*]Upcoming sequel [/list]  [h1][b]Minuses:[/b][/h1] [list] [*]Short [*]Version with +18 scenes not avaliable on steam (without modding) [*]Lack of choices [/list]  Sounds and voice acting: 9/10 Music: 7/10 Art: 10/10 Story: 10/10 Translation: 10/10 (For English version)  [b]Overall: 9/10[/b]

Alright,  Besides all the obvious content other reviewers refer to, Nekopara has many other great things going for it, besides the cute catgirls.  The backgrounds are awesome and just as beautiful as the characters. And about the characters, I've not read many VN's with that good drawing style. It's just awesome. Very detailed and very warm. Sound and music are spot on also. They fit right in and provide a very good atmosphere.  One thing though, that I don't like, is the fact that when you want to overwrite a save file or want to quit the VN; the mouse cursor moves to the "NO" button at first. I get the idea that it's funny the first tme.., but after 3, 4, 5 times...sorry. Well, that's just about the only thing that's not very good with this VN. I mean, everything else is perfect: Writing, art, cute characters and fun. Oh, about the hentai thing; this is on the green side, nothing you can't see on youtube.

I'm not a fan of full-on visual novels where you don't get to make any choices ... but for those of you who enjoy the genre, this is exactly what you're looking for. AAA+ quality "game" as far as art, animation, story and the characters themselves. You'll & truly really fall in love with your cat-girls and even the narrator (you!) is a likable dude, so no one should have trouble relating. Also, they're not kidding with the "mature" and "nudity" user-tags, haha. Tastefully done, still, if you don't find yourself getting a bit, uh, excited, playing this game, well ... you're just not human!  10/10. I have yet to give out a perfect score on any game I've reviewed, but this is truly a flawless piece of art. I personally did not encounter any bugs, glitches, or even spelling/grammatical errors, so I will stick to my perfect score until finding otherwise.

I was attracted by the title when I saw steam releasing a new Comic Market release, after I investigated a little bit and decide to buy it full price - I'm the kind of person usually wait for titles to pick up until it went on sale, but the "good" reviews and my curoisity overwhelmed by patience on the title. I "beat the game" in 6 hours and I feel for 10 dollars, this is not bad for a visual novel.  Pros:  High animation quality (In terms of Visual Novel) - The main game is basically reading a novel, but with slideshows involved. I have "played" some visual novels in the past, but this time I'm pleasently surprised due to the movement of the characters are actually pretty good (except for some death stares when they forgot (I think?) to animate the eyes). The characters move pretty realistically (again, in visual novel standards), and the legendary "P" key enchance the gameplay for approximately 200%.  Good voice acting - This is mostly personal preference, but I do like the voice acting in the game. It's anime-y and it gives you the vibes of watching a shounen "full of service" anime. Also I highly appreciate the publisher keeping the original voice cast instead of going for the localization of games (I'm looking at you, Dynasty Warriors).  Cons:  NOT a dating sim - I don't know what steam's definition of "Dating Sim" is (Or better yet, who put dating sim in the tag in the first place), but a dating sim in my book involves choices - choices that you choose determines which girl you are pursuing, but this game has no choices at all, basically it's the "Left click and you beat the game" game. I have no problem Nekopara has no choices whatsoever, but please steam, don't mislead people into thinking they are playing a game which they have choices.  Cutting content - I know that steam is trying to fend off the "made for erotic sensation" games in steam, but cutting content still stinks no matter what the reason is. For those who are not aware: The game is originally R-18, but steam decides to only include the non R-18 content (The original have the settings to enable/disable it). It does not affact the story much (Only 3 scenes are invloved), and there are fixes that enable the content (Check out the only guide in this game for details), but I feel like it's like playing witcher 2 without the sex - It's okay, but it feels weird.  Small typo on subtitles - I did not check the japanese subtitles (as I do not know japanese well enough), but the chinese and english subtitles have small typos and paste errors. It does not affact the game much, and the rest of the translation is top-notch... but just a minor con in my opinion.  In general I recommend this game if you like Visual Novels and the "sweet-sweet" type story, and I'm looking forward to Sekai Project's next game to publish, cause I feel they have enough passion to gather such a new VN to steam, I feel and hope they will publish more high quality VNs here.

If you are going to "play" this, you might as well get the 18+ version to get the most out of it.   1. Buy this game one Steam. 2. Install the game. 3. Get the 18+ version. 4. Install it in the same directory, overwrite any existing files. 5. In Steam client, right click on Nekopara Vol. 1-> Properties-> Set Launcher Options->Add: -steam="yes" 6. Play the game the way it meant to be. All the Steam features including Achievements will work.  Brace yourselves when you get to chapter 5.

So erm Nekopara.... Right off with the review!  So Nekopara is a visual novel or eroge if you want to call it. Now what's a visual novel? Technically visual novel is like a movie, voice pack, picture book, and usually visual novel are rate 18+ but with steam you have the all age version.  (To get the R 18 Go here -> http://www.dlsite.com/ecchi-eng/work/=/product_id/RE144678.html)  Now Nekopara you play as a guy, Minaduki Kashou. You just open a small bakery in a small town and just as you were moving and clearing your item. you encounter two box which seems oddly out of place.... Meet the two main heroine. Chocola and Vanilla two cute cat girl! Here your adventure start with your two lovely cute cat girl.  Pros:  This is the 1st few Visual novel i played that have animated moving character sprite and it does help you get more into the game then most visual novel does. +Great animation   The game also provide good voice acting, cute infact!  ( granted i don't play japan game with English voice so i wouldn't know how the English voice acting sound like...) +Good voice acting  The character are likeable (just about it) +Likeable character  The Meh part:  The game length is reasonable. i clock in at about 6 hour or so. -/+ depends on how you view it. to me it felt right, any longer will feel like a drag.   Cons:  Ok so in visual novel usually there are choices, which decide which heroine you want to romance with. But this feature doesn't seem to be anywhere in this game... so it took me out of bit and actually. Replay vaule in visual novel are important, by introducing so many character and off no different at all is sad and make  me wish for more. Only reason to actually play this again is maybe in a few weeks or months time. -No choice -No replay vaule.  Conclusion: Do i think you should buy it? Well honestly.... Yes!  If you are a fan of visual novel with tons and tons of cats/Neko then give this a shot. If you are a fan of muti ending, and want different route to play with then.... sadly you wont find any here. But i say buy this to show support!  Support this title so next time we might see more visual novel on steam!  Rating 8/10

nice meme
4/10 No backstory; is this a different world? Is it a different timeline? If it's earth did the cats mutate? Are they aliens? How did they first meet humans, etc. The overall story isn't particularly engaging.  Quite predictable as well. I didn't feel like I could relate or empathize with the main character at all. In terms of being a vn: visual novels are meant to give the player a sense of control in how they affect the storyline. The fact that the player cannot influence any of the  protagonists decisions in the VN is a fairly big deal and severely affects replayability. The game is based around the premise of "cats that are humanoid" however they don't act like cats. Cats in general I have found to be standoffish and much more self absorbed then they are portrayed in this VN and this causes the feline character to seem much more doglike. The art is amazing however, and the visual effects are quite fluid (transitions, the boob jiggle, expression changes etc.) Music was quite standard with other visual novels. Not bad but not outstanding.  In summary, subpar as a game, subpar as a visual novel but it has nice art and decent music for its genre. Not worth $10 however if you're curious pick it up if it's less then $3.   P.S If you are interested in light novels after this game, and have never read Katawa Shoujo... Go give it a go, I promise you won't be disappointed.

Classic.  10/10
Similar to Sakura Spirit; this kind of isn't a game, its more like an book in some aspects.  But unlike Sakura Spirit, Nekopara has actually shown some heart and care, and has put in both voice acting and done some very fluid animations for pretty much all scenes.  The steam version has a good chunk of the adult content cut out; but I am told that it is possible to go find the 18+ version elsewhere; if you have the money for both, you can technically combine them so your playing through the steam overlay and getting the achievements, while at the same time getting the hentai content originally created for the game.  I imagine the 18+ content was left out for child/family friendliness... or else theres intentions to make it as separate dlc content later on. Don't know.  Also unlike Sakura Spirit, I can actually stand to read what the main character is saying.  Not to mention the storyline for Nekopara looks, so far, like it will be far longer than Sakura Spirit, and with a good deal more thought put into it; even if it is sort of more of a "slice of life" modern day fantasy setting.  Would I recommend this? Yeah, the creators did some good work on this, and theres real quality in it.

So~~~  Everyone here knows what he or she is in to I hope. The full version is an adult visual novel, this means there is r18 content.  Now, for those that are conserned, the steam version cut out all the r18 content. It is possible to enable the full game on steam if you have the files from the uncut version.  I have played throught the full version, so including the r18 content. Please do keep that in mind while reading the review.    Once again, everyone here knows what he or she is getting in to. Nekopara Vol. 1 is the first chapter about you, you are making a new start by starting up an patisserie called "La Soleil". While you are moving you notice 2 extra boxes, seems like some catgirls from home snuck along for the ride! You start of by wanting to send them back home, but they really do not want to be seperated from you, they plead, they beg and the amount of willpower you can muster start to falter. They can stay.  and this is the start of your adventure ;)  Now about the game itself. I really enjoyed the story, I found it well thought out. Vanilla and Chocola have a good back and forth compatability, and while this may be subjective I really liked the way they voiced them. The voices fit really wel, this has also been done for other recurring characters! I would like to note that on auto reading it will take you just a bit less then 6 hours to finish Nekopara Vol. 1  As for the visuals, this is somewhat unlike a normal visual novel. Normally VN's are like a picture book, the pictures are still and the picture changes when something happens. In Nekopara Vol. 1 small bits and pieces have been animated.  This small addition made it really nice to watch what was unfolding. The background and overall characterdesign are really well done as well in my honest opinion.  The music was ok, nothing too memorable there but it is good for what it wants to do. I have not had the feeling that it was annoying or anything of the likes in the whole playthrough.  Also there is one thing I want to say about the settings. There is a "Boob bounciness" setting, you can set it from no movement at all to gravity defying so~ This was weird to see in the options, but thank you Sekai Project for implementing!  Last thing, more than once I got a message from my friends that looked something like this: "What the heck are you playing?!?!?" So be prepared to be judged by your friends.  Now as for my recommendation, I will recommend Nekopara. I will however say that the r18 version is the one you want. I will play through the cut version to see what the impact of the cut has on the Steam version. The art is very nice, I liked the characters, the music wasn't great but it was passable and there is an very interesting settings option.   Now I just want the Steam trading cards and I'm set. ... ... At least untill they announce Nekopara Vol. 2 :')
Someday I will make genetically modified catgirls but for now this will do as I brush up in my science and get a master degree in making this a reality for people everywhere.
10/10 Would bathe with catgirls again.

A short and sweet story about catgirls nothing less but maybe something more...
This game is beyond adorable. The entire story is well-written ((in my honest opinion)), the animations are as smooth as I've ever seen in the past and the artwork itself is fantastic.   While the game does have its "low points", some of it being grammical errors or cheesy story-writing here and there, Nekopara Vol 1 was an outstanding accomplishment. I hope that the developers are very proud of how well they did with this visual novel. I loved every second of the story, getting both versions of the game. The background music is very engaging and appropriate for each scene and chapter. The opening page of each new chapter is very well done and they each gave me a smile.  The story is very well-written, keeping me hanging on every word. Each character was brought out at the right time and presented in such a way that they never got old when ever they were brought back in. The only things I have an issue with when it comes to the narrative is that the sentence structure of "__ did __ when I __  __" I noticed it a lot during the beginning and middle portions of the narrative itself as I went through. Also, there were moments where the VAs could have expressed more emotion into the words they were saying in some parts of the narrative. I'd give examples, but I'd be too worried of spoiling the experience from other people. However, those are the only quips I have about the story writing.  I thoroughly enjoyed the animation of each character model. I feel that the developers should be very proud of how well they turned out. The thing about static character models is that you only get one face most of the time, with the only changes being when the character has a shift in attitude. The use of animated models are exceedingly better ((depending on how well they are done)) can give the player a much better view on what a character is feeling. In Nekopara, there were moments where VAs didn't express the seriousness of some of the situations. However, that was almost immediately remedied by the expression the character models presented as they moved and talked with the spoken words.  I just completed the full version that I got through other sources besides Steam and I cannot wait to see what the developers come up with for Vol 2

11/10  SO Kawaiiiii Best Game Everrrrrrrrrrrrr
It’s been a while since I played a visual novel, and unexpectedly this became a reminder of why I like them. Nekopara is dubious to say the least, as it’s a story about a man getting sexually involved with cat girls.  This is designed to provide relief from the horrible reality of every day life. The world of Nekopara is bright, pure, and uncomplicated. It’s full of love and hope. Whatever happens in the world, it’s never sinister, never dark. The most dramatic thing that happens is people getting sick. And because the stakes are so low, it manages to get some drama out of everyday events. The world doesn’t go under, nobody is hurt, nobody dies.   It delivers exactly what it says on the box. Definitely not for everyone. Can’t deny I found it pleasant, and it made me want to play more visual novels. Not because I crave more cat girls in my life. I just enjoy the process of playing them. Because you click to get the next line of text, you feel in control of the pace. Nothing punishes you for wanting to take it slow, or if you blaze through a scene. Unlike games the story doesn’t go on break. Every click advances the plot. Visual novels are their own thing, separate from games, film, books or comics. I like their mechanics, and the possibilities they provide for telling stories in ways which blur the line between mediums.  Nekopara doesn’t try to do much. But for what it is, it’s well put together. It’s enough to make me excited about playing other titles with more ambitious stories. And that’s enough for me to not harbor any negative feelings toward the title. I’m glad Steam has become a place where both this and Hatred can co-exist.
I thought this would be a joke and just be something you would buy once and stop once you barely got into it, but I was very surprised to find that it was very well done. The story was interesting, albeit a little gratuitous, it had interest that went beyond just having cat girls in a game, but it had an interesting world and motivation within it, with each character having different drives, opinions and personalities that work well in the game. Twas a good game/visual novel. GG 10/10

NEKOPARA isn't a game. It's an amazing Visual Novel, and I recommend it extremely. We play as Kashou Minaduki, he moved out from his home without telling anyone, in order to open his own shop "La Solei" But soon after moving in, 2 giant boxes get send to him; Inside of them are Chocola and Vanilla, the two catgirls from his original home, who want to be with their master. And this is where the fun begins. Chocola and Vanilla are two catgirls who want to be with their master a lot, even when Master doesn't want them to be here, because he wants to have a fresh start: They don't wanna go away. Master was the person who cared about them the most, and they don't wanna leave Master. The soundtrack is pretty great, and fits for each respective scene. Voice acting is done nicely, and all the characters sound extremely cute.  And the animations and art in general, it's so great that I can't even believe it. It's done smoothly, and cutely. In other words, in the best way possible. And if you're trying to learn Japanese/Chinese, then this game can even help you with doing that. There's an option to turn on both, English and Japanese/Chinese subtitles at the same time, so you can learn words easily. As the game goes on, the characters are developing over time, in a very good way. The story is very good too, it introduces every character in a good way, and explains nicely what's going on at all times.   I would tell you a lot of more reasons as to why I really like this VN, but if I did I would spoil a lot of the game, and I don't want to do that.  In other words, if you like visual novels and/or love adorable catgirls, get this game. I cannot wait for vol.2, which will probably be amazing as well.  10/10  *Nyaaaaaaaaa~!
Simply put, it's a cute game. Having been a fan of Sayori's art for a long time now, couldn't let this slip without playing it.  Can't wait for Vol2 to come...
It is a great time to be a kemonomimi fan.

So kawaii it needs a trigger warning.
Already played non steam version. and yeah, it's good for lonely ppl. This game will warmed your cold life.
First of all, as you should know, this isn't a game. It's a Visual Novel, which is kind of like a book with a more visual focus. Most VNs have some gameplay elements, like picking a choice and thus altering and/or branching the story slightly or majorly. THIS VN HAS NO SUCH THINGS. There is absolutely not one single choice in this, and as such, it can't be called a game at all.  Well, a book is fine too.  Now then, for a VN, the UI in the game is superb. Pretty much only outdone by Majikoi. Let's see now: + The default resolution is 1280x720, but the game has 10 hotkeys for resolution ranging from miniscule 320x180 to 1600x900. You can also stretch the window to whatever you want and use "Lock resolution to (your current window size)." This makes it easy to just stretch the window into 1920x1080 and lock it there. When you next launch the game, the game will remember your locked resolution. - The game tends to go to 1921x1080. If you're autistic like me, you'll be resizing until you finally get the proper 1920x1080. + The game upscales BEAUTIFULLY. I do not know what resolution the ingame files are, but I cannot notice the upscaling pixels at all at 1080p. If the ingame files really are 720p - and why wouldn't they be since that's the game default resolution? - then this upscaling is by far the best I've ever seen. + Full controller support, you can rebind keys in Advanced Settings. + Multi-core support. At least, that's in Advanced Settings... but I honestly can't tell the difference on my computer so it may or may not work. By default it's in 1 core, but you can set it to Auto (why is Auto not the default option...?), 2, 4 or 8 cores. + Steam Cloud support. By default it's on Automatic, but you can manually opt to "Update local save data to Steam Cloud," "Download save data from Steam Cloud" and "delete save data from Steam Cloud." - Overly zealous Steam Cloud support. I'm not sure does the game store your config and savefiles on your computer at all by default - they're stored in Steam Cloud. At least, when I turned off Steam Cloud automation I lost everything until I manually used "Download Save Data from Steam Cloud." I would recommend that the first thing you do when you launch the game is taking off Cloud support (and restart the client) so that you won't get screwed over incase you want to continue playing (read: reading) offline. + The File menu can be hidden with a nifty little X. Pressing Alt will, as always in Windows, bring the File menu back up - this time with a nifty little + if you want to unhide the menu. + Triple language support. The game comes with Japanese dub and the text comes in English, Japanese and Traditional Chinese. There's a separate setting for System as well for the same three languages. + Dual language display support. You can set the text language to Japanese/Chinese and select "Simultaniously display text using System and language setting" and you will get both your System language (English, I assume) as well as Japanese/Chinese. Want to brush up on your moonrunes? No problem: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=368457378 + The E-Mote system, including the famous Breast Bounciness Slider. More of which later (at the very end, actually). + Everything else you'd expect from a quality VN UI, like volume adjustment per character and message window transparency.  Now then, after advertising the great UI... what else is there to say?  The "game" is SHORT. You might blaze it through in two hours and I wouldn't be surprised. This is, however, a cheap title and "Volume 1" so I find this entirely acceptable. For your money's worth... this VN by far surpasses Sakura Spirit (which at the point of this writing) is pretty much the only competitor on Steam. I'd personally recommend even full price on this title.  Plotwise, the game doesn't offer you much. If compared to Sakura Spirit, this game at least has consistency and doesn't feel like short sketches just slapped together. It's just small "slice of life" cut. Other than that, you can pretty much just expect cuteness rather than character development. And bouncing breasts (unless you set Breast Bounciness Slider into "The British Royal Guard" setting like some other Reviewer said).  The Steam version is the "All Ages" version. The full game has pornography which is forbidden on Steam. You can buy the full game from elsewhere (costs roughly double compared to the Steam version) and extract it over the Steam version. If you launch the game with -steam="yes" option you can use the full version on Steam with no problem. Achievements and everything works perfectly. I would strongly advice you against posting screenshots of adult content into Steam Cloud, however.  The English translation is iffy at times. If it was a free game, the slight iffyness would be at a fully acceptable level. This is a commercial product, so it's not acceptable. The demo had a DREADFUL translation and thankfully, the translation has noticeably improved from then. Not to perfect though, sadly.  Voice Acting felt good to me. I have absolutely no complaints. I will not praise any VA into the heavens either, but they did a solid job if you ask me.  Music is not a strong point of the game. There are no fantastic tracks in the game, but no dreadful ones either. Some musics successfully set the mood right so it's not a complete flop.  Sound Effects... ... let me be honest, the SFX of this game are outright terrible. For a commercial product they are pretty much inexcuseable. In the Steam version they might be almost okay, but if you play the full version... eugh.  The strenght of the game when compared to other games is in the E-Mote system. Not something I can properly express in text - I'd suggest you YouTube search "nekopara vol 1 introduction" for the official introductions from Sekai Project. They should give you a pretty good idea on what the E-Mote system does. But if I were to try to explain in text... well, the girls move on the screen. Constantly. This is done by having multiple layers on the girls, and interactions of these multiple layers gives them a very, very wide variety of expressions - even more so since the game mostly has catgirls, which means that they have twitchy ears and a tail. It looks absolutely gorgeous. If I were to complain about something, it is that their up-and-down sway stops whenever they're talking. And that up-and-down sway is a bit over the top to begin with... anyway, it actually makes the game feel better OUTSIDE of the CGs. Because the CGs are static and only have a few expressions made into them. Usually, you want to see the the static CGs in VNs because those are the gorgeous parts - here it's in reverse! As I said, you have to see it to get a good feel of it. A LOT of effort was put into the emotions of all the girls, it truly looks fantastic.  tl;dr; If VNs are your thing, this is a short but quite solid experience. I give it my recommendation and I am looking forward to Vol 2.
its a very nice game. Cute characters design and music and shaking boobs. the animated character make it superb game. However those who are looking for a longer gameplay might be disappointed though.

Nekopara is a beautiful love story between a man and his loyal cats showing him the value of family. It's the kind of light hearted love story that sincere, sensitive, gentle men would enjoy. Married men may want to sit this one out, but I would say it could make you more romantic and appreciative towards your spouse; clingy if you take it too far. And for any female gamers who may be interested in Nekopara: bless you for being able to step into a male protagonist's shoes and understanding.  I can not stress this enough: Nekopara is a heavenly fantasty that leaves you begging for more. Part of you will feel extremely satisfied after completion, but another part of you will be left longing for the warm embrace of a lover. IMO, these are very disirable feelings to have, and can only make you a better, sweeter person.  Nekopara Vol.1 is the first part of an upcoming series. And while the play time is only several hours, I think you may appreciate the low asking price. There is an adults-only version of the game available outside of Steam. You can read the discussion forum FAQ section for more information on where to purchase it.

This has a great story, set in the future of japan after an apocalyptic event, where a virus mutated people and cats alike. Lovely illustrations as expected, fully voiced and the animations really help to bring the cat girls to life!  A surprising amount of options for a VN, it might only be native 720p but it still looks and runs great and has many options for different scaling and cropping to full screen for any unexpected screen sizes.  I really like that it's possible to change languages on the fly and also to have multiple languages visible at once if you choose. It really shows the amount of effort that went into this release. It also has controller support which is handy for playing with Steam home streaming on TV.  It's a shame that the AO version isn't on Steam, but that's Valve's fault for believing that it's necessary to push American values on the rest of the world. NEKOPARA Vol.1 looks like it fits 100% into an outsider’s view of visual novels; a dull, fandom-focused story with pretty girls who do nothing but dote on you. Yes, these catgirls are pretty devoted, but there’s more going on than a simple harem storyline. One can’t help but be intrigued by Kashou’s devotion to baking, understanding both catgirls, and wanting to see everything turn out well. With that said, some may be put off by the sexual storyline aspect which suddenly shows up. Others might be mad knowing they’ve missed out on some scenes due to Steam’s restrictions on adult content. Still, NEKOPARA is a light and fluffy visual novel that fans of catgirls will enjoy their time with.  8/10

The  motion  in  this  game  is  fantastic  same  with  the  artwork.  As  a  anime/manga  lover  and  a  person  who  reads  a  lot  of  anime  visual  novels  i  just  cant  get  into  this game. The  plot  itself  is  just terrible  and  the  explaination  for  cat  girls  doesnt  make  sense  either. To  me  its  just fan  service, i  dont  mind  fan  service  but  with  an  unexcusible  plot  with  it  just  unsatisfies  me. Its  very  cute and  moe  but  i  cannot  explain  why  it  bugs  me  after  reading  it.  It  has  a  wonderful  system  i do  admit  but  i  hope  in  the  future  people   will  not make  visual  novels  with  motion  in  it,  that  to  me  will  just  ruin  visual  novels  itself  for  me.  One  of  the  settings  for  it,  is  Chest Bounciness, which  i  find  absurd  and  amusing,  i  can  see  why  people  would  buy  it  because  its very  cute  and  moe.  I  did  get  the  demo  for  this  game  and  was  thrilled  but  when  it  was released  everything  was  off  for  me. There  is  barely  any  character  development,  but  so  far  this  is  just  an opinion. Though  the  characters  personality  is  good  and  i  like  it,  but  the characters  postures  and  tone  of  voice  sounds  weird  to  me,  its  not  flown  well  with  eachother.    I  want  to  spread  anime  love but  not  like this, i  feel  like  the  anime  community  is  just  silly  and is  known  well  for  its  perverted  fan  service,  fan  service  isnt  bad  but  too much  gets  in  the  way  of  the  plot   thus  making  it  look  bad. This  game  offers  tight  clothing  and  a  lot  of  panty shots,  I  feel  like its a starting  point  for  motion  visual  novels.  I  believe  that  motion  visual  novels  wont  be  as  good  as  non  mottion  ones.  Ive  been  watching  and  reading  romance  genre  animes  for  almost  12  years.  I  felt  like  the  romance  in  this  novel  went by  too  fast  that its  unatural  and  has  no  reason  why  they  would  fall  in  love.  I  dont  know  how  the  main character  can  handle  2 l ove  intrests  either  nor  both  Vanilla  and  Chocola  can  deal  with  it.  My final  result  for  this  game  is 4.5/10  but  this  is  an  opinion  by  me  so  dont  let  this  encourage you  not  buying  the  game  i  say  try  out  the  demo and see if  you  like  it  or  not. (hey at least i didnt say it was crap, i didnt even compare to school days now that anime was an embarassment to all animes hehehe :p) I  know  most  of  you  will  not  like  this  review  but  stare  at  the cute  cat  maids. Short version: Short, sweet, and just fine.  Long Version:  I think for the price, it's a bit much. The entire visual novel is about 5 hours long worth to read (And this is the adult version, so cut out 30 or so minutes for the smut) so it's a relatively short for a visual novel, however unlike other VNs, every character portrait is animated with the use of programs like Emofuri (Where each part of the character is held in different layers and are warped to give the illusion of breathing and physics)  The game comes in English, Japanese and Chinese, which is a HUGE thing as this is probably the first Visual Novel I ever heard of that had a simultanious international release. There was no wait time between the Japanese release and the International release. (Even the adult version has English text in it, however expect an additional $10 from you and to convert that money to Japanese Yen)  [b]So what about the content?[/b] It's a short story. You will probably finish it in a single sitting. The voice actresses are skilled, but the main female love interests both sound the same when their have to raise their voices. The window is easily resized and you can mute some characters you dislike (I didn't do this, though I was considering muting the minor nameless characters)  That aside, I think the game is worth it, the content is definately mature, but a lot of the "mature" content seems to have a lazy excuse to occure. Buy it on Steam, buy it on Nekopara's website, either works. It's short, sweet and just fine.  Bonus points because the art was made by a artist known as Sayori who has had her hand in some eroge Visual novels in Japan such as: Phi Age's "Owarinaki Natsu, Towa Naru Shirabe" e-xtreme's "Momoiro Taisen Pairon" And least we forget Sayori's artbook "Neko Works" A supurb artist, who finally has her original characters see a visual novel.
Anyone who love cats must try this game and "E-mote" system is awesome!

Nekopara is a cheerful slice-of-life story about you and the two catgirls who tagged along when you decide to leave the family business to pursue your career in cake making. Beautifully drawn and coupled with the animations and voice acting makes it one of the best presented VN's I've ever played.   The plot isn't really there plus around chapter 5, it starts to feel like a porno (as in 'my-cat-is-in-heat-and-the-only-way-to-help-her-is-to-get-it-on-and-not-read-the-pet-care-book-i-bought-a-few-chapters-ago'). However, the characters are interesting and the sprinkle of humor and cuteness through the game is enough to make you keep clicking forward. Also, small references.   Gameplay wise, it's linear,there are no branching choices at all. You can replay previous conversations (as in replaying the sound) but not 'reverse' back to a previous scene. No option to start at different chapters. You can hide the text box to view the scene better though.  Music is nice and comfy. Fits the cheerful theme of the game very well.    Overall, the game is like a cake. It's sweet and fluffy, but it's not very filling.   Extra notes: - Twins don't mind sharing.  - It can be played with a controller, but once the game starts there is no button to access the menu. - Vanilla is best

Summary:  Nekopara is a visual novel based on the works of [Neko Works] which follows the lives of two neko, Chocola and Vanilla and their Master. They will go though a series of events which deepen their bond with their master.  Rating: 9 nyaas out of 10  Pros: - Neko grills  - Good voice acting - Deep story - Characters that actually move - Beautiful art  Cons: -Slightly generic background music -Censorship (XDD) -Lack of any user imput  My Review:  This game had me always entertain at every moment with moments of joy and sadness at times. What I enjoy the most out of this visual novel was its clear attention to detail with each character's facial movements (also the bouncyness of a certain body feature *cough*). The story is great with the great scripting with each character having lines well suited and the occational joke with the character taken to account. If you are willing to just have a game where you do nothing but read this is the game. The background music could be improved but all in all it does its job of creating the atmosphere of each event.   Note:  This is my first review of a game. I might have a thing for neko grills

Went in for catgirl moey-ness. Got exactly what I wanted.  Shame Chocola & Vanilla are the only romancable characters. I wanted to see the MC get it on with his imouto
First off: if you're bothered for it being an all-ages edition, go get the R-18 version at DLSite. It costs 2160yen (around $17).  What has drawn me to NEKOPARA was, in the first moment, the art. Sayori's art looks so great, and I got really happy when I got notice that her circle, NEKO WORKs, was going to make a visual novel. I've had my eyes set on this since it was a Greenlight candidate, and F5'd my way to getting it as soon as it got on Steam (I literally refreshed the page a few times at midnight my time (6PM PST, the release time) so I could get the game ASAP).  NEKOPARA is a heartwarming story about a confectioner, Kashou, and the Nekos around him (though the story focuses on Chocolat and Vanilla, like on all of the NEKOPARA doujinshi by NEKO WORKs). It's a short and easy to read story that will have you giggle a lot, and feel warm inside too. I have to admit that Sekai Project's translation wasn't one of the best (as usual from them), but having played the game in both Japanese and English I feel safe saying that the translation doesn't kill the game's experience (and, the R-18 scene cuts can't be noticed at all).  If you're not looking for something with a serious plot and just have to take some weight off your routine, NEKOPARA is the right choice. If you plan on getting involved with a more complex and serious plot that will take up a lot of reading time, I suggest you go get something else, as this is NOT what you're looking for.  UPDATE: http://imouto.club/ddl/ has a reintegration patch (probably breaks Steam achievements, BTW) for the game to be really full, including R-18 scenes.

So my family still think I'm some lowlife living in their loft with my waifu pillows and I can't really hold that against them cause it's true.  I think however, them seeing me on this game has led them to the verge of getting me counseling again but as this is a review of the game I can say, it's fucking worth it.   I played the demo for this game and by God was I blown away. The visual experience is astounding. I've never seen a visual novel look so amazing. The lip syncing is really good, the character animation is spot on and the general art is just brilliant as well. Who doesn't want to be surrounded by kawaii neko girls? That's right. Republicans.  The story is pretty good. You play as some guy who's fucking off to make his own bakery and become fucking Buddy Valastro from Cake Boss. Basically these cat girls who he's been living with while with his family go all Metal Gear in cardboard boxes in a moving truck to tag along with him and the story pretty much starts there.  They also have this OP song and video thing. Fuck me, it's like I'm on an acid trip. That shits amazing, like honestly, fucking amazing. I feel like I've been shifted from a visual novel to an anime. It's pretty crazy. Not only that, they've got a wide range of characters to meet so your not stuck with a few girls.   Might I also add that this game, THIS GAME! Has in the options a 'Chest Bounciness' option. Now, I'm pretty damn sure I'm not the only one here thinking this but DAMN! You know you've found a fucking good game when they have CHEST BOUNCINESS in the options menu. Genius.   Also I'd like to add that the price is great. The game is enjoyable and takes quite some time so for £6.99 full price or however much that is for 'Murica or other nationalities I imagine not that much more.   All in all, 10/10 will get hentai version.
